questions.text: Elderly woman fell down while cleaning the washroom and developed a deformity shown below. Which of the following complication is most likely to occur in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Median nerve compression

Explanation:

Colles’ fracture is a distal radius fracture occurring typically 2–3 cm proximal to the wrist joint, with:

  • Dorsal displacement of the distal fragment
  • Dorsal angulation
  • Common in elderly women after fall on outstretched hand (FOOSH)

Most common complications of Colles’ fracture include:

  • Median nerve compression / Carpal Tunnel Syndrome → due to swelling, hematoma, or displacement affecting the carpal tunnel
  • Malunion → Dinner fork deformity
  • Stiffness, especially in elderly
  • Rupture of Extensor Pollicis Longus (EPL) tendon

AVN of scaphoid (Option A): Seen with scaphoid fractures, especially waist fractures — not Colles’ fracture.
 

Radial nerve compression (Option C): The radial nerve runs more dorsally and is less likely to be compressed in distal radius fractures.
 

Ulnar nerve compression (Option D): Ulnar nerve is on the medial side of the wrist (Guyon’s canal), and not typically compressed in Colles’ fracture.

 

Fall on OutStretchedhand

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features correlates best with the pathological image shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Opsoclonus myoclonus

Explanation:

  • The image represents neuroblastoma, a common childhood tumor
  • Opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome (OMAS) is a rare paraneoplastic syndrome strongly associated with neuroblastoma
  • Characterized by chaotic eye movements (opsoclonus), myoclonic jerks, and ataxia

Opsoclonus Myoclonus and Neuroblastoma

Neuroblastoma:

  • Malignant tumor of neural crest origin
  • Arises commonly from adrenal medulla or sympathetic chain
  • Histology shows small round blue cells with Homer-Wright rosettes

Paraneoplastic Manifestation:

  • Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome is seen in ~2-3% of neuroblastoma cases
  • Caused by an autoimmune response against neuronal tissue
  • Often persists even after tumor resection

Clinical Features of OMAS:

  • Rapid, multidirectional, involuntary eye movements (opsoclonus)
  • Myoclonus: sudden, brief jerky movements
  • Ataxia: unstable gait and limb coordination issues
  • Irritability, sleep disturbance, developmental delay

Diagnosis and Workup:

  • MRI/CT to detect primary tumor
  • Urinary VMA and HVA levels (metabolites of catecholamines)
  • Biopsy for histopathology

Management:

  • Tumor resection
  • Immunotherapy: IVIG, steroids, rituximab for paraneoplastic symptoms

Cat eye reflex / Leukocoria (Option B):

  • Seen in retinoblastoma, not neuroblastoma
  • Fundoscopic appearance of white pupillary reflex

Optic neuritis (Option C):

  • Associated with multiple sclerosis, not neuroblastoma
  • Features include painful vision loss and afferent pupillary defect

Lisch nodules (Option D):

  • Seen in Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)
  • Pigmented iris hamartomas, not linked to opsoclonus or myoclonus

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is most commonly implicated in biofilm-associated infective endocarditis of cardiac implantable electronic devices?

choices.text: Gram-positive cocci forming dextran-positive colonies on sucrose media
Gamma-hemolytic, bile-esculin positive, PYR-positive diplococci from a urinary source
Coagulase-negative, novobiocin-sensitive cocci from lead pocket
Golden-yellow β-hemolytic colonies on blood agar with catalase and coagulase positivity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Coagulase-negative, novobiocin-sensitive cocci from lead pocket

Explanation:

  • Cardiac implantable electronic devices (CIEDs) like pacemakers and defibrillators are prone to device-associated infections, which are typically biofilm-mediated.
  • The most common organism implicated in biofilm-associated infective endocarditis (CIED-IE) is:

Staphylococcus epidermidis

  • Coagulase-negative Staphylococcus (CoNS), Novobiocin-sensitive
  • Produces extracellular polysaccharide matrix → biofilm formation
  • Colonizes skin flora, which is often the source of contamination during device implantation
  • Low virulence, but difficult to eradicate once biofilm is formed
  • Presents with low-grade fever, lead pocket swelling, and positive blood cultures
  • Often requires device removal + prolonged antibiotics

Option A: Refers to Streptococcus mutans (dextran-producing viridans strep) → more native valve IE, usually post-dental procedures

Option B: Describes Enterococcus faecalis/faecium → often GU-source endocarditis.

Option D: Refers to Staphylococcus aureus → more acute, hematogenous, not typically device biofilm-associated

questions.text: A child with biliary atresia will usually present by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 7 days of life

Explanation:

  • Persistent jaundice after 7 days of life is a red flag for pathological causes such as biliary atresia.
  • Biliary atresia usually begins to manifest clinically around day 7, although diagnosis is typically made in the 3rd to 6th week.

Biliary Atresia

Definition:

  • Biliary atresia is a progressive, fibro-obliterative disorder of the extrahepatic biliary system, leading to obstruction of bile flow, cholestasis, and eventually liver failure if untreated.

Etiology:

  • Idiopathic in most cases
  • Possibly due to perinatal viral infections or autoimmune-mediated bile duct injury

Typical Clinical Course:

  • Birth: Infant appears normal
  • By day 7: Persistent jaundice that does not resolve; may still be subtle at this stage
  • 2–4 weeks: Development of pale (acholic) stools, dark urine, and hepatomegaly
  • Beyond 4–6 weeks: Liver damage progresses, leading to failure to thrive, coagulopathy, and signs of chronic liver disease

Warning Signs (Red Flags in Neonatal Jaundice):

  • Jaundice persisting beyond 2 weeks in term infants
  • Elevated direct (conjugated) bilirubin
  • Acholic stools and dark yellow urine

Investigations:

  • Serum bilirubin: Raised conjugated bilirubin fraction
  • Liver enzymes: Elevated AST, ALT, and GGT
  • Ultrasound: May show absent or small gallbladder
  • Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan: No tracer excretion into intestines
  • Liver biopsy: Bile duct proliferation, portal tract edema, and fibrosis

Management:

  • Kasai portoenterostomy (hepatoportoenterostomy):
    • Best outcomes when performed before 60 days of life
    • Restores bile flow by connecting small intestine to liver surface
  • Liver transplantation may be needed in case of Kasai failure or late diagnosis

Prognosis:

  • Early diagnosis and surgery improve prognosis
  • Delay in recognition (especially beyond 60–90 days) is associated with worse liver outcomes

24 hours of life (Option A):

  • At this stage, most neonatal jaundice is physiological.
  • Biliary atresia does not manifest this early.

3 weeks of life (Option C):

  • While this is the average age at diagnosis, the clinical signs start appearing around day 7.
  • Delaying until week 3 misses the opportunity for early suspicion and testing.

3 months of life (Option D):

  • By 3 months, infants with untreated biliary atresia will often have advanced liver damage and signs of cirrhosis.
  • Intervention at this stage has poorer outcomes.

questions.text: Which is not correct about active management of third stage of labour?

choices.text: Injection methergin to mother within one minute of delivery of baby
Wait for spontaneous expulsion of placenta
Ligate the cord and inspect for abnormalities

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Wait for spontaneous expulsion of placenta

Explanation:

  • Active Management of the Third Stage of Labour (AMTSL) includes:
    • Administration of uterotonic (e.g., Methergine or Oxytocin)
    • Controlled cord traction
    • Delayed cord clamping
    • Uterine massage after delivery of placenta
  • Waiting for spontaneous expulsion is part of expectant management, not AMTSL.
  • Cord inspection is important for completeness of placenta. (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Bi-spectral Index monitoring is correct?

choices.text: Processes EEG signals to provide a numerical value indicating duration of aesthesia
Value of 40-60 indicates appropriate level for performing surgery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: (Option C) Value of 40–60 indicates appropriate level for performing surgery

Explanation:
Bi-spectral Index (BIS) monitoring is a non-invasive technique that uses processed EEG signals to assess the depth of anaesthesia. It outputs a numerical score from 0 to 100:

  • 100 = fully awake
  • 40–60 = adequate level of anaesthesia for surgery
  • <40 = deep hypnotic state or burst suppression

A BIS value of 40–60 correlates with adequate hypnotic depth and low probability of awareness under anaesthesia, making it ideal for most surgical procedures.

Processes EEG signals to provide a numerical value indicating duration of anaesthesia (Option A): BIS does not measure duration, but rather current depth of anaesthesia based on EEG-derived parameters.

Placed on the patient’s chest (Option B): The BIS sensor is placed on the forehead/scalp, not the chest, because it requires direct access to brain electrical activity.

Directly measures cerebral perfusion pressure (Option D): BIS measures cortical electrical activity, not cerebral blood flow or perfusion pressure. Cerebral perfusion pressure is calculated based on mean arterial pressure and intracranial pressure, not from EEG.

questions.text: Which is not correct about Cheyne stokes respiration

choices.text: Seen in conditions that lower Intracranial pressure

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Seen in conditions that lower Intracranial pressure

Explanation:

Cheyne-Stokes Respiration is not seen in conditions that lower intracranial pressure; rather, it typically occurs in conditions that increase intracranial pressure, such as stroke, brain injury, or tumors.

  • A type of abnormal breathing pattern characterized by cyclic periods of apnea followed by gradually increasing and then decreasing tidal volumes.
  • Cause: Delay in feedback between blood CO₂ levels and respiratory drive.
  • Seen in:
    • Advanced heart failure (Option B ruled out)
    • Stroke or brain injury (↑ intracranial pressure) (Option A)
    • High altitude (Option C ruled out)
    • Central sleep apnea (Option D ruled out)
  • Mechanism: Instability in the respiratory control center of the brainstem.
  • Clinical Significance: Suggests neurologic or cardiac dysfunction, often a poor prognostic sign in heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is called golgi tendon reflex
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Inverse stretch reflex

Explanation:

The Golgi tendon reflex is also known as the inverse stretch reflex.

  • Receptor: Golgi tendon organ (located at the muscle–tendon junction)
  • Stimulus: Excessive tension in the muscle
  • Reflex arc:
    • Afferent: Group Ib sensory fibers
    • Integration: Spinal cord (inhibitory interneurons)
    • Efferent: Alpha motor neuron inhibition of the same muscle
  • Response: Inhibition (relaxation) of the muscle under tension
  • Function: Protective reflex to prevent tendon or muscle damage from over-contraction
  • Opposite to stretch reflex, which causes contraction

Myotatic reflex (Option A) is another name for the Stretch reflex (Option B), which is mediated by muscle spindles and triggers muscle contraction in response to stretch, such as in the knee jerk reflex.
 

Withdrawal reflex (Option D): A polysynaptic pain reflex, not related to tendon tension.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of triad of Autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome type 1?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Type 1 Diabetes mellitus

Explanation:

  • Autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome type 1 has Addison disease, hypoparathyroidism and mucocutaneous candidiasis and presents in early infancy.
  • Mnemonic is CHAI is Tea

C: Candidiasis

H: Hypoparathyroidism

A: Addison, AIRE gene on chromosome 21, Autosomal recessive

I: infancy

T: Thyroid disorders: Grave and autoimmune thyroiditis

Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome Type 1

Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome Type 2

Endocrine

Endocrine

Addison's disease Hypoparathyroidism

Addison's disease Type 1 diabetes

Hypogonadism

Graves' disease or autoimmune thyroiditis

Graves' disease or autoimmune thyroiditis

Hypogonadism

Type 1 diabetes

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of High anion gap metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Causes of HAGMA

Causes of NAGMA

KULT: mnemonic

DR FUSE: mnemonic
  • Ketoacidosis
  • Uremia- AKI, ATN
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Toxins
  • Inborn errors of metabolism like organic acidemia, pyruvate decarboxylase deficiency etc.
  • Diarrhea
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Fistula
  • Ureterosigmoidostomy

questions.text: A primigravida 30-year-old lady has developed Leakage per vaginum for last 24 hours at 32 weeks of gestation. Which complication can develop in the mother?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Chorioamniotis

Explanation:

  • Preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM) predisposes to ascending infections such as chorioamnionitis, especially after 24 hours.
  • Chorioamnionitis in the PPROM setting requires urgent management to prevent serious complications.
  • Prompt delivery, preferably vaginal, is crucial when chorioamnionitis is diagnosed.
  • Antibiotics are essential in managing chorioamnionitis.
  • Even without detectable bacteria, intra-amniotic inflammation is risky, especially with early preterm labour onset.
  • In preterm pregnancies, bacteria in amniotic fluid often cause labour, unlike in term pregnancies, where it results from the labour process.
  • Diagnosing chorioamnionitis is challenging; maternal leukocytosis is inconsistent, and fever (≥ 38°C or 100.4°F) is the most reliable indicator. Lower temperatures and other clinical risk factors can also suggest infection.
  • Chorioamnionitis increases fetal and neonatal morbidity, leading to sepsis, respiratory distress, early-onset seizures, intraventricular haemorrhage, periventricular leukomalacia, and cerebral palsy.
  • Amniotic fluid embolism (Option A): Rare, acute emergency, not common in PPROM.
  • Complete abortion (Option B): Not applicable at 32 weeks gestation.
  • Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) (Option D): Fetal complication, not maternal.

questions.text: 35-year-old G4P3A0L3 lady with 12 weeks of amenorrhea presents with vaginal bleeding and has noticed some grape like vesicles expelled per vaginum with lower abdominal discomfort. On pelvic examination uterus is enlarged more than period of gestation and feels doughy. Cervix is favourable and FHS is not heard. Sonography report is shown below. Which is best management of this case?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Suction evacuation

Explanation:

  • In a case of complete hydatidiform mole (grape-like vesicles, enlarged uterus, absent FHS), the preferred management is suction evacuation, which allows complete removal and monitoring of β-hCG.
  • Hysterectomy (Option B) is reserved for older women or those with recurrent disease.
  • Methotrexate (Option D) is used in gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN), not initial mole.
  • Hysterotomy (Option C) is obsolete due to high bleeding risk.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with complaints of palpitations and dizziness after playing lawn tennis. She is having multiple such episodes for the past 2 years. ECG is shown below. Which of the following is correct about histopathological findings seen in this patient?

choices.text: Hypertrophy of myocytes with fragmented nuclei

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fibrofatty replacement on cardiac biopsy

Explanation:

This patient is of young age and has recurrent palpitations & dizziness. ECG shows epsilon waves (a small positive deflection at the end of the QRS in V1–V3) and her symptoms trigger during exertion (e.g., playing tennis). All strongly suggest Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia/Cardiomyopathy (ARVD/ARVC).

 

Histopathological Hallmark:

Replacement of right ventricular myocardium by Fatty and Fibrous tissue → Known as fibrofatty replacement, most often seen in the RV free wall.

 

Helter Skelter appearance of myocytes (Option B): This is seen in HCM (Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy) due to disorganised hypertrophied fibers. There is no fat infiltration, unlike ARVC.

 

Hypertrophy of myocytes with fragmented nuclei (Option C): Primarily seen in HCM, but can also be seen in DCM in later stages.

  • HCM: prominent myocyte hypertrophy with nuclear enlargement and bizarre shapes.
  • DCM: may show mild hypertrophy and nuclear changes, but not disarray; mostly shows myocyte atrophy and interstitial fibrosis.

Amyloid deposition between myocytes (Option D): This is seen in restrictive cardiomyopathy (e.g., amyloidosis), not in ARVC.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about the congenital malformation shown below?

choices.text: Failure of closure of posterior neuropore
Death due to renal agenesis and pulmonary hypoplasia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Failure of closure of posterior neuropore

Explanation:

The image depicts Sirenomelia, or Mermaid Syndrome, and the incorrect statement about this condition is that it results from failure of closure of the posterior neuropore.

  • A congenital anomaly characterized by fusion of the lower limbs, resembling a mermaid’s tail.
  • It is associated with severe urogenital and gastrointestinal malformations, including renal agencies and imperforate anus.
  • The condition is thought to result from a vascular steal phenomenon, where abdominal blood flow from a persistent vitelline artery diverts blood away from the caudal structures. (Option C ruled out)
  • It is often lethal due to renal agencies and pulmonary hypoplasia. (Option D ruled out)
  • Antenatal diagnosis is possible via ultrasound as early as the first trimester.

 

Defect of gastrulation (Option B): Sirenomelia arises from a gastrulation defect affecting the formation of the caudal mesoderm, which is responsible for development of the lower body structures.

questions.text: Incorrect about pityriasis Rosea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Civatte bodies

Explanation:

  • Civatte bodies are eosinophilic apoptotic keratinocytes typically seen in Lichen planus, not in Pityriasis Rosea. Hence, this statement is incorrect.

HHV-7 (Option A): Pityriasis Rosea is thought to be associated with reactivation of HHV-6 and HHV-7, which are human herpesviruses.

Christmas tree appearance (Option B): This describes the typical pattern of lesions distributed along Langer’s lines on the trunk, resembling a Christmas tree.

Mother patch on trunk (Option C): Also known as a herald patch, it is the initial larger lesion that appears on the trunk 1–2 weeks before the secondary rash.

questions.text: In ACLS, which of the following is correct about the last component shown?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Recovery

Explanation

  • The last component points to recovery.
  • Emphasizes long-term care, neurologic rehabilitation, and functional support after initial treatement

 

 

Post cardiac care (Option A) is 5th step, Defibrillator (Option C) is 3rd step, and Adavanced resuscitation (Option D) is the 4th step.

questions.text: 28-year-old G2P1A0L1 lady presents in labour pain at 34 weeks of gestation for past 6 hours. On examination she looks tired, anxious and HR= 110/min with BP of 140/90 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows periodic uterine contraction with fetal heart rate of 80/min. CTG was done and shows FHR of persistently < 100 /min. Which of the following is not to be done in this case?

choices.text: Requisition for Blood transfusion and Plan for urgent LSCS

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Tocolysis with Atosiban

Explanation:

  • In the presence of fetal bradycardia (<100 bpm) and non-reassuring cardiotocography (CTG), tocolysis is contraindicated because delaying delivery may worsen hypoxia.
  • Betamethasone (Option A): Given to enhance lung maturity, but timing is crucial.
  • Left lateral position (Option B): Improves uteroplacental perfusion.
  • Plan LSCS (Option D): Necessary for fetal distress.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with the following lesions and a skin biopsy is performed. Which of the following findings and treatment options is most consistent with this condition?

choices.text: Histology shows Munro micro-abscesses; treated with topical coal tar
Histology reveals saw-toothing of rete ridges treated with topical corticosteroids
Histology shows "tombstone" basal cells; treated with systemic corticosteroids
Histology reveals molluscum bodies treated with curettage or imiquimod

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Histology reveals saw-toothing of rete ridges treated with topical corticosteroids

Explanation:

  • The image shows violaceous, polygonal, flat-topped papules typically seen on the lower legs and feet, which is characteristic of lichen planus.
  • Biopsy shows saw-tooth appearance of rete ridges with band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermo-epidermal junction.
  • Treated with topical corticosteroids as first-line.

Lichen Planus

Definition:

  • A chronic inflammatory mucocutaneous disorder involving skin, nails, mucosa, and hair.

Etiology and Pathogenesis:

  • Autoimmune in nature: T-cell mediated attack on basal keratinocytes
  • May be associated with Hepatitis C, certain drugs (e.g., ACE inhibitors, NSAIDs), or idiopathic

Clinical Features:

  • Classic 6 Ps:
    • Pruritic
    • Purple
    • Polygonal
    • Planar
    • Papules and Plaques
  • Wickham striae: White lacy pattern seen over lesions or mucosa
  • Distribution: Flexor surfaces, wrists, legs, oral mucosa

Histopathology:

  • Hypergranulosis, acanthosis
  • Saw-tooth appearance of rete ridges
  • Dense band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at dermo-epidermal junction
  • Civatte bodies: apoptotic keratinocytes

Treatment:

  • Topical corticosteroids: first-line for cutaneous involvement
  • Systemic steroids or immunosuppressants in severe cases
  • Antihistamines for pruritus

 

Histology shows Munro micro-abscesses; treated with topical coal tar (Option A):

  • Refers to psoriasis, not lichen planus.
  • Psoriatic plaques are silvery scales on extensor surfaces.

Histology shows "tombstone" basal cells; treated with systemic corticosteroids (Option C):

  • Describes pemphigus vulgaris, a blistering disorder.
  • This image does not show flaccid bullae or mucosal erosions.

Histology reveals molluscum bodies treated with curettage or imiquimod (Option D):

  • Molluscum contagiosum presents as umbilicated pearly papules, not flat-topped violaceous lesions.

questions.text: eGFR grade 3 A is?

A 30-year-old female presents with a history of weight loss, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, and pleural effusion. HRCT shows a "tree-in-bud" appearance with lung consolidation and effusion. Pleural fluid analysis reveals low ADA levels and lymphocytic predominance. What is the most likely finding on a biopsy from the lymph node?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Necrotizing epithelioid granuloma

Explanation:

Clinical history plus CT findings plus lymphocytosis is highly suggestive of tuberculosis etiology. High Adenosine levels are diagnostic of pleural TB but low levels do not rule out TB. High endemicity of TB is another reason for favoring TB diagnosis.

Biopsy: Necrotizing epithelioid granuloma is a characteristic finding of TB.

Reactive hyperplasia (Option A): Non-specific. Seen in viral infections or inflammation but doesn’t explain granulomas or HRCT findings.

Fungal hyphae (Option C): Would be seen in immunocompromised hosts and have distinct histology (e.g. branching septate hyphae). Not likely with this presentation.

Anthracosis pigment (Option D): Seen in smokers or people with heavy pollution exposure. Doesn’t cause systemic symptoms or pleural effusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for development of Pseudomyxoma peritonei?

choices.text: Drop down metastasis from stomach cancer to ovary

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Mucinous cyst adenoma

Explanation:

  • Pseudomyxoma peritonei is a condition where mucin accumulates in the peritoneal cavity, often due to rupture of:
    • Mucinous cystadenoma or cystadenocarcinoma of ovary or appendix.
  • Serous tumors don't produce mucin. (Option B)
  • Drop metastases from stomach (Krukenberg) cause solid tumors, not mucin. (Option C)
  • Theca lutein cysts are non-mucinous functional cysts. (Option D)

questions.text: Most important external sign of drowning is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lathery froth at the mouth

Explanation:

Lathery froth at the mouth:

  • This is considered the most characteristic external sign of drowning, especially freshwater drowning.
  • Features of the froth:
    • Fine, white, persistent, lathery bubbles
    • Seen at the mouth and nostrils
    • Increases on chest compression
  • It indicates active respiration in water and confirms the person was alive at the time of submersion (i.e., ante-mortem drowning).

Cadaveric spasm (Option B):

  • It is instantaneous stiffening of a muscle at the time of death, seen in cases of sudden violent deaths, not specific to drowning.
  • May be seen in the hand grasping weeds or grass, supporting drowning but not a consistent or definitive sign.

Cutis anserina (Option C):

  • Refers to "goose skin" appearance from contraction of erector pili muscles.
  • It is non-specific, and may be seen in cold deaths or prolonged immersion.

Washerwoman hands (Option D):

  • Refers to skin wrinkling of fingers/toes after immersion.
  • Seen in any prolonged immersion, not diagnostic of drowning.

questions.text: The following lung specimen is of a person who expired due to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Drowning

Explanation:

The lung specimen shows:

  • Grossly swollen, ballooned lungs
  • Dark red discoloration
  • Mottled, congested surface (classic "mosaic" appearance)
  • Wet and glistening pleural surface, consistent with pulmonary oedema

These findings are hallmark of drowning, where fluid inhalation leads to:

  • Acute pulmonary oedema
  • Emphysema aquosum
  • Overdistension and heavy lungs

COVID-19 pneumonia (Option A):

  • Lungs in COVID-19 show rubbery consistency, consolidation, and diffuse alveolar damage, not the marked oedematous congestion seen here.
  • No "mosaic pattern" or gross ballooning is typically noted.

Strangulation (Option C):

  • Though it may show congestion and petechiae, the lungs are not grossly oedematous or ballooned like in drowning.
  • No typical fluid-filled or overinflated lung pattern.

Lung laceration (Option D):

  • Involves direct trauma, leading to visible tears, haemorrhagic tracks, and blood pooling.
  • This image lacks evidence of direct injury or laceration.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about scorpion sting?

choices.text: Neurotoxins that cause sodium channels to close
Tap test increases pain and paresthesia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Neurotoxins that cause sodium channels to close

Explanation:

Scorpion venom contains neurotoxins that keep sodium channels open, not closed. This prolonged depolarisation leads to continuous neuronal excitation, resulting in massive release of catecholamines, hence producing an autonomic storm.

Autonomic storm (Option A):

  • Hallmark feature of scorpion sting.
  • Caused by excessive sympathetic and parasympathetic discharge due to sodium channel activation.
  • Presents with hypertension, tachycardia, diaphoresis, salivation, and sometimes pulmonary oedema.

Prazosin used for cardiovascular effects (Option C):

  • Prazosin, an α1 blocker, is used to counteract catecholamine-induced hypertension and cardiac failure.
  • It is the drug of choice in scorpion sting-induced cardiovascular toxicity.

Tap test increases pain and paresthesia (Option D):

  • Tap test (tapping the sting site) may exacerbate local pain or paresthesias, confirming neuropathic involvement due to venom action.

Grade

Effects

Treatment

1

Local effects only

Analgesia, local anesthesia

2

Autonomic excitation

Antivenom, prazosin
 

Agitation and anxiety

Benzodiazepines

3

Pulmonary edema

Admission to intensive care unit, noninvasive or mechanical ventilation, antivenom
 

Hypotension and cardiogenic shock 

 Antivenom, dobutamine 
  Severe neuromuscular excitation (associated with centruroides species) Antivenom, benzodiazepines 
  Multiorgan failure, including coma, seizures, and end-organ damage caused by hypotension  supportive care, mechanical ventilation, inotropes (e.g., dobutamine), benzodiazepines

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the procedure shown in the diagram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Whipple procedure

Explanation:

  • The diagram depicts a pancreaticoduodenectomy, also known as the Whipple procedure.
  • Key features include removal of the pancreatic head, duodenum, gallbladder, distal stomach, and common bile duct, followed by reconstruction via multiple anastomoses.

Whipple Procedure (Pancreaticoduodenectomy)

Indications:

  • Carcinoma head of pancreas (most common)
  • Ampullary carcinoma
  • Cholangiocarcinoma (distal common bile duct)
  • Duodenal carcinoma
  • Selected cases of chronic pancreatitis

Structures Removed in Classical Whipple:

  • Head of the pancreas
  • Duodenum (first and second parts)
  • Distal stomach (antrum or pylorus depending on variant)
  • Common bile duct (distal portion)
  • Gallbladder

Types:

  • Classical Whipple: Includes distal stomach resection
  • Pylorus-preserving Whipple (PPPD): Pylorus is spared, used increasingly when feasible

Reconstruction (Triple Anastomosis):

  1. Pancreaticojejunostomy – pancreatic remnant anastomosed to jejunum
  2. Hepaticojejunostomy – bile duct anastomosed to jejunum
  3. Gastrojejunostomy – stomach anastomosed to jejunum

Purpose:

  • Re-establish continuity of the gastrointestinal and biliary tracts after resection.
  • Prevent reflux and leakage of bile/pancreatic secretions.

Postoperative Considerations:

  • Delayed gastric emptying
  • Pancreatic fistula
  • Nutritional deficiencies (especially if stomach resection is extensive)

Billroth I procedure (Option A):

  • Involves gastroduodenostomy – direct anastomosis of stomach to duodenum.
  • Performed after distal gastrectomy.
  • Does not involve pancreas, bile duct, or gallbladder.

Billroth II procedure (Option B):

  • Involves gastrojejunostomy – stomach to jejunum with duodenal stump closed.
  • Also used after distal gastrectomy.
  • Pancreas and biliary structures are not resected.

Roux-en-Y cholecystojejunostomy (Option C):

  • Creates a bypass from gallbladder to jejunum.
  • Typically done in cases of malignant biliary obstruction.
  • Does not involve duodenum or pancreas.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man with a history of sleeping pill abuse is brought to the emergency department with confusion, dry mouth, dilated pupils, flushed skin, and visual hallucinations after reportedly chewing seeds from a wild plant. Vitals reveal tachycardia and hyperthermia. Which of the following is the most appropriate antidote in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Physostigmine

Explanation:

  • This patient has classic features of anticholinergic toxicity:
    • Confusion, hallucinations (central effects)
    • Flushed skin, dry mouth, mydriasis, tachycardia, hyperthermia (peripheral effects)
  • The source is likely Datura (aka "Jimsonweed"), which contains atropine-like alkaloids (e.g., atropine, scopolamine), responsible for antimuscarinic poisoning.
  • Physostigmine, a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, is the antidote of choice. It crosses the blood-brain barrier and reverses both central and peripheral anticholinergic symptoms.

Neostigmine (Option A): It is also an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, but does not cross the blood-brain barrier, so it's ineffective for central anticholinergic symptoms (like confusion and hallucinations).

Naloxone (Option B): Used to reverse opioid overdose, characterized by miosis, respiratory depression, and bradycardia — not present here.

Flumazenil (Option D): Antidote for benzodiazepine overdose, but contraindicated in chronic users (like this patient) due to seizure risk and limited efficacy outside benzo toxicity.

questions.text: 24-year-old primigravida with 26 weeks of gestation by USG report is having complaints of Daily headaches and some swelling in her feet. Her BP is measured to be 150/90 mm Hg. She is previously normotensive as per her medical records. Work up shows 2 random clean catch urine specimens having no proteinuria. Fundus examination is normal. KFT and serum uric acid are normal. Which is correct about her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Gestational Hypertension

Explanation:

  • Gestational hypertension is diagnosed when new-onset hypertension (≥140/90 mmHg) arises after 20 weeks of gestation without proteinuria or other signs of organ dysfunction.
  • Eclampsia (Option A): Preeclampsia + generalized tonic-clonic seizures.
  • Pre-eclampsia (Option C): BP >140/90 after 20 weeks gestation associated with:
    • Proteinuria: ≥300 mg/24 h of urine or 1+ on urine dipstick
    • Urine protein: creatinine >0.3 Or
    • End organ damage: platelets <1,00,000/microL; Creatinine >1.1 mg/dL; doubling of serum transaminase level; headache, visual disturbances
  • Chronic kidney disease (Option D): Usually associated with persistent proteinuria or abnormal renal parameters predating pregnancy.

questions.text: Correct about lathyrism is all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Oedema of both limbs

Explanation:

Lathyrism is a neurodegenerative disease caused by excessive consumption of Lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal), especially during famine conditions. It is primarily due to a toxin called BOAA (β-N-oxalyl amino alanine).

Lathyrism affects motor neurons, not fluid balance or protein metabolism directly.

Oedema is not a feature of lathyrism. This points more toward nutritional deficiencies like Kwashiorkor, nephrotic syndrome, or heart failure.

Khesari dal consumption (Option A): The disease is caused by chronic consumption of khesari dal (Lathyrus sativus), which contains the neurotoxin BOAA. It is ​​common in parts of India like Bihar, UP, and MP.

Spastic paraparesis (Option B): It is a classic presentation- Upper motor neuron (UMN) type weakness in both lower limbs. This leads to spastic gait and crippling paralysis in severe cases. Typically, there is no sensory loss or bladder involvement.

Vitamin C prophylaxis (Option C): Actually, Vitamin C prophylaxis is used in Scurvy, not lathyrism. The correct preventive strategy for lathyrism is:

  • Avoidance of Khesari dal
  • Nutritional diversification
  • Detoxification of the dal (e.g., soaking, parboiling)

questions.text: Name the defect shown below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bladder exstrophy

Explanation:

The image depicts Ectopia vesicae (also known as Bladder Exstrophy).

  • It is a rare congenital defect where the urinary bladder is exposed outside the abdomen due to a failure to develop the lower abdominal wall.
  • M/c in males.

Clinical Feature

Description

Visible Bladder Exposure

The bladder mucosa is exposed on the lower abdomen, typically above the pubic symphysis, and can range from the exposed trigone to the entire bladder.

Genital Abnormalities

Males: Epispadias (urethra opens on the dorsal side of the penis), short and broad penis, upward curvature

Females: Bifid clitoris, separation of the labia minora, abnormal vaginal opening

Abdominal Wall Defect

Absence of lower abdominal wall muscles, widened pubic symphysis, diastasis of rectus muscles

Outward rotation of pelvic bones

Higher incidence of indirect inguinal hernia

Urological

Continuous leakage of urine due to the inability to close the bladder outlet. Vesicoureteral reflux, possible renal anomalies like renal dysplasia or hydronephrosis.

Anorectum

Rectal prolapse

Imperforate anus

Shortened perineum

 

Omphalocele (membrane sac)

(Option B ruled out)

Gastroschisis (exposed viscera)

(Option C ruled out)

Umbilical cord in midline

Umbilical cord is attached paraumbilical to right side

Covered with peritoneum and amnion

Exposed bowel
  • Cover with sterile non adherent dressing
  • Gentle reduction of viscera into abdomen and primary closure if small.
  • Staged closure using silo if viscera is large like contains liver
  • Cover with sterile soaked gauze/plastic wrap
  • Closure within hours if bowel loops not edematous or inflamed
  • If not feasible gradual reduction using silo bag

Ectopia cordis (Option D) is rare defect where the heart is located outside the thoracic cavity, usually due to failure of the sternum to close.

questions.text: For evaluation of vaccine coverage best method is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cluster random sampling 

Explanation: This method is the most appropriate and widely used for evaluating vaccine coverage, particularly in large, geographically dispersed populations (like those in developing countries). The population is divided into "clusters" (e.g., villages, urban blocks, or health districts). A random sample of these clusters is chosen, and then a systematic or simple random sample of individuals within the selected clusters is surveyed. It is highly practical and cost-effective. The World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF have successfully used a standardized cluster sampling methodology (e.g., the 30-cluster survey) for decades to assess immunization coverage.

Systematic random sampling (Option A): This method involves selecting subjects at regular intervals from a list of the entire population (e.g., every 5th person). While statistically sound, it is logistically impractical for a large-scale vaccine coverage survey. Creating a complete and accurate list (a sampling frame) of every person in a large country or region is virtually impossible. This method would also require survey teams to travel to scattered, individual households, making it very expensive and time-consuming.

Stratified random sampling (Option B): This method involves dividing the population into subgroups (strata) based on certain characteristics (e.g., age, gender, rural/urban). A random sample is then drawn from each stratum. This method is useful for ensuring representation from different subgroups and for making comparisons between them. However, similar to systematic sampling, it still requires a comprehensive sampling frame for each stratum, which is difficult to obtain in large-scale public health surveys. While a valid method in theory, it is often not the most practical choice for a primary coverage survey.

Snowball sampling (Option D): This is a non-probability sampling method where participants recruit future participants from their social networks. It is highly prone to bias and is used for studying hard-to-reach or hidden populations (e.g., drug users, sex workers). It is completely inappropriate for evaluating a public health metric like vaccine coverage, as the results would not be representative of the general population and could lead to significant over- or under-estimation.

questions.text:
A New diagnostic test was evaluated for detecting a disease in a population of 1,000 individuals. The results are as follows. Calculate the negative predictive value


	
		
			 
			
			Disease present 
			
			
			Disease absent 
			
			
			Total 
			
		
		
			
			Test positive 
			
			
			180
			
			
			70
			
			
			250
			
		
		
			
			Test negative 
			
			
			20
			
			
			730
			
			
			750
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 97%

Explanation:

True Negatives (TN): The number of individuals who tested negative and are actually disease-absent = 730

False Negatives (FN): The number of individuals who tested negative but are actually disease-present = 20

Total people who tested negative: 730 + 20 = 750

NPV = True Negatives / Total people who tested negative = 730 / 750 = 0.973 or 97.3% (Option D)

questions.text: A 45-year old HIV positive patient presents with chronic diarrhea for the past 1 month. Stool examination using Kinyoun staining is performed. Which is the correct diagnosis and treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cystoisospora, Cotrimoxazole

Explanation:

  • A HIV-positive patient with chronic diarrhea indicates a likely opportunistic parasitic infection.
  • Kinyoun stains reveal elliptical, large oocysts with two sporoblasts, a hallmark of Cystoisospora belli.
  • Cotrimoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the first-line treatment.

Cystoisospora belli (Isospora belli)

Etiology & Pathogen:

  • Caused by Cystoisospora belli, a coccidian protozoan.
  • Opportunistic infection in immunocompromised hosts, especially with CD4 count <200 cells/mm³.

Clinical Features:

  • Watery, non-bloody diarrhea lasting for weeks
  • Abdominal pain, anorexia, weight loss, and malaise
  • Common in AIDS patients

Diagnosis:

  • Modified acid-fast stain (Kinyoun stain) of stool:
    • Elliptical oocysts with two sporoblasts – diagnostic of Cystoisospora belli

Treatment:

  • Cotrimoxazole (TMP-SMX) – drug of choice for both treatment and prophylaxis
  • Alternative: Pyrimethamine + folinic acid (if sulfa allergy)

Prophylaxis:

  • Secondary prophylaxis often continued until immune reconstitution with ART

Cystoisospora, Nitazoxanide (Option A):

  • Nitazoxanide has some activity but is not first-line; TMP-SMX is more effective.

Cryptosporidium, Nitazoxanide (Option C):

  • Cryptosporidium oocysts are round and smaller (4–6 µm).
  • Nitazoxanide works in immunocompetent hosts, but is less effective in AIDS.

Cryptosporidium, Cotrimoxazole (Option D):

  • Cotrimoxazole is not effective for Cryptosporidium.
  • No definitive treatment exists for AIDS patients other than HAART to restore immunity.

questions.text: Which of the following has non-bile-stained eggs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) H. Nana

Explanation:

  • Hymenolepis nana (H. nana) produces non-bile-stained eggs. These eggs are colorless, thin-shelled, and appear clear in microscopy since they do not absorb bile pigments.

Bile stained eggs : CAT-F

Non bile Stained: HEN

Clonorchis Sinesis (Option C ruled out)

Ascariasis (Option A ruled out)

Trichuriasis

Tenia (Option B ruled out)

Fasciola

H. Nana

Enterobius Vermicularis

Necator americanus

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Behçet's disease is incorrect?

choices.text: Pathergy test is done under the ISG criteria
Intestinal manifestations resemble those of Crohn's disease
Oral and genital ulcers on dorsal aspect of penis are common features
It is associated with a higher risk of thrombosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Oral and genital ulcers on dorsal aspect of penis are common features

Explanation:

  • Behçet’s disease is a systemic vasculitis involving both arteries and veins of all sizes. It presents with recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, arthritis, and systemic features. Thrombosis and neurological involvement may also occur.

  • In males, genital ulcers typically occur on the scrotum, not the dorsal aspect of the penis. (Option C)

  • In females, ulcers tend to occur on the vulva or vaginal mucosa.

  • Pathergy test (Option A) (development of pustule at needle prick site within 24–48 hrs) is a part of the International Study Group (ISG) criteria.

  • Intestinal involvement in BD may resemble Crohn’s disease (ulcerations, transmural inflammation). (Option B)

  • BD is a vasculitic disorder and strongly associated with venous and arterial thrombosis due to endothelial dysfunction and hypercoagulability. (Option D)

questions.text: A 16 year old teenager with type 1 DM is having the following skin lesions on the shin. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum

Explanation:

  • Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is a chronic granulomatous skin condition associated with diabetes mellitus, especially Type 1 DM. It typically presents with yellowish-brown, atrophic plaques with raised violaceous borders and telangiectasia, commonly over the shin. It is more common in females and often occurs before or after the onset of DM.

Acanthosis nigricans (Option A): Presents as velvety, hyperpigmented thickening of the skin, typically over intertriginous areas like the neck and axilla—not the shin. It's associated with insulin resistance (often in Type 2 DM), not with well-demarcated plaques or telangiectasia.

Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (Option C): Occurs in hypercoagulable states, especially with visceral malignancies (Trousseau syndrome). Presents as painful, inflamed superficial veins, not as atrophic plaques over the shin.

Necrolytic migratory erythema (Option D): Classically associated with glucagonoma, this presents as erythematous, eroded, and crusted plaques, often in perioral, perineal, and lower abdominal areas, not localized to the shin, and unrelated to Type 1 DM.

questions.text: Which is true about diagonal conjugate?

choices.text: Upper border of symphysis pubis to mid point of sacral promontory
Lower border of symphysis pubis to mid-point of sacral promontory
Upper border of ilio-pubic eminence to mid-point of sacral promontory
Lower border of ilio-pubic eminence to mid-point of sacral promontory

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lower border of symphysis pubis to mid-point of sacral promontory

Explanation:

  • The diagonal conjugate is measured from the inferior border of the symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory, and it represents the only clinically measurable pelvic inlet diameter.
  • This measurement is used to estimate the true conjugate (obstetric conjugate), which is essential for assessing pelvic adequacy.
  • The distance from the upper border of the symphysis pubis to the midpoint of the sacral promontory refers to the anatomical conjugate (also called true conjugate or conjugata vera). (Option A)
  • Upper/ Lower border of ilio-pubic eminence to mid-point of sacral promontory are not a standard named pelvic diameter in classical obstetrics (Option C, D)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the ER with a sudden headache described as the “Worst of their life”. A non-contrast head CT is normal. Despite this, the suspicion of subarachnoid hemorrhage remains high. What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient?

choices.text: Repeat the head CT scan in 24 hours
Lumbar puncture to assess for xanthochromia
Perform a Time-of-Flight Magnetic resonance angiography (TOF-MRA)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lumbar puncture to assess for xanthochromia

Explanation:

  • In a patient with sudden severe headache and normal non-contrast CT, but high clinical suspicion of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), the next best step is lumbar puncture (LP).
  • LP can detect xanthochromia and elevated RBC count, which may not be visible on CT if performed >6 hours after symptom onset.

Evaluation of Suspected Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH)

Clinical Presentation:

  • Sudden onset of a “thunderclap headache” (worst headache of life)
  • May be associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, loss of consciousness, or neck stiffness

First-Line Investigation:

  • Non-contrast CT brain is the initial test of choice due to high sensitivity within first 6 hours of symptom onset (approaches ~98%).
  • Sensitivity declines over time (>6–12 hours).

If CT is Negative and Suspicion Remains High:

  • Lumbar puncture is indicated to assess:
    • Xanthochromia (bilirubin from hemolyzed RBCs): appears ~12 hours after hemorrhage, persists for 1–2 weeks
    • Persistent elevated RBC count in successive tubes

Further Imaging After Confirmation:

  • Once SAH is confirmed by CT or LP, the source is typically evaluated using:
    • CT angiography (CTA)
    • Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) — gold standard for aneurysm localization

Management:

  • ICU admission, blood pressure control, neurosurgical consultation
  • Prevent vasospasm using nimodipine
  • Monitor for complications like hydrocephalus and rebleeding

Repeat the head CT scan in 24 hours (Option A):

  • Delaying diagnosis risks rebleeding or deterioration.
  • Xanthochromia may be detectable on LP much earlier than hemorrhage becomes visible on repeat CT.

Immediate cerebral angiography (Option C):

  • Reserved for localizing the bleeding source once SAH is confirmed.
  • Not performed as an initial test in the absence of radiological or LP evidence of bleeding.

Time-of-Flight Magnetic Resonance Angiography (TOF-MRA) (Option D):

  • MRA is non-invasive and useful but less sensitive than LP for detecting minor bleeds.
  • Primarily used after diagnosis to visualize vascular anomalies.

questions.text: Triad in asphyxial death includes all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Abnormal fluidity of blood

Explanation:

  • This is not considered part of the classical forensic triad seen in asphyxial deaths.
  • While fluidity of blood may be seen postmortem in some cases, it is not a defining feature or reliable forensic sign of asphyxia.

Classical Triad of Asphyxial Death:

Feature

Explanation

Cyanosis (Option C)

Due to reduced oxygen in haemoglobin

Petechial hemorrhages (Option B)

Due to capillary rupture from backpressure

Visceral congestion (Option A)

Due to impaired venous return

 

Asphyxial triad

Asphyxial quintet
  • Visceral congestion of organs
  • Petechial hemorrhage
  • Cyanosis
  • Asphyxial triad
  • Abnormal fluidity of blood
  • Dilatation of chambers of heart

questions.text: JEET programme is funded by which of the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Global Fund

Explanation:

The JEET programme (Joint Effort for Elimination of Tuberculosis) is a public-private partnership (PPP) initiative in India.

  • It is funded by the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria (Global Fund).
  • Implemented in collaboration with:
    • Central TB Division (CTD) under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.
    • NGOs and technical partners like PATH, World Health Partners, and CARE India.

Aim of JEET:

  • To engage the private sector in the early diagnosis, notification, and treatment of TB, especially Drug-Sensitive and Drug-Resistant TB, contributing toward the goal of eliminating TB in India by 2025.

Central government (Option A): The Central Government (through the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare) is a partner in the implementation of the JEET programme. However, it does not fund JEET directly. The financial support comes from international donors, specifically the Global Fund.

State government (Option B): Like the central government, state health departments support and implement JEET activities in coordination with private sector providers. But funding does not originate from state budgets.

WHO (Option C): The World Health Organization (WHO) may offer technical guidance and strategic input on TB elimination globally. However, WHO does not fund JEET. It’s not a donor organisation in this case.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with a painful red swelling over his thigh. Pus aspirated from the lesion was cultured and the organism grows on blood agar showing beta-hemolysis and also ferments mannitol on a selective medium turning the agar yellow. Which of the following best describes the organism?

choices.text: Gram-negative diplococcus, grows on Thayer-Martin medium
Gram-positive bacillus, catalase negative, urease positive
Gram-positive cocci in clusters, catalase and coagulase positive
Gram-positive cocci in chains, non-hemolytic, bile soluble

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Gram-positive cocci in clusters, catalase and coagulase positive

Explanation:

  • Painful red swelling → consistent with skin/soft tissue infection (like abscess or cellulitis)
  • Pus culture grows an organism on blood agar with beta-hemolysis
  • Ferments mannitol → turns agar yellow (mannitol salt agar)

These point toward Staphylococcus aureus.

  • Catalase positive- Staphylococci (differentiates from Streptococci)
  • Coagulase positive- Confirms Staphylococcus aureus (vs. coagulase-negative Staph)

Staphylococcus aureus

Microbiology:

  • Gram-positive cocci arranged in grape-like clusters
  • Facultative anaerobe; catalase positive (differentiates from Streptococci)
  • Coagulase positive (differentiates from other Staphylococcus species)

Culture Features:

  • Blood agar: shows beta-hemolysis (clear zones around colonies)
  • Mannitol salt agar (MSA): ferments mannitol → yellow coloration of the medium

Virulence Factors:

  • Protein A (binds Fc region of IgG)
  • Hemolysins, Leukocidins, Enterotoxins, TSST-1
  • Exfoliative toxin (scalded skin syndrome)

Common Clinical Presentations:

  • Skin and soft tissue infections: furuncles, carbuncles, abscesses, cellulitis
  • Invasive infections: pneumonia, osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, endocarditis
  • Toxin-mediated syndromes: toxic shock syndrome, food poisoning

Gram-negative diplococcus, grows on Thayer-Martin medium (Option A):

  • Describes Neisseria gonorrhoeae
  • Gram-negative diplococci, not cocci in clusters
  • Does not produce beta-hemolysis or ferment mannitol

Gram-positive bacillus, catalase negative, urease positive (Option B):

  • Describes organisms like Corynebacterium or Erysipelothrix
  • These are bacilli, not cocci; not arranged in clusters
  • Do not show beta-hemolysis and do not ferment mannitol

Gram-positive cocci in chains, non-hemolytic, bile soluble (Option D):

  • Refers to Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • Typically alpha-hemolytic, diplococci in chains
  • Not beta-hemolytic and not catalase or coagulase positive

questions.text: Which is correct about content of the marked triangle in the neck
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Parathyroid gland

Explanation:

  • The triangle marked in the neck represents the Muscular Triangle, a part of the anterior triangle, which includes the parathyroid gland among the listed options.

Clinical Importance of the Muscular Triangle:

  • Access for thyroid surgery (Thyroidectomy):
    • The thyroid and parathyroid glands lie within the muscular triangle.
    • It is the main surgical window for performing thyroid and parathyroid surgeries.
  • Tracheostomy site:
    • The trachea, located deep to the infrahyoid muscles in this triangle, is accessed through the muscular triangle during emergency or elective tracheostomy.
  • Ansa cervicalis exposure:
    • This triangle provides access to the ansa cervicalis, a nerve loop supplying the infrahyoid muscles, often encountered during neck dissection.
  • Goiter palpation and surgery:
    • Enlarged thyroid gland (goiter) often expands in this triangle, making it a common site of visible anterior neck swelling.
    • knowledge of ots anatomy helps avoid injury to nearby structures (e.g., recurrent laryngeal nerve) during surgery.
  • Infection spread and surgical Drainage:
    • Deep neck infections: thyroid abscesses, or lymphadenitis can localize or track through this space, sometimes requiring surgical drainage.

 

Lingual gland (Option B): No such structure; possibly confused with the sublingual gland, which is located in the floor of the mouth, not in the neck triangle.

Internal carotid artery (Option C): Found deeper and more posterior, mainly within the carotid triangle, not the muscular triangle.

External carotid artery (Option D): Also located within the carotid triangle, giving off branches to the face and neck.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about intraperitoneal rupture of bladder

choices.text: Rupture of superior wall of bladder

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Blood at the meatus

Explanation:

  • Blood at the urethral meatus is more commonly associated with urethral injury or extraperitoneal bladder rupture, not intraperitoneal rupture.

Intraperitoneal rupture of the bladder

Mechanism

Sudden rise in pressure

(Example: kicked on full bladder)

Site of rupture

Dome superior wall of bladder (Option A ruled out)

Site of leakage

Peritoneal cavity

Symptoms

Abdominal pain, guarding and rigidity

Signs

Chemical peritonitis (Option B ruled out)

Catheter output

Initially free flow and then low or absent urine flow

CT cystogram

Confirms bladder rupture (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Death in throttling is due to?

choices.text: Intimal tear of vertebral arteries leading to cerebral ischemia
Blocking of jugular vein flow leading to low cardiac output
Inward compression fracture of hyoid bone

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cardiac arrest

Explanation:

  • In throttling (manual strangulation using hands), death most commonly occurs due to:
    • Asphyxia from airway compression
    • Vagal inhibition due to pressure on the carotid sinus
    • Both of which can lead to reflex cardiac arrest (even before full airway occlusion)
  • Thus, cardiac arrest is the immediate cause of death in most throttling cases.

Intimal tear of vertebral arteries leading to cerebral ischemia (Option A):

  • This is more commonly a mechanism in traumatic whiplash or hanging, not throttling.
  • Vertebral artery tear is not the primary cause of death in manual strangulation.

Blocking of jugular vein flow leading to low cardiac output (Option B):

  • Jugular vein compression causes cerebral congestion, not low cardiac output.
  • Venous blockage alone is not sufficient to cause death.

Inward compression fracture of hyoid bone (Option D):

  • Though fracture of hyoid bone is a forensic sign of throttling, it is not the cause of death.
  • It supports diagnosis of manual strangulation but does not directly result in death.

Strangulation

Hanging
  • Congested face and cyanosis
  • Bloody froth at the nose
  • Frank bleeding
  • Ecchymosed ligature mark
  • Ligature mark encircles neck except where knot was tied (subaurally or submental)
  • Le facies sympathetique
  • Saliva dribbling and seminal emission
  • Splitting of carotid artery (amussat sign)

questions.text: A per oral examination of a 30-year-old lady is shown. Which is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lichen planus

Explanation:

  • The image shows a white, reticular, lace-like pattern on the buccal mucosa.
  • This appearance is classic for oral lichen planus, especially the reticular variant.

Oral Lichen Planus (OLP)

Definition:

  • Chronic autoimmune inflammatory condition affecting oral mucosa, skin, and occasionally genital mucosa.

Etiopathogenesis:

  • T-cell mediated autoimmune reaction against basal epithelial cells.
  • May be associated with systemic lichen planus, dental restorations, or hepatitis C.

Clinical Features:

  • Most common in middle-aged women.
  • Common sites: buccal mucosa, tongue, gingiva.
  • Often bilateral and symmetrical.
  • Reticular type is most common:
    • Characteristic Wickham striae: white lacy, reticular pattern
  • Other forms: erosive, plaque-like, bullous, atrophic
  • May be asymptomatic or cause burning sensation with spicy foods

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical examination and confirmed with biopsy showing:
    • Saw-tooth rete ridges
    • Civatte bodies
    • Lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermoepidermal junction

Management:

  • Topical corticosteroids are first-line therapy
  • Antifungals may be added to prevent secondary candidiasis
  • Severe or erosive cases: systemic corticosteroids or immunosuppressants
  • Regular monitoring due to low risk of malignant transformation

Leucoplakia (Option B):

  • Leucoplakia appears as well-demarcated white plaques, typically with a homogeneous or speckled surface.
  • Does not exhibit reticular or lace-like patterns.

Erythroplakia (Option C):

  • Presents as a velvety red patch, often with high malignant potential.
  • The lesion shown here is white and reticular, not red.

Oral submucous fibrosis (Option D):

  • Characterized by pale, stiff oral mucosa with progressive trismus due to fibrosis.
  • Usually linked to areca nut chewing, and presents as a diffuse blanching, not lace-like lesions.

questions.text: Select the correct management strategy based on the audiogram shown below of a 30-year-old woman with hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Stapedectomy

Explanation:

The audiogram shows the following findings:

  • Right Ear:
    • Air conduction (AC) thresholds are poorer than bone conduction (BC) thresholds.
    • Air-Bone Gap (ABG) is seen → classic conductive hearing loss.
    • BC is within normal limits (<25 dB HL), but AC is worse (40–70 dB HL).
  • Left Ear:
    • Similar ABG is present → bilateral conductive hearing loss.
  • Type of hearing loss: Bilateral conductive hearing loss with preserved bone conduction thresholds and normal tympanogram assumed.
  • Most likely diagnosis: Otosclerosis - most common in young to middle-aged women, typically presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss with normal tympanic membrane.
  • Stapedectomy is indicated in otosclerosis to bypass the fixed stapes footplate and restore hearing.

Myringotomy with grommet insertion (Option A) is used for serous otitis media or eustachian tube dysfunction, not otosclerosis. The tympanic membrane is usually normal in otosclerosis.

Mastoidectomy (Option C): This is used for chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) with mastoid disease. Not relevant here.

Cochlear implant (Option D): Cochlear implants are used in severe-to-profound sensorineural hearing loss, not in isolated conductive loss with normal cochlear function.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency department 6 hours after accidentally ingesting an unknown quantity of paracetamol syrup. The pediatrician initiates treatment with N-acetylcysteine (NAC). Which of the following best explains NAC's mechanism of action in this scenario?

choices.text: It neutralizes NAPQI by directly binding to the toxic metabolite
It enhances liver metabolism of acetaminophen via cytochrome P450 induction
It replenishes glutathione by providing sulfhydryl (-SH) groups
It inhibits formation of NAPQI by blocking acetaminophen oxidation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It replenishes glutathione by providing sulfhydryl (–SH) groups

Explanation:

N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is the antidote of choice for acetaminophen (paracetamol) overdose, particularly when administered within 8 hours of ingestion.

  • Paracetamol is normally metabolized in the liver via glucuronidation and sulfation.
  • A small amount is oxidized by cytochrome P450 to a toxic metabolite, NAPQI (N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine).
  • In normal doses, glutathione neutralizes NAPQI.
  • In overdose, glutathione stores get depleted, allowing NAPQI to accumulate, leading to hepatic necrosis.
  • NAC works by replenishing glutathione, as it donates sulfhydryl (–SH) groups, which conjugate with NAPQI, detoxifying it.

It neutralizes NAPQI by directly binding to the toxic metabolite (Option A): NAC does not directly bind NAPQI. It aids indirectly by restoring glutathione, which then neutralizes NAPQI.

It enhances liver metabolism of acetaminophen via cytochrome P450 induction (Option B): This would be dangerous, as it increases NAPQI formation. NAC does not induce CYP450 enzymes.

It inhibits formation of NAPQI by blocking acetaminophen oxidation (Option D): NAC has no inhibitory action on the oxidation of paracetamol to NAPQI. It supports detoxification, not prevention of NAPQI formation.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with high-grade fever, cough with purulent sputum, and respiratory distress. CXR is shown below. Gram stain of sputum shows Gram-positive cocci in clusters resembling grapes. Which of the following is the best treatment, and what is a known complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Linezolid; pneumothorax

Explanation:

Linezolid; pneumothorax:

  • The causative organism is most likely Staphylococcus aureus:

    • Gram-positive cocci in clusters

    • Produces necrotising pneumonia, especially in children

  • Necrotising pneumonia can lead to:

    • Cavitation

    • Pneumatoceles

    • Pneumothorax

  • Methicillin-resistant Staph aureus (MRSA) should be suspected in severe cases.

    • Linezolid is effective against MRSA, including strains causing necrotising pneumonia.

    • Vancomycin is an alternative, but Linezolid has better lung penetration.

  • Complication: Pneumothorax is a known sequela due to rupture of pneumatoceles or necrotic lung tissue.

Ceftriaxone; bronchiectasis (Option A):

  • Ceftriaxone is not reliable for MRSA.

  • Bronchiectasis is a chronic complication and less commonly a direct acute complication in this setting.

Amoxicillin-clavulanate; empyema (Option C):

  • This combination is more suited to community-acquired pneumonia with typical pathogens.

  • Not adequate for MRSA or necrotising pneumonia.

  • Empyema is possible, but pneumothorax is more characteristic of necrotising staph pneumonia.

Azithromycin; pulmonary fibrosis (Option D):

  • Azithromycin covers atypical organisms (e.g., Mycoplasma, Chlamydia), not Staph aureus.

  • Pulmonary fibrosis is not a typical post-pneumonia complication in children.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male diagnosed with MDR-TB is initiated on the WHO-recommended 6-month all-oral BPaLM regimen. Which of the following statements about the mechanism of action of the drugs in this regimen is incorrect?

choices.text: Bedaquiline inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthase, disrupting energy production
Pretomanid releases reactive nitrogen species under anaerobic conditions, damaging mycobacterial cell wall
Linezolid inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit
Moxifloxacin inhibits DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, blocking DNA replication

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Linezolid inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit

Explanation:

  • Linezolid is a protein synthesis inhibitor, but it binds to the 50S ribosomal subunit, not the 30S. It blocks the initiation of translation by preventing formation of the initiation complex in bacterial protein synthesis. Hence, the statement in Option C is incorrect.

Bedaquiline (Option A): Bedaquiline targets the proton pump of mycobacterial ATP synthase, which is essential for energy production, making it bactericidal, especially effective against dormant bacilli.

Pretomanid (Option B): Under anaerobic conditions, Pretomanid generates reactive nitrogen species (e.g., nitric oxide) that damage the mycolic acid cell wall and interfere with respiration. It is especially useful in non-replicating bacilli.

Moxifloxacin (Option D): Moxifloxacin is a fluoroquinolone that inhibits DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, crucial for DNA supercoiling and replication in bacteria. It is bactericidal and active against M. tuberculosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with skin and oral lesions. DIF appearance is shown. All are true except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Antibodies against hemidesmosomes

Explanations:

  • The clinical presentation (skin and oral lesions) along with a specific DIF pattern typically points toward Pemphigus vulgaris, a classic vesicobullous disorder.
  • Antibodies against hemidesmosomes are found in bullous pemphigoid, not pemphigus. In bullous pemphigoid, the autoantibodies are directed against BP180 (type XVII collagen) and BP230, which are components of the hemidesmosome anchoring complex, leading to subepidermal blistering.

Key Features of Pemphigus Vulgaris:

  • Autoantibodies: IgG autoantibodies directed against desmoglein 3 (DSG3) and in many cases desmoglein 1 (DSG1). (Option A and B ruled out)
  • DIF Findings: Intercellular (fish-net or chicken-wire) pattern of IgG and C3 deposits within the epidermis.
  • Mucosal Involvement: Oral mucosa is commonly involved due to DSG3 targeting.
  • IgG Dominance: IgG is the predominant immunoglobulin type involved in pemphigus. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: True about Ayushman Bharat program?

choices.text: Coverage of 5 lacs per family member
To be eligible, at least one family member should be paying income tax
Excludes if the family owns a refrigerator

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Excludes if the family owns a refrigerator

Explanation:

  • Under the Ayushman Bharat – Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (AB-PMJAY), eligibility is based on the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC), which excludes families with assets such as refrigerators, motorized vehicles, or land beyond a certain limit.
  • Rupees 5 lakh per family, not per member. (Option A)
  • The scheme is for both genders. (Option B)
  • Income tax-paying families are excluded, not eligible. (Option C)

questions.text: A 55-year-old hypertension patient is having tearing chest pain in the interscapular area with shortness of breath. CTA is done and is shown below. Which of the following is correct about management of this patient?

choices.text: Oxygen –Morphine – esmolol – sodium nitroprusside- surgical repair if warranted
Oxygen – Morphine – sodium nitroprusside – esmolol- surgical repair if warranted
Oxygen – Morphine – esmolol – enoxaparin- Urgent surgical repair
Oxygen – morphine – sodium nitroprusside- Alteplase – urgent surgical repair

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Oxygen –Morphine – esmolol – sodium nitroprusside- surgical repair if warranted

Explanation:

  • Sudden, tearing chest pain radiating to the interscapular region, history of hypertension, imaging (CTA) likely shows descending aortic involvement → Type B dissection
  • Initial Management of Aortic Dissection includes reducing the shear stress on the aortic wall by controlling heart rate (target <60 bpm) and reducing systolic BP (target 100–120 mmHg).

Step

Description

Oxygen

Support hypoxia and reduce cardiac workload

Morphine

Pain control → reduces sympathetic surge

Esmolol (first-line)

Rapid β-blocker to control HR and reduce dP/dt (rate of pressure rise)

Sodium nitroprusside

Added only after HR control, to further reduce BP

Surgical repair

Needed for Type A, and for complicated Type B (organ ischemia, rupture)

 

If Nitroprusside given first (Option B), it can cause reflex tachycardia, worsening the dissection.

Enoxaparin (Option C) is contraindicated — anticoagulation is not indicated in dissection.

Alteplase (Option D) is for thrombotic strokes or PE, not dissection — giving it may cause catastrophic rupture.

questions.text: Name the muscle marked X below which sciatic nerve is traversing
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Piriformis

Explanation:

  • The muscle marked X, through which the sciatic nerve passes, is the Piriformis.

Features

Piriformis

(Option B)

Gluteus Medius

(Option A ruled out)

Superior Gemellus

(Option C ruled out)

Adductor Magnus

(Option D ruled out)

Origin

Anterior surface of the sacrum (S2–S4 segments) and sacrotuberous ligament

External surface of the ilium, between the anterior and posterior gluteal lines

Ischial spine

Adductor part: Inferior ramus of the pubis and ramus of ischium.

Hamstring part: Ischial tuberosity.

Insertion

Superior border of the greater trochanter of the femur

Lateral surface of the greater trochanter of the femur

Medial surface of the greater trochanter of the femur

Adductor part: Linea aspera of the femur.

Hamstring part: Adductor tubercle of the femur.

Action

Laterally rotates the thigh at the hip joint.

Assists in abduction of the thigh when the hip is flexed.

Abducts the thigh.

Medially rotates the thigh.

Stabilizes the pelvis during walking.

Laterally rotates the thigh

Adducts the thigh.

Adductor part: Flexes the thigh.

Hamstring part: Extends the thigh.

Nerve supply

Nerve to piriformis (sacral plexus, S1 and S2)

Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)

Nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1)

Adductor part: Obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4)

Hamstring part: Tibial part of sciatic nerve (L4)

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl collapses during school assembly. Her ECG shows prolonged PR interval, occasional broad qRS complexes and QT interval 500 msec. What is the most likely underlying cause?

choices.text: Wolf Parkinson white syndrome type A
Wolf Parkinson white syndrome type B

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Romano-Ward syndrome

Explanation:

  • ECG shows prolonged QT interval (500 ms), a key feature of congenital long QT syndrome.
  • Romano-Ward syndrome is the most common inherited form and is purely cardiac.
  • Sudden collapse in a young person with QT prolongation is highly suggestive of this diagnosis.

Romano-Ward Syndrome and Long QT Syndromes

  • Romano-Ward syndrome is an autosomal dominant congenital long QT syndrome caused by mutations in ion channels:
    • Most commonly in KCNQ1, KCNH2, or SCN5A genes, affecting potassium and sodium channels.
    • Leads to prolonged cardiac repolarization and delayed ventricular repolarization.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Symptoms usually begin in late childhood or adolescence.
    • Syncope, often triggered by exercise, emotional stress, or sudden auditory stimuli.
    • May progress to torsades de pointes, ventricular fibrillation, and sudden cardiac death.
    • No extracardiac features (distinguishes it from Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome, which includes congenital sensorineural deafness).
  • ECG Findings:
    • Prolonged QTc (> 460 ms in females, > 440 ms in males).
    • May show broad-based T waves or episodes of polymorphic VT (torsades).
  • Investigations:
    • ECG is the primary diagnostic tool.
    • Holter monitoring or exercise testing may reveal arrhythmias.
    • Genetic testing can confirm mutations in ion channel genes.
    • Family screening is recommended due to autosomal dominant inheritance.
  • Management:
    • Beta-blockers (e.g. propranolol or nadolol) are first-line to reduce adrenergic stimulation.
    • Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) in high-risk or symptomatic patients.
    • Avoid QT-prolonging drugs and correct electrolyte imbalances (hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia).
  • Prognosis:
    • With appropriate treatment and lifestyle modification, many patients live a near-normal lifespan.
    • Early diagnosis and intervention are critical to prevent sudden cardiac death.

Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome type A (Option A):

  • Due to accessory pathway (bundle of Kent), causing pre-excitation.
  • ECG: short PR interval, delta wave, wide QRS.
  • QT interval is not prolonged.
  • Presents with tachyarrhythmias, not torsades or syncope due to QT prolongation.

Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome type B (Option B):

  • Similar to WPW type A but involves a right-sided accessory pathway.
  • ECG findings are similar: short PR, delta wave, wide QRS.
  • QT interval is normal, no association with torsades.

Lown-Ganong-Levine syndrome (Option D):

  • Caused by accessory pathway (James fibers) bypassing AV node.
  • ECG shows a short PR interval with normal QRS, no delta wave.
  • Associated with paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia, not QT prolongation or syncope from torsades.

questions.text: Which of the following finding is seen in toxocariasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chronic endophthalmitis

Explanation:
Toxocariasis (ocular larva migrans) is caused by migration of Toxocara canis or Toxocara cati larvae into the eye.

  • It presents in children and young adults, often with unilateral decreased vision.
  • The hallmark ocular manifestation is chronic endophthalmitis.
  • It may mimic retinoblastoma due to the presence of a white reflex (leukocoria).
  • Granulomatous reaction occurs around the larva, leading to chronic intraocular inflammation.

Headlight in fog appearance (Option A):

  • Seen in Toxoplasmosis chorioretinitis.
  • Represents a focal white retinal lesion (headlight) surrounded by dense vitreous inflammation (fog).

Cottage cheese and tomato ketchup (Option B):

  • Classic description of CMV Retinitis.
  • White fluffy lesions (cottage cheese) with hemorrhages (ketchup) in the retina.

Candle wax dripping (Option D):

  • Seen in sarcoidosis (especially ocular sarcoidosis).
  • Describes granulomatous periphlebitis of retinal veins (exudates along vessels).

questions.text: Second Leopold grip is used for finding position of?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Position of anterior shoulder

Explanation:

  • The second Leopold maneuver determines the position of the fetal back and extremities, which indirectly helps assess the position of the anterior shoulder.

  • It involves placing both hands on the sides of the uterus to locate the firm, smooth fetal back on one side and small, irregular limbs on the other.

Leopold's Maneuver

Position

Technique

Purpose

Fundal Grip (First Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Palpate the fundal area with both hands

Determine which fetal pole is in the fundus

  • Broad, soft, irregular mass: Breech

  • Smooth, hard, globular mass: Head

  • Transverse lie: Neither pole palpable

Lateral or Umbilical Grip (Second Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Place hands flat on either side of the umbilicus, palpate one side at a time

Identify the position of the fetal back, limbs, and anterior shoulder

  • Back: Smooth, curved, resistant

  • Limb side: Comparatively empty with small, knob-like parts

  • Anterior shoulder: Prominent in the lower part of the uterus above the head

Pawlik’s Grip (Third Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Place thumb and four fingers over the lower pole of the uterus, ulnar border on the upper symphysis pubis

Grasp the presenting part if not engaged and test its mobility

  • Transverse lie: Pawlik’s grip is empty

Pelvic Grip (Fourth Leopold)

Facing the patient’s feet

Place four fingers of both hands on either side of the midline in the lower pole of the uterus, pressing downward and backward

Identify the part in the lower pole, its attitude, and engagement

  • Head Characteristics

    • Precise presenting area

    • Attitude (position of sinciput and occiput)

    • Engagement (noted by the presence/absence of sinciput and occiput, convergence/divergence of finger tips)

 

  • Breech presentation is evaluated primarily in the third and fourth grips. (Option A)

  • Cephalic presentation is determined by the first grip (fundal). (Option B)

  • Lower uterine segment assessment is done in the third grip. (Option D)

questions.text: A 35-year-old female came with complaints of rash on the convexities of face. The lesions worsen on hot drinks, sunlight and emotion. Comment on the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Acne rosacea

Explanation:

  • Acne rosacea is a chronic inflammatory skin condition commonly affecting the central convexities of the face. Key features include facial flushing, telangiectasias, papules/pustules, and worsening with triggers like hot drinks, sun exposure, and emotions. It typically affects adults aged 30–50, especially women, and lacks comedones (unlike acne vulgaris).

Drug-induced lupus (Option A): Usually presents with systemic symptoms like arthralgia and fever, along with a photosensitive rash, but lacks papules/pustules and flushing. No drug history here.
