Systemic lupus erythematosus (Option B): While SLE may cause a malar (butterfly) rash, it is non-pustular, not triggered by hot drinks or emotions, and is usually associated with systemic symptoms (e.g., joint pain, fatigue).

Nodulocystic acne (Option D): Presents with deep nodules and cysts, primarily over the jawline, back, and chest, and involves comedones, which are not seen in rosacea. Age of onset is also typically earlier.

questions.text: Riboflavin deficiency will affect functioning of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Glutathione reductase

Explanation:

  • Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) is a water-soluble vitamin essential for the synthesis of two major cofactors:
    • FMN (Flavin mononucleotide)
    • FAD (Flavin adenine dinucleotide)
  • These flavin cofactors are crucial for redox reactions in many oxidoreductase enzymes.
  • Glutathione reductase is an FAD-dependent enzyme, meaning it requires FAD (derived from riboflavin) to function properly.
  • It maintains cellular redox balance by regenerating reduced glutathione (GSH) from its oxidized form (GSSG) using NADPH as an electron donor.
  • Riboflavin deficiency impairs FAD availability → Glutathione reductase activity declines → leads to oxidative stress, especially in red blood cells.
  • Clinically, this manifests as cheilitis, glossitis, seborrheic dermatitis, and normocytic anemia due to oxidative damage.​

Glutathione oxidase (Option B): This enzyme is not a recognized entity in human metabolism; likely confused with glutathione peroxidase, which uses selenium, not riboflavin, as a cofactor.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (Option C): This enzyme is NADP⁺-dependent and part of the pentose phosphate pathway. It does not require riboflavin or FAD for its activity.

Glucose-6-phosphatase (Option D): This enzyme is involved in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. It is not a flavoprotein and functions independently of riboflavin.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for uncomplicated Plasmodium falciparum malaria in an adult patient in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Artemether-lumefantrine + single dose of primaquine

Explanation:

According to the National Centre for Vector Borne Diseases Control (NCVBDC) and WHO guidelines, the recommended treatment for uncomplicated P. falciparum malaria in adults in India is:

Artemisinin-based Combination Therapy (ACT):

  • Artemether + Lumefantrine (ACT-AL)
  • PLUS a single dose of primaquine (0.75 mg/kg) on day 2
    • to eliminate gametocytes and prevent transmission

Parameter

Uncomplicated Falciparum Malaria

Complicated (Severe) Falciparum Malaria

Clinical status

Conscious, stable vitals, no organ dysfunction

Altered sensorium, seizures, shock, severe anemia, organ failure

Initial Drug of Choice

Artemether + Lumefantrine (oral ACT)

IV Artesunate at 0, 12, 24 hrs, then daily

Primaquine Use

Single dose (0.75mg/kg) on Day 1 (if G6PD normal)

Single dose at discharge (not during acute phase)

Alternative ACT

Artesunate + Sulfadoxine - Pyrimethamine (AS+SP)

Switch to oral ACT after IV completion (3 day full ACT course)

Route

Oral only

Parenteral initially, switch to oral when stable

Duration of Treatment

3 days (ACT)

Minimum 24 hrs IV + 3 days oral ACT

 

Artesunate injection + doxycycline (Option A): Used for complicated or severe falciparum malaria, not for uncomplicated cases. IV artesunate is reserved for patients with organ dysfunction or altered consciousness.

Chloroquine + primaquine (Option B): Standard for P. vivax malaria. P. falciparum in India is chloroquine-resistant.

Quinine + clindamycin (Option D): Used as an alternative in special situations (e.g., pregnancy or drug resistance), but not first-line for uncomplicated falciparum malaria.

questions.text:
60-year-old man with T2DM is brought to hospital with complaints of left sided face, arm weakness > leg weakness, developing 2 hours after waking up at 6 am. Arrival time to hospital is 6pm and BP is 200/100 mm Hg. NCCT head is shown below. Which of the following is best suited for management of this patient?

 

​​​
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Endovascular treatment

Explanation:

This is a case of acute ischemic stroke with wake-up onset — the patient woke up at 6 am already symptomatic, and presented at 6 pm, which places him well beyond the 4.5-hour window for thrombolysis. The weakness pattern (face and arm > leg) suggests a middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory infarct.

Although IV thrombolysis is no longer an option, mechanical thrombectomy (endovascular treatment) is now indicated up to 24 hours from last known well, in select patients with large vessel occlusion and salvageable penumbra. This patient is within the extended window, and the clinical picture supports a large vessel occlusion, making endovascular therapy the best choice.

Thrombolysis (Option A): Too late (>4.5 hours).

Lower BP with labetalol (Option C): Only lower BP if >185/110 before thrombolysis or >220/120 otherwise. Here, BP = 200/100, which is not a reason alone to intervene urgently.

Perform CT angiography (Option D): Useful, but treatment is the priority in a clearly indicated case.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man sustained a deep traumatic injury. On examination, in the left calf there is skin discoloration, foul-smelling discharge, and crepitus under the skin. Gram stain of the wound discharge shows large gram-positive bacilli without spores, and the culture grows in Robertson’s cooked meat broth. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

choices.text: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy + Clindamycin and below knee amputation
Hyperbaric oxygen therapy + Penicillin G + Surgical debridement

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hyperbaric oxygen therapy + Penicillin G + Surgical debridement

 

Explanation:
The clinical features and lab findings suggest Clostridial myonecrosis (gas gangrene)—a rapidly progressive soft tissue infection typically caused by Clostridium perfringens.

  • Surgical debridement is life-saving to remove necrotic, toxin-producing tissue.
  • Penicillin G is the drug of choice due to its activity against Clostridium species.
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy helps oxygenate ischemic tissues and inhibits anaerobic bacterial growth.

Hyperbaric oxygen therapy + Clindamycin and below knee amputation (Option A): Amputation is reserved for extensive, non-salvageable tissue involvement. It's not the first-line if surgical debridement is possible.

Hyperbaric oxygen therapy + Clindamycin (Option B): Clindamycin has anti-toxin effects but Penicillin G is the mainstay. Hyperbaric oxygen is adjunctive, not standalone.

Hyperbaric oxygen therapy + penicillin G (Option D): Without surgical debridement, infected and necrotic tissue remains, allowing progression of the disease. Surgical debridement is life-saving.

questions.text: The following catheter is used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bladder irrigation post prostatectomy

Explanation:

  • The catheter shown is a three-way Foley catheter, specifically used for continuous bladder irrigation.
  • Most commonly indicated post-TURP (Transurethral Resection of Prostate) to prevent clot retention and maintain catheter patency.

Foley Catheter Types and Uses

  • A three-way Foley catheter is an indwelling urinary catheter with three separate ports:
    • One port for urine drainage.
    • One port for inflating the Foley balloon, which anchors the catheter inside the bladder.
    • One port for bladder irrigation, used to flush the bladder and prevent or manage blood clot formation.
  • 3-way Foley catheters are indwelling catheters with three ports — one for urine drainage, one for Foley balloon inflation and a third port for bladder irrigation to prevent or manage blood clots.
  • Primary indications for three-way Foley catheters:
    • Continuous bladder irrigation, especially post-prostatectomy or post-TURP.
    • Management of gross hematuria and clot evacuation.
  • French scale:
    • Catheter size is measured in French (Fr) units.
    • 1 Fr = 0.33 mm in diameter.
    • Common adult male sizes: 14–16 Fr (14 Fr most used).
    • Common adult female sizes: 10–12 Fr (12 Fr most used).
  • Length of Foley’s catheters:
    • Male length: 15–18 inches (due to longer urethra)
    • Female length: 7–10 inches
    • Pediatric length: 11–13 inches

Reduction of intussusception (Option A):

  • Typically performed by hydrostatic or pneumatic enema under imaging.
  • Uses rectal catheters, not Foley catheters.

Supra pubic urine drainage (Option B):

  • Involves direct insertion into the bladder through the abdominal wall.
  • Uses Pezzer or Malecot catheters, not Foley.

Relieve urine retention in BPH (Option D):

  • Managed with a two-way Foley catheter, not three-way.
  • Irrigation is unnecessary unless hematuria is present.

questions.text: Which of the following colour of escaping liquor would alert you to possible requirement of LSCS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Green

Explanation:
Green-coloured amniotic fluid indicates the presence of meconium-stained liquor, which is a common sign of fetal distress. When meconium is passed into the amniotic fluid before or during labour, it raises concern for fetal hypoxia.

  • Green liquor signifies recent passage of meconium, especially in a live, distressed fetus.

  • If accompanied by non-reassuring fetal heart rate patterns (on CTG), it may necessitate emergency LSCS to prevent complications like meconium aspiration syndrome or worsening hypoxia.

Dark brown (Option A): Dark brown liquor may suggest old meconium or even intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD). In IUFD, LSCS is not usually indicated unless needed for maternal indications; vaginal delivery is preferred.

Golden (Option C): It indicates haemolysis (e.g., from Rh isoimmunisation) with bilirubin in the liquor. While concerning, it doesn’t acutely necessitate LSCS unless fetal distress is present.

Saffron (Option D): Saffron-coloured liquor is seen in postmaturity, due to concentration of pigments. It indicates aging placenta, but not an immediate LSCS indication unless signs of fetal compromise arise.

questions.text: Absence of any measurable amount of amniotic fluid sonographically is called as?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Anhydramnios

Explanation:

  • Anhydramnios refers to the complete absence of amniotic fluid, confirmed by absent measurable vertical pocket and amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 0 cm on ultrasound.
  • It is seen in conditions such as renal agenesis, prolonged premature rupture of membranes, or postmaturity with placental insufficiency.
  • Oligohydramnios (Option A): Refers to reduced fluid (AFI <5 cm), but not absent.
  • Polyhydramnios (Option C): Refers to excess fluid (AFI >24 cm).
  • Spontaneous rupture of membranes (PROM) (Option D): Can cause anhydramnios, but is not the term used to describe the ultrasound finding itself.

questions.text: Which is correct about mechanism of labour in cephalic presentation?

choices.text: Crowning – Delivery of head by extension- Restitution- external rotation
Crowning – Delivery of head by flexion- Restitution- external rotation
Crowning – Restitution-Delivery of head by extension- external rotation
Crowning – Restitution -Delivery of head by flexion - external rotation

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Crowning – Delivery of head by extension- Restitution- external rotation

Explanation:

  • In vertex presentation, the correct sequence is:
    Crowning → Delivery of head by extension → Restitution → External rotation
  • Crowning occurs when the biparietal diameter is encircled by the vulvar ring.
  • Extension follows as the occiput passes under the pubic symphysis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old farmer from a hilly rural area presents with high-grade fever for 7 days, headache, and myalgia. On examination, you note a black necrotic lesion with an erythematous base on his lower abdomen. There is mild hepatosplenomegaly. Which of the following statements is true regarding his likely diagnosis?

choices.text: The disease is transmitted by sandflies and treated with amphotericin
The eschar is pathognomonic and treatment of choice is doxycycline
It is caused by Borrelia recurrentis and transmitted by lice
The organism is a spirochete detected on peripheral smear

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The eschar is pathognomonic and treatment of choice is doxycycline

Explanation:

  • Farmer from hilly rural area with fever, headache, myalgia
  • Presence of black necrotic eschar with erythematous base = pathognomonic for scrub typhus
  • Causative agent: Orientia tsutsugamushi
  • Transmitted by chigger (larval mites)
  • Doxycycline is the treatment of choice

Scrub Typhus

Etiology and Transmission:

  • Caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, an obligate intracellular Gram-negative bacterium
  • Transmitted by larval mites (chiggers) found in rural/hilly scrub vegetation
  • Endemic in South and Southeast Asia, particularly affecting farmers and people living in rural areas

Clinical Features:

  • Acute febrile illness: sudden high-grade fever, chills, headache, myalgia
  • Eschar: painless black necrotic lesion with erythematous base, often in hidden areas (groin, axilla, abdomen)
  • Hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, maculopapular rash
  • Complications: meningoencephalitis, interstitial pneumonia, AKI, MODS

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical suspicion + presence of eschar in endemic settings
  • Weil-Felix test (OXK positive)- low sensitivity and specificity
  • IgM ELISA and PCR- more specific diagnostic tools

Treatment:

  • Doxycycline is the drug of choice (even in children >8 years)
  • Azithromycin is alternative, especially in pregnancy

The disease is transmitted by sandflies and treated with amphotericin (Option A):

  • Refers to Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala-azar), not scrub typhus
  • No eschar formation
  • Typically presents with prolonged fever, massive splenomegaly, pancytopenia
  • Transmitted by sandflies, treated with amphotericin B or miltefosine

It is caused by Borrelia recurrentis and transmitted by lice (Option C):

  • Refers to relapsing fever, caused by spirochete Borrelia
  • Transmitted by body lice
  • No eschar; patient experiences recurrent fever episodes, hepatosplenomegaly
  • Treated with doxycycline or erythromycin

The organism is a spirochete detected on peripheral smear (Option D):

  • Incorrect because Orientia tsutsugamushi is not a spirochete
  • It's a rickettsial organism (obligate intracellular), not visualized on peripheral smear
  • Spirochetes like Borrelia, Treponema, or Leptospira are seen in different disease entities

questions.text: Which hormone levels will spike at night time and fall at day time and has no effect on blood sugar levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Melatonin

Explanation:

  • Secreted by the pineal gland in response to darkness
  • Follows circadian rhythm: rises at night, falls during the day
  • Plays a key role in regulating sleep-wake cycles
  • Does not affect blood glucose levels

Melatonin and Circadian Hormones

Melatonin:

  • Hormone produced by pineal gland from serotonin
  • Secretion is stimulated by darkness and inhibited by light
  • Regulated by the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) of the hypothalamus
  • Controls biological clock, induces sleep onset
  • Used therapeutically in insomnia, jet lag, delayed sleep phase syndrome
  • No direct metabolic effects on blood glucose

ACTH (Option A):

  • Released in a pulsatile manner with early morning peak
  • Stimulates cortisol production → influences glucose metabolism

Cortisol (Option B):

  • Peaks in the early morning, decreases by evening
  • Increases blood glucose via gluconeogenesis and insulin antagonism

GH (Option D):

  • GH peaks at night, especially in deep sleep (Stage 3)
  • Has anti-insulin effects, raises blood glucose levels

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency department with breathlessness. She has a history of a viral infection and chest pain from 7 days ago. CXR is shown below. All of the following statements are true except;

choices.text: Echocardiography showing RA and RV collapse requires immediate intervention

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Loud S1

Explanation:

  • The case describes a patient with breathlessness, a recent viral infection, chest pain, and increased cardiothoracic (CT) ratio on chest X-ray. This is strongly suggestive of pericardial effusion, possibly progressing to cardiac tamponade.
  • In cardiac tamponade or large pericardial effusion, heart sounds are typically muffled/distant, not loud. Loud S1 is more associated with conditions like mitral stenosis.
  • Pulsus paradoxus is observed (Option A): Pulsus paradoxus is a clinical finding where the systolic blood pressure drops by more than 10 mmHg during inspiration. This is a classic sign of cardiac tamponade.
  • Emergency pericardiocentesis may be required (Option C): If tamponade is present, this is a life saving intervention. It is usually Indicated in hemodynamic instability or echocardiographic evidence of tamponade.
  • Echocardiography showing RA and RV collapse requires immediate intervention (Option D): This is a hallmark of cardiac tamponade on echocardiography. It maybe due to the cardiac tamponade causing obstructive shock.
  • RA collapse in systole and RV collapse in diastole = tamponade physiology → urgent pericardiocentesis.

questions.text: Shortest acting CCB?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Clevidipine

Explanation:

Clevidipine is ideal in perioperative hypertensive management, especially in cardiac surgery:

  • Ultra-short acting DHP CCB (half-life ~1 min)
  • Selectively causes arterial vasodilation
  • Minimal effect on heart rate or cardiac contractility
  • Rapidly titratable and safe in ischemic heart disease

Landiolol (Option A): Landiolol is a β1-selective beta-blocker, not a CCB. It is used for rapid rate control but irrelevant to this CCB-focused question.

Felodipine (Option C): Long-acting oral DHP CCB used in chronic hypertension; not used for rapid control and has a longer half-life.

Nicardipine (Option D): Although used IV for hypertensive emergencies, its half-life (~8 hours) is much longer than clevidipine, making it less rapidly titratable

questions.text: A 30-year-old G2P1A0L1 lady is in the late third trimester of pregnancy. She had multiple episodes of syncope last week. Her BP is 110/70 mm Hg on sitting and decreases to 90/70 mm Hg in the supine position and continuous murmur is heard. Lab workup shows Hb 10gm% with mild anisocytosis and poikilocytosis. Serum ferritin levels are low, and serum vitamin B12 levels are normal. Which of the following advice is best for her?

choices.text: Parenteral Jectofer with oral folic acid supplements.
Restricted physical activity till delivery and rest in lateral position
Perform echocardiography to rule out cardiac valvular defects.
Increase salt intake with elastic compression stockings.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Restricted physical activity till delivery and rest in the lateral position

 

Explanation:
This patient is in late pregnancy and presents with postural hypotension (BP drop in supine position), multiple syncope episodes, continuous murmur and Iron deficiency anemia, suggestive of supine hypotension syndrome.

 

This occurs due to: In late pregnancy, gravid uterus compresses the inferior vena cava (IVC) when lying supine, reducing venous return and cardiac output → hypotension, syncope, and sometimes a venous hum or continuous murmur.

  • The mainstay of management is avoiding the supine position and encouraging left lateral positioning, which relieves IVC compression.
  • Mild anaemia is also present (Hb = 10 g/dL), but the syncope is not due to anaemia; it is positional.

Hence the best advice for the patient is - Restricted physical activity till delivery and rest in the lateral position as → Left lateral decubitus relieves IVC compression and resolves symptoms.

Parenteral Jectofer with oral folic acid supplements (Option A): Jectofer is a parenteral iron preparation (iron sorbitol citric acid complex), used to treat moderate to severe iron deficiency when Oral iron is ineffective. This would correct anemia but doesn’t address acute cause of syncope (supine hypotension).

 

Perform echocardiography to rule out cardiac valvular defects (Option C): Not first-line. The continuous murmur here is likely a venous hum due to IVC compression; no evidence of structural heart disease.
 

Increase salt intake with elastic compression stockings (Option D): Used in orthostatic hypotension, not for supine hypotension syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following epithelium is shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Transitional epithelium

Explanation:

Transitional Epithelium is depicted in the above image.

  • It is found in the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and prostatic urethra.
  • Because of this distribution, it is also called urothelium. This is a multilayered epithelium with four to six thick cells that can contract and expand as needed (stretchable epithelium).

Features:

  • Cells towards the lumen are very large and called umbrella-shaped cells (typical for transitional epithelium).
  • Each cell is attached to the basement membrane by a cytoplasmic extension. The basement membrane is straight.
  • It is exclusively located in the urinary system and is named as urothelium.
  • It is called transitional because it is transitional between stratified squamous and stratified columnar epithelia. It differs from stratified squamous epithelium in that the cells at the surface are not squamous.
  • The deepest cells are columnar or cuboidal. The middle layers are made up of polyhedral or pear-shaped cells.
  • The superficial cell layer, which lines the lumen, is the only fully differentiated layer of the epithelium. It provides an impenetrable barrier between the lumen and the bloodstream.

Stratified columnar (Option A) has multiple layers with columnar cells only on the surface. It is rare and found in limited areas like the male urethra but lacks the ability to stretch like transitional epithelium.

Stratified squamous (Option B) has multiple layers with flat cells on top. It consists of multiple layers of flat cells designed for protection, not stretching.

Pseudostratified columnar (Option D) appears multilayered due to nuclei at different levels but is actually a single layer of columnar cells all attached to the basement membrane. It appears layered due to nuclei at different levels but is actually a single layer, mostly lining the respiratory tract and not designed for stretching.

questions.text: Stocker line has deposition of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: (Option A) Iron

Explanation:

  • Stocker’s line is a brownish line seen at the head of a pterygium (where it encroaches onto the cornea).
  • It is caused by iron deposition in the superficial corneal layers, especially the Bowman’s membrane.
  • It is a type of iron line, similar to:
    • Fleischer ring (in keratoconus)
    • Hudson-Stähli line (in elderly)

Copper (Option B): Copper deposition in the eye is classically seen as the Kayser-Fleischer ring, located at the Descemet’s membrane, not in Stocker’s line.

Cobalt (Option C) does not get deposited in the cornea in any known physiological or pathological state.

Molybdenum (Option D) does not participate in corneal pigment deposition or line formation.

questions.text: Cervical cancer that extends into the ureter, leading to hydroureter and hydronephrotic changes in the kidney, belongs to stage _____ as per FIGO staging.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) III

Explanation:

Stage I: Tumor confined to cervix (ignore extension to uterine corpus)

  • IA: Microscopic disease, depth <5 mm
    • IA1: Stromal invasion <3 mm
    • IA2: Stromal invasion ≥3 mm and <5 mm
  • IB: Invasion ≥5 mm, limited to cervix
    • IB1: <2 cm in greatest dimension
    • IB2: ≥2 cm and <4 cm
    • IB3: ≥4 cm

Stage II: Beyond uterus, not into lower 1/3 of vagina or pelvic wall

  • IIA: Upper 2/3 of vagina, no parametrial involvement
    • IIA1: <4 cm
    • IIA2: ≥4 cm
  • IIB: Parametrial involvement, not up to pelvic wall

Stage III: Involves lower 1/3 vagina, pelvic wall, hydronephrosis, or nodes

  • IIIA: Lower 1/3 of vagina only
  • IIIB: Pelvic wall and/or hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney
  • IIIC: Pelvic and/or para-aortic nodes (any size/extent)
    • IIIC1: Pelvic nodes
    • IIIC2: Para-aortic nodes

Stage IV: Beyond true pelvis or invasion of bladder/rectal mucosa

  • IVA: Adjacent pelvic organs (bladder, rectum)
  • IVB: Distant metastases

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy bit the teacher in the hand. He loves to torture animals and bullies other students at school. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Conduct disorder

Explanation:

  • The child demonstrates aggressive, antisocial behavior, including hurting animals, bullying peers, and biting an authority figure.
  • These behaviors are consistent with Conduct Disorder — a serious behavioral/emotional disorder in children.

Conduct Disorder

Definition:

  • A psychiatric disorder in children and adolescents marked by persistent patterns of violating societal rules, norms, or the rights of others.

Key Features:

  • Aggression to people and animals (e.g., bullying, cruelty, physical fights)
  • Destruction of property
  • Deceitfulness or theft
  • Serious violations of rules (e.g., truancy, running away)

Age of Onset:

  • Usually diagnosed in children under 18 years of age
  • If symptoms persist beyond age 18, may develop into Antisocial Personality Disorder

Management:

  • Psychotherapy: Behavioral therapy, family therapy
  • Parent management training
  • Medications (for comorbidities like ADHD or mood disorders)

ADHD (Option A):

  • While ADHD can involve impulsivity and hyperactivity, it does not involve cruelty or violation of rights.
  • ADHD behaviors are not intentionally aggressive or harmful.

Separation anxiety (Option C):

  • Characterized by excessive fear or distress about being away from home or caregivers.
  • This child exhibits externalizing aggression, not anxiety or fear.

Oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) (Option D):

  • Involves argumentative, defiant behavior, often directed at authority figures.
  • However, ODD does not involve physical aggression toward animals or serious rule violations — which are seen in conduct disorder.

questions.text: 3-year-old unvaccinated child presents with fever, cough, and stridor. A throat swab Gram stain shows small pleomorphic Gram-negative coccobacilli. The organism grows on chocolate agar but not on blood agar unless near Staphylococcus aureus colonies. What explains this growth pattern?

choices.text: The organism requires bile salts for growth
It utilizes catalase and urease for satellitism
It requires X (hemin) and V (NAD) factors provided by S. aureus
It is a facultative anaerobe and grows in anaerobic conditions only

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It requires X (hemin) and V (NAD) factors provided by S. aureus

Explanation:

The clinical picture and microbiological features point to Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib).

  • H. influenzae is a small pleomorphic Gram-negative coccobacillus.
  • It requires two essential growth factors:
    • Factor X (hemin) – a heat-stable component found in RBCs
    • Factor V (NAD) – a heat-labile coenzyme
  • Chocolate agar provides both factors as the RBCs are lysed during heating.
  • Blood agar does not release NAD (Factor V) unless hemolysis occurs. However, colonies of Staphylococcus aureus secrete NAD, enabling Haemophilus to grow only near S. aureus colonies, a phenomenon called satellitism.
     

The organism requires bile salts for growth (Option A): Bile salts are used in media to isolate enteric organisms like Shigella or Salmonella, not Haemophilus influenzae.

It utilizes catalase and urease for satellitism (Option B): Satellitism depends on NAD (Factor V) secreted by S. aureus, not on catalase or urease activity.

It is a facultative anaerobe and grows in anaerobic conditions only (Option D): Although H. influenzae is a facultative anaerobe, its growth is not limited to anaerobic conditions. The issue here is factor availability, not oxygen tension.

questions.text: Hypotension, Hypothermia and Hippus is seen with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Aconite

Explanation: Aconite (from Aconitum napellus) is a highly toxic plant alkaloid.

Key features of aconite poisoning include:

  • Hypotension: due to myocardial depression and vasodilation.

  • Hypothermia: due to peripheral vasodilation and CNS depression.

  • Hippus (spasmodic, rhythmic pupillary dilation and constriction): due to central nervous system effects.

  • Other features: paresthesias (tingling and numbness), arrhythmias, convulsions, and death due to cardiac arrest.

Cerebera thevetia (Option B):

  • Also known as yellow oleander.

  • Contains cardiac glycosides (thevetin), similar to digoxin.

  • Causes arrhythmias, hyperkalemia, and gastrointestinal symptoms, but not hippus or hypothermia.

  • Pupils may be normal or show other changes, but hippus is not a feature.

Capsicum annum (Option C):

  • Common chilli pepper.

  • Contains capsaicin, an irritant.

  • Causes burning sensations, reflex tachycardia, and lacrimation.

  • No hypotension, hypothermia, or hippus are characteristic.

Calotropis gigantea (Option D):

  • Also called Madar or Ak.

  • Contains cardiac glycosides (calotropin).

  • Causes GI symptoms, cardiac toxicity, and local irritation.

  • Hippus and hypothermia are not features.

questions.text: An alcoholic slept on the sofa while drinking on the weekend. He wakes up with a numb and weak arm and comes to the ER. You diagnose him as a case of Saturday night palsy. Which of the following is not correct about this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Wallerian degeneration

Explanation:

Saturday night palsy is a transient radial nerve palsy caused by prolonged nerve compression, typically in intoxicated individuals sleeping with the arm in an awkward position, and is a classic example of Neurapraxia.

 

Neurapraxia (Seddon Type I):

  • The mildest form of nerve injury
  • No axonal damage
  • Just segmental demyelination
  • Full recovery in days to weeks

 

Wallerian degeneration is seen in axonotmesis and neurotmesis (Seddon types II and III). It is not present in neurapraxia, because the axon is intact.

 

Neurapraxia (Option A): Saturday night palsy is a classic example of neurapraxia.
 

Type 1 Seddon Classification (Option B): This is correct.

  • Seddon Type I = Neurapraxia
  • Type II = Axonotmesis
  • Type III = Neurotmesis

 

EMG is normal (Option C): In neurapraxia, EMG is usually normal initially. Abnormalities (if any) may appear after 10–14 days, and even then are mild.

 

 

Feature

Neuropraxia

Axonotmesis 

Neurotmesis

Definition

Temporary block (no structural damage)

Axon disrupted, sheath intact

Complete nerve transection

Cause

Compression/Mild injury (e.g., shoulder dislocation)

Crush/Stretch (e.g., shoulder dislocation)

Laceration/Stab wound

Wallerian degeneration

Absent

Present

Present

Connective tissue

Intact

Intact

Disrupted

Recovery

Full (Within days-weeks)

Possible,slow (months)

Poor without surgery

EMG findings

Normal/minimal changes

Fibrillations, reduced conduction

No conduction

Seddon classification

Type 1

Type II

Type III-V (With Sunderland subtypes)

questions.text: All are quantitative, continuous, polyotomus variable except?
A 25-year-old lady has a history of vague and chronic physical complaints. She says she has been sick but her doctors cannot identify her problem and cannot help her. Diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Somatization disorder

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with multiple vague, chronic physical complaints without an identifiable medical cause.
  • Despite repeated evaluations and reassurance, she continues to believe she is ill.
  • This clinical picture is most consistent with somatization disorder (now classified under Somatic Symptom Disorder in DSM-5).

Somatization Disorder (Somatic Symptom Disorder)

Definition:

  • A psychiatric condition where patients present with multiple, clinically significant physical symptoms over a long duration.
  • These symptoms are not fully explained by any underlying medical illness.

Features:

  • Usually begins before age 30 and persists for several years.
  • Multiple organ systems involved: pain, GI, sexual, and neurological symptoms
  • High health care utilization with frequent doctor visits
  • Patient genuinely believes they are ill (unlike malingering or factitious disorder)
  • Symptoms cause significant distress or impairment in daily life

Diagnosis (DSM-5 criteria):

  • ≥1 somatic symptom that is distressing or results in disruption
  • Excessive thoughts, feelings, or behaviors related to the symptoms
  • Persistent symptoms typically >6 months

Management:

  • Establish a strong therapeutic alliance
  • Regularly scheduled visits with a single primary physician
  • CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy) is the most effective
  • Avoid unnecessary investigations or interventions

Hypochondriasis (Option B):

  • Involves preoccupation with having a serious illness despite no or minimal symptoms.
  • The patient here has multiple physical complaints, not just worry about a disease.

Body dysmorphism (Option C):

  • Characterized by preoccupation with an imagined or slight defect in physical appearance.
  • This patient is focused on somatic symptoms, not appearance.

Tourette syndrome (Option D):

  • A neurodevelopmental disorder marked by motor and vocal tics.
  • No mention of tics or involuntary movements in this case.

questions.text: 60-year-old patient is admitted with low urine output and swelling all over the body. BUN: 140 mg/dl, serum creatinine 8.0 mg/dl and urine protein by dipstick is 4+. USG abdomen shows normal size kidney. Which of the following is useful for distinguishing acute kidney injury from chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Urine albumin

Explanation:

This clinical case suggests: Advanced renal dysfunction

  • The BUN:Cr ratio is elevated, urine protein is heavy (4+), and kidneys are normal-sized, which is inconclusive (as CKD like diabetic nephropathy can also have normal-sized kidneys).

  • In such cases, urine albumin levels (graded as A1, A2, A3) help assess chronicity and disease progression, especially in CKD.

  • Persistent albuminuria is a hallmark of CKD.

  • It is graded to assess CKD staging (A1: <30 mg/g, A2: 30–300, A3: >300).

  • In AKI, albuminuria may be absent or transient depending on cause.

Creatinine (Option A) - Elevated in both AKI and CKD; not distinguishing

Size of kidney (Option B) – Chronic disease typically causes small shrunken kidneys, but exceptions exist (e.g., diabetic nephropathy, amyloidosis) → kidneys may still be normal-sized

Urinary output (Option C) – Decreased in both AKI and late-stage CKD, not diagnostic on its own

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about M. Gravis?

choices.text: Increased Jitter on Single fiber Electromyography
Decreased jitter on Single fiber electromyography
Post tetanic potentiation on Repetitive nerve stimulation
Muscle weakness improvement with day progression

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Increased Jitter on Single fiber Electromyography

Explanation:

  • Myasthenia Gravis (MG) is an autoimmune condition caused by antibodies targeting acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, resulting in fluctuating muscle weakness, with Single Fiber Electromyography (SFEMG) being the most sensitive diagnostic test.

Electrophysiological Findings:

  • Single Fiber Electromyography (SFEMG) is the most sensitive test for MG.
    • It shows increased jitter, which refers to variability in the time between muscle fiber activation — a sign of impaired neuromuscular transmission. (Option A) (Option B ruled out).

Post-tetanic potentiation on Repetitive nerve stimulation (Option C) is seen in Lambert-Eaton.

Muscle weakness improvement with day progression (Option D): MG worsens with activity and as the day progresses (fatigability), not improvement.

questions.text: Non-union of metanephros and ureteric bud components will form which of the following defects:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B)

Explanation:

Condition

Description

Image

Horseshoe kidney

(Option A)

A congenital condition where the lower poles of the two kidneys fuse, forming a U-shaped structure, usually without affecting the ureteric bud–metanephros union.

​

Polycystic Kidney Disease

(Option B)

Results from a failure of proper union between the ureteric bud and metanephric tubules, leading to cyst formation due to disconnected nephrons.

​

Duplex Kidney

(Option C)

Caused by duplication of the ureteric bud, resulting in a kidney with two separate collecting systems or ureters.

​

Unilateral Renal agenesis

(Option D)

Occurs when the ureteric bud fails to form or reach the metanephric blastema, leading to complete absence of one kidney.

​

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about the procedure shown below?

choices.text: Base is crushed with artery forceps
Purse string suture applied on distal end

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Purse string suture applied on distal end  

Explanation:

The organ shown is appendix and the procedure shown is an appendicectomy. This is the surgical removal of the appendix, typically performed for acute appendicitis.

A purse-string suture is a circular stitch placed around the base of the appendix (not the distal end). After the appendix is removed, this suture is tightened to invert the appendiceal stump into the cecum.

  • This reduces the risk of stump leakage or infection.
  • The distal end is discarded — no suture is placed there.

Babcock forceps at distal end (Option A):

  • Babcock forceps are non-traumatic graspers used to hold soft tissues like the appendix.
  • They are placed at the distal end of the appendix (the tip) to gently manipulate and elevate it without crushing or tearing it.
  • Crushing the appendix could lead to spillage of infected contents, so atraumatic handling is crucial.

Base is crushed with artery forceps (Option B):

  • The base of the appendix (where it joins the cecum) is crushed and ligated.
  • Crushing it with artery forceps makes it easier to tie a tight ligature and seal the lumen before cutting.
  • This step is important to prevent leakage of bowel contents during removal.


Always located on Anti-mesenteric border (Option D):

  • The appendix arises from the posteromedial wall of the cecum, typically at the anti-mesenteric border. This location helps surgeons identify the appendix during surgery.
  • Though its position can vary (retrocecal, pelvic, subcecal, etc.), its origin on the anti-mesenteric border is constant.

questions.text: Mechanic-hands are seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Antisynthetase syndrome

Explanation:

  • Antisynthetase syndrome is a subset of idiopathic inflammatory myopathies, most commonly associated with anti-Jo-1 antibodies.
  • It features:
    • Interstitial lung disease
    • Myositis
    • Arthritis
    • Fever
    • Mechanic’s hands (rough, cracked, dirty-appearing skin on the hands)

Scleroderma (Option A): Characterized by tightening and thickening of skin, especially fingers (sclerodactyly), but not mechanic’s hands.

Polymyositis (Option C): Causes proximal muscle weakness, but lacks the cutaneous signs like mechanic’s hands unless part of antisynthetase syndrome.

SLE (Option D): May show malar rash, discoid lesions, photosensitivity, but mechanic’s hands are not a recognized feature.

questions.text: The most common type of cervical cancer is squamous cell carcinoma originating at squamocolumnar junction. Which is correct about the leading mode of spread of this cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Direct local spread

Explanation:

  • Cervical cancer primarily spreads via:
    • Direct extension to parametrium, vagina, bladder, rectum
    • Later: Lymphatic spread to pelvic nodes (Option A)
    • Hematogenous and transcoelomic spread occur in advanced disease (Option B)

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents with abdominal distention. She has fluid thrill and tense abdominal wall with engorged superficial veins. Abdominal paracentesis was done and report is given


	
		
			
			Serum album
			
			
			3.0 g/dl
			
		
		
			
			Ascitic fluid protein
			
			
			2.5 g/dl
			
		
		
			
			Ascitic fluid albumin
			
			
			2.1 g/dl
			
		
		
			
			Cells
			
			
			850 cells

			75% lymphocytes

			20% macrophages

			5% mesothelial
			
		
	


Which of the following is possible aetiology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Malignant ascites

 

Explanation:

The above scenario is diagnosed as Malignant Ascites, characterized by a low SAAG, high protein content, and lymphocyte-predominant fluid.

  • SAAG calculation: 3.0 – 2.1 = 0.9 g/dl (<1.1) → Indicates Malignant ascitesascites
  • Ascitic fluid protein: 2.5 g/dl (high) → Suggests exudative ascites (infection/malignancy)
  • Cell count: 850 cells with 75% lymphocytes → Indicates chronic inflammation or malignancy.

Cirrhosis (Option A) and Budd Chiari syndrome (Option B) usually have high SAAG (>1.1) with low protein.

CHF (Option C): Has high SAAG and low protein ascites

questions.text: According to the latest National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) guidelines, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the management and control of tuberculosis in India?

choices.text: The program emphasizes passive case finding only, relying on symptomatic individuals to seek care, with sputum microscopy as the primary diagnostic tool for all suspected cases.

The use of GeneXpert MTB/RIF assay as an initial diagnostic test is recommended for all presumptive TB cases, including children and extrapulmonary TB suspects, to ensure rapid detection and rifampicin resistance screening.
Treatment under NTEP involves a universal 12-month regimen for all TB patients regardless of drug susceptibility or co-morbid conditions, with monthly follow-ups limited to sputum-negative cases.

Contact tracing is discouraged in the latest guidelines to focus resources on treating active TB cases rather than preventive measures among high-risk groups like household contacts and people living with HIV.

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) The use of GeneXpert MTB/RIF assay as an initial diagnostic test is recommended for all presumptive TB cases, including children and extrapulmonary TB suspects, to ensure rapid detection and rifampicin resistance screening.

Explanation:

  • The NTEP has undergone a significant paradigm shift from the old RNTCP (Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme). The core of this change is to "Find, Test, Treat, and Prevent."
  • A key component of this strategy is the use of rapid, accurate diagnostics. The GeneXpert MTB/RIF assay (also known as CBNAAT) is a rapid molecular test that can detect the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex DNA and, crucially, simultaneously test for resistance to rifampicin.
  • The latest NTEP guidelines strongly recommend GeneXpert as the initial diagnostic test for all individuals suspected of having TB. This includes smear-negative presumptive pulmonary TB cases, children, and suspected cases of extrapulmonary TB (e.g., from lymph node biopsies or pleural fluid). This rapid diagnosis allows for the initiation of the correct treatment regimen, including for drug-resistant TB, much faster than traditional culture methods.

The program emphasizes passive case finding only, relying on symptomatic individuals to seek care, with sputum microscopy as the primary diagnostic tool for all suspected cases. (Option A)

  • The NTEP has moved beyond passive case finding (waiting for symptomatic individuals to show up at a clinic). The program now actively promotes Active Case Finding (ACF) and Intensified Case Finding (ICF).

Treatment under NTEP involves a universal 12-month regimen for all TB patients regardless of drug susceptibility or co-morbid conditions, with monthly follow-ups limited to sputum-negative cases. (Option C)

  • The NTEP uses specific, evidence-based, and differentiated treatment regimens.The standard regimen for drug-sensitive pulmonary TB is a 6-month regimen (2 months of intensive phase followed by 4 months of a continuation phase).

Contact tracing is discouraged in the latest guidelines to focus resources on treating active TB cases rather than preventive measures among high-risk groups like household contacts and people living with HIV. (Option D)

  • Contact tracing is a cornerstone of the NTEP's prevention strategy.

questions.text: Which is correct about the image shown?

choices.text: A= Velamentous placenta, B= Battledore placenta, C= Succenturiate lobe
A= Battledore placenta, B= Velamentous placenta, C= Succenturiate lobe
A= Succenturiate lobe, B= Battledore placenta, C= Velamentous placenta
A= Velamentous placenta, B= Battledore placenta, C= Placental marginata

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Velamentous placenta, B= Battledore placenta, C= Succenturiate lobe

In the image -
A: Umbilical cord inserted into the membranes away from the placental mass. This corresponds to a velamentous placenta.

B: Umbilical cord inserted at the placental margin. This corresponds to a battledore placenta.

C: An accessory lobe of the placenta is present. This corresponds to a succenturiate lobe.

Option A - Velamentous placenta is a condition where the umbilical cord is not attached to the center of the placenta, but to the amniotic sac. In velamentous cord insertion, the blood vessels of the umbilical cord are exposed as they pass between the amnion and chorion, leading to the placenta. This can lead to the rupture of these blood vessels during labor, a condition called vasa previa, which can be life-threatening for the fetus.

Option B - Battledore placenta, also known as marginal cord insertion, is a condition where the umbilical cord is inserted at the edge of the placenta, rather than at the center. This condition is not usually associated with adverse outcomes, but it can be a risk factor for preterm labor and low birth weight.

Option C - Succenturiate lobe is a condition where one or more accessory lobes of the placenta are present. These lobes are connected to the main placenta by blood vessels, but they are not fully fused with the main placental body. This can be a risk factor for postpartum hemorrhage, as the accessory lobe may be retained in the uterus after delivery.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease and chronic hypertension is undergoing CABG. During the operation, his blood pressure rises to 190/110 mmHg. The anesthesiologist wants to rapidly bring down his blood pressure while maintaining heart rate and avoiding myocardial depression. Which of the following intravenous antihypertensive agents is most appropriate in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nitroprusside

 

Explanation:

Nitroprusside :

  • Very rapid onset (within seconds) and short half-life (1–2 minutes) → makes it easy to titrate intraoperatively, especially when minute-to-minute control is needed, as in cardiac surgery.
  • It causes direct arterial and venous vasodilation → leading to decreased preload and afterload → helps reduce myocardial oxygen demand, which is beneficial in CAD.
  • No direct effect on heart rate or myocardial contractility → hence no direct myocardial depression.

 

Esmolol (Option A): Esmolol is not an anti-hypertensive agent. It is a rapid β1-blocker which primarily reduces heart rate, not BP. Negative inotropy could worsen cardiac output. Not useful as sole agent to reduce such high BP intraoperatively.
 

Clevidipine (Option C): Clevidipine is an ultra–short-acting dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker used for rapid blood pressure control. While it's effective in many situations, it is not ideal in this patient undergoing CABG with known coronary artery disease (CAD), as it causes:

  • Reflex Tachycardia:
    • Clevidipine causes peripheral arterial vasodilation → leading to reflex sympathetic activation → results in tachycardia.
    • In patients with CAD, this reflex tachycardia increases myocardial oxygen demand, which can precipitate ischemia or worsen angina, especially intraoperatively.

Labetalol (Option D): Blocks both α and β receptors, reducing both BP and heart rate. The β-blockade component depresses myocardial function, which is not preferred in intraoperative cardiac settings.

questions.text: A 60-year-old hypertensive patient has muscle weakness, low potassium, and a plasma aldosterone-renin ratio (ARR) >30. Which test is best to differentiate primary from secondary hyperaldosteronism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. CT abdomen + ARR

 

Explanation:

The patient has hypertension, hypokalemia and elevated plasma aldosterone-renin ratio (ARR > 30). This is highly suggestive of primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn’s syndrome), where excess aldosterone is produced independently of renin.


CT Abdomen + ARR is the Best Next Step

  • Plasma ARR >30 is a screening test for primary hyperaldosteronism.
  • CT abdomen is the first-line imaging to:
    • Detect adrenal adenoma (most common cause)
    • Identify bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
    • Rule out adrenal carcinoma
  • Combining ARR (biochemical evidence) with CT imaging (anatomical evidence) helps to:
    • Confirm primary hyperaldosteronism.
    • Differentiate it from secondary causes like renal artery stenosis (which would show high renin).

Stepwise diagnostic workup:

 

Step

Test

Purpose

1

Plasma Aldosterone-Renin Ratio (ARR)

Screening — ratio >20–30 with high aldosterone is suggestive

2

CT scan of adrenal glands

Identify macro-adenoma or adrenal hyperplasia

3

Adrenal Venous Sampling (AVS)

Lateralization — differentiate unilateral adenoma vs bilateral hyperplasia (if surgery is considered)


Option B and D are ruled out as they are used for Cushing syndrome diagnosis.

Adrenal venous sampling (Option C): It's the gold standard to lateralize the source (unilateral vs bilateral disease) but done after CT scan if surgery is being considered.

questions.text: Drug of choice for management of the following condition is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Alprostadil
Explanation:

  • Alprostadil = Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1)
  • Used to maintain ductus arteriosus patency in cyanotic congenital heart diseases like:
    • Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)
    • Transposition of great arteries (TGA)
    • Tricuspid or pulmonary atresia
  • It ensures continued mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood by keeping the ductus open until definitive surgery or palliation.

Indomethacin (Option A): It is used to close a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), not to keep it open. Used in premature infants with symptomatic PDA.

Ibuprofen (Option B): Like indomethacin, it is a NSAID that promotes ductal closure, not useful when ductal patency is desired.

Treprostinil (Option D): A prostacyclin analogue used in pulmonary arterial hypertension, not for ductal patency.

questions.text: Spot Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Becker nevus

Explanation:

  • The given image represents a picture of Becker nevus. Becker nevus is a benign pigmented hamartoma that typically appears during adolescence, especially in males. It presents as a unilateral, sharply demarcated, hyperpigmented patch with hypertrichosis, often over the shoulder, chest, or upper back. It is usually asymptomatic and non-progressive.

Nevus of Ota (Option B): Pigmentation occurs over the face, including sclera, typically in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve. It presents as blue-gray pigmentation—not brown, and not located over the chest.

Nevus of Ito (Option C): Appears over the shoulder or upper back, but the pigmentation is bluish-gray (due to dermal melanocytosis) and lacks hair growth. It is usually seen in the supraclavicular or scapular area, not chest.

Malignant melanoma (Option D): Typically presents as an irregular, asymmetric lesion with color variation, border irregularity, and recent changes. It is not stable, and does not show terminal hair growth. Becker nevus is stable and present since adolescence.

questions.text: Which is correct about iron status in pregnant state?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Low TIBC

Explanation:

  • In pregnancy:
    • Serum iron levels decrease due to increased maternal demands and hemodilution. (Option A)
    • TIBC (Total Iron Binding Capacity) increases due to rise in transferrin levels. (Option B)
    • Ferritin decreases, reflecting lower stores. (Option D)
    • % transferrin saturation also decreases. (Option C)

questions.text: The following red graph is for transport maximum of which of the following solutes in the kidney?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sugar

Explanation:

The red graph shown represents the Transport Maximum (Tm) of glucose.

  • It represents the maximum rate at which a solute can be reabsorbed in the kidney tubules.
  • Glucose reabsorption occurs mainly in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) via SGLT transporters.
  • The process is carrier-mediated and saturable, meaning it has a finite capacity.
  • When blood glucose levels exceed the Tm, carriers become saturated, and excess glucose appears in the urine (glycosuria).
  • Other solutes (like urea, creatinine, and inulin) do not exhibit a clear Tm because their reabsorption is not saturable. (Option B, C, D ruled out)

 

Parameter

Value

Normal plasma glucose

~70-100 mg/dL

TM of glucose

~375 mg/min (in adults)

Renal threshold

~180-200 mg/dL (plasma glucose level at which glucose starts appearing in urine)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating hearing loss. Audiogram is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Meniere's disease

Explanation: Meniere's disease:

  • Characterised by the classical triad:
    • Episodic vertigo
    • Tinnitus
    • Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss
  • Audiogram typically shows:
    • Low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss (as shown in the image)
    • Hearing may return between episodes, especially early in the disease.
  • Caused by endolymphatic hydrops (excess endolymph in the inner ear).

Vestibular neuritis (Option A): Causes vertigo without hearing loss or tinnitus.

BPPV (Option B): Causes brief episodes of vertigo triggered by position change. No hearing loss or tinnitus.

Acoustic neuroma (Option D):

  • Causes gradual, progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss.
  • May involve cerebellar signs or facial nerve palsy in large lesions.
  • Audiogram shows high-frequency loss, not low-frequency as in Meniere's.

questions.text: Which is correct about the fracture shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chauffeur fracture

Explanation:

  • Also known as a radial styloid fracture, usually intra-articular.
  • Occurs due to compression of the scaphoid bone against the radial styloid — typically seen in FOOSH injuries (fall on outstretched hand) or during sudden ulnar deviation of the wrist.
  • The term "chauffeur" comes from the early 20th century, when hand-cranking a car could cause such injuries.

Colle’s fracture (Option B): It is an extra-articular distal radius fracture with dorsal angulation, commonly seen in elderly women post-fall.

Bennet fracture (Option C): A fracture-dislocation of the base of the first metacarpal bone (thumb), not the radial styloid.

Smith fracture (Option D): Also a distal radius fracture but with volar (anterior) angulation, opposite to Colle’s fracture.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in infant born to lady with Gestational diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- D) Sacral agenesis

Explanation- This is a rare but severe congenital malformation characterized by the abnormal development or absence of the sacrum and lumbar vertebrae. This specific malformation is strongly and almost exclusively associated with pre-existing, poorly controlled, pregestational diabetes mellitus (Type 1 or Type 2), not with gestational diabetes that develops later in pregnancy. The critical period for the formation of the spine occurs in the very early weeks of embryonic development, before a diagnosis of GDM is typically made.

Hypoglycemia (Option A): This is a very common and expected complication in infants of diabetic mothers. High maternal blood glucose levels cross the placenta, causing the fetal pancreas to produce an excessive amount of insulin. After birth, the infant's glucose supply from the mother is abruptly cut off, but the high insulin levels persist, leading to a rapid and significant drop in the infant's blood sugar.

Macrosomia (Option B): This is a hallmark feature of infants born to mothers with poorly controlled GDM. The excess glucose from the mother is a continuous supply of fuel for the fetus, which is converted into fat and muscle. Fetal hyperinsulinemia acts as a growth hormone, leading to an overly large baby (typically defined as a birth weight >4000g).

Hypocalcemia (Option C): This is a known complication, although the exact mechanism is not fully understood. It is believed to be related to prematurity, hypomagnesemia, and an imbalance in parathyroid hormone regulation in the infant. It usually manifests within the first 24-48 hours of life.

questions.text: 20-minute whole blood clotting test is done to determine
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Venom-induced afibrinogenemia

Explanation:

  • The 20-minute whole blood clotting test (WBCT) is a bedside test primarily used in cases of viper snake bite.
  • It checks whether blood fails to clot within 20 minutes in a clean, dry glass test tube — this indicates afibrinogenemia or defibrination syndrome caused by haemotoxic venom.
  • A positive test (no clot) suggests coagulopathy due to venom-induced consumption of clotting factors, especially fibrinogen.

Anti-venom administration (Option B):

  • The WBCT is not used to decide whether to give anti-venom, but rather to assess whether the venom has caused coagulopathy.
  • Clinical signs and envenomation grade guide anti-venom need.

Anti-venom efficacy (Option C):

  • WBCT can be repeated after anti-venom to assess resolution of coagulopathy, but this is not its primary purpose.
  • It’s mainly a diagnostic tool, not a therapeutic monitor.

Venom-induced neurotoxicity (Option D):

  • Neurotoxic envenomation (e.g., krait, cobra) affects cranial nerves and muscles but does not affect clotting.
  • WBCT does not detect neurotoxicity.

questions.text: Most common electrolyte derangement seen in case of idiopathic hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Low chloride

Explanation:

Idiopathic hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is a condition seen in infants that causes projectile non-bilious vomiting due to gastric outlet obstruction. Because the vomitus is rich in HCl, repeated vomiting leads to significant loss of chloride and hydrogen ions.

Electrolyte disturbances:

  • This results in a hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis
  • Among these, hypochloremia is the most consistent and characteristic abnormality
  • Chloride is used up in the kidney during bicarbonate retention in alkalosis, worsening the deficit

Idiopathic Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis is a common cause of non-bilious projectile vomiting in infants, typically presenting between 2–8 weeks of age. It results from hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction. On examination, a palpable “olive-shaped” mass may be felt in the epigastrium. Infants often have persistent vomiting, which leads to hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis due to the loss of gastric hydrochloric acid.

Ultrasound is the diagnostic modality of choice, showing a thickened pylorus.

Treatment is surgical via Ramstedt pyloromyotomy.

Low sodium (Option B): May occur, but it is milder and nonspecific.

Low potassium (Option C): Occurs secondarily due to renal compensation but is not the most dominant change.

Low calcium (Option D): Not involved in the pathophysiology of IHPS.

questions.text: Which is not a component of Meig syndrome

choices.text: Spontaneous resolution of ascites and pleural effusion on tumour resection

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Left sided Pleural effusion

Explanation:

  • Meigs syndrome is a triad of:
    • Benign ovarian fibroma/ Brenner’s tumor/ thecoma/ granulosa cell tumor (Option C)
    • Ascites (Option A)
    • Right-sided pleural effusion (due to diaphragmatic lymphatic spread) (Option B)
  • Pleural effusion resolves after tumor removal. (Option D)

questions.text: Not a component of Waddell triad?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ipsilateral head injury

 

Explanation:

  • The Waddell triad describes a pattern of injuries seen in paediatric pedestrian vehicle trauma, especially when the child is struck by a car.

  • The classic triad includes:

    • Femoral shaft fracture

    • Thoracic or abdominal injury (e.g., hemothorax or hemoperitoneum)

    • Contralateral head injury (not ipsilateral) – due to the child being thrown and landing on the opposite side of impact.

Femoral shaft fracture (Option A): Occurs from the initial bumper impact to the leg - part of the Waddell triad.

Hemoperitoneum (Option B): Represents abdominal organ injury from secondary impact - also part of the triad.

Hemothorax (Option C): A thoracic injury, such as hemothorax, is also included under truncal injuries of the Waddell triad.

questions.text: Basal electrical rhythm is not present in which of the following organs
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Oesophagus

Explanation:

Basal Electrical Rhythm (BER), also called as slow waves is not present in the esophagus.

  • Refers to rhythmic fluctuations in membrane potential generated by interstitial cells of Cajal, serving as pacemakers for GI motility.
  • Seen in:
    • Stomach
    • Small intestine (duodenum, jejunum, ileum) (Option A ruled out)
    • Large intestine (caecum, colon, sigmoid) (Option C, D ruled out)
    • These regions exhibit slow waves, which coordinate peristalsis and muscle contractions.

questions.text: Child is undergoing VP shunt surgery. Which of the following would be the anaesthetic agent of choice for quick recovery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sevoflurane

Explanation:

  • Sevoflurane is the preferred inhalational anaesthetic in paediatric patients, including for VP shunt surgery, because of its rapid onset and offset, non-pungent odour, and excellent safety profile.
  • Though desflurane has a faster recovery due to lower blood-gas solubility, sevoflurane is the agent of choice in children because desflurane is pungent and causes airway irritation, making it unsuitable for inhalational induction in paediatrics.
  • In VP shunt surgeries, rapid recovery is desirable to allow early neurological evaluation, and sevoflurane balances both quick recovery and smooth induction, making it ideal in this setting.

Desflurane (Option B): Although it allows for very rapid recovery, it is pungent and can cause airway irritation, coughing, and laryngospasm, especially in children. Hence, not preferred for paediatric anaesthesia.

Isoflurane (Option C): It has a higher blood-gas solubility coefficient (~1.4), leading to slower induction and emergence, making it less ideal for quick recovery.

Halothane (Option D) is incorrect due to its high risk of hepatotoxicity, especially with repeated use, and its pro-arrhythmic potential. It also has slow recovery and has largely been replaced by safer agents in modern paediatric anaesthesia.

questions.text: A man presents to the ER with recurrent episodes of pulsations in neck and palpitations. His ECG reveals narrow complex tachycardia. What is the best treatment to prevent recurrence of these episodes?

choices.text: IV adenosine 6 mg bolus followed by saline push

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Catheter ablation

Explanation:

The presence of palpitations, neck pulsations (cannon A waves), and narrow complex tachycardia points toward AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT), the most common type of PSVT. Since the patient has recurrent episodes, the focus is now on preventing recurrence, not acute termination.

Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice for long-term management of PSVT:

  • Definitive and curative (success rate >95%)
  • Targets the slow pathway in AVNRT or accessory pathways in AVRT
  • Recommended for patients with recurrent symptoms, drug intolerance, or preference to avoid lifelong medications

NOTE: The question is asking for prevention and not acute management. Option A, C and D are used for emergency management. Abolishment of re-entry circuit is done with catheter ablation.

questions.text: Ladder tear occurs at which site in case of Motor vehicle injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Aorta

Explanation:

  • A ladder tear refers to transverse tears in the intima and media of the aorta, resembling the rungs of a ladder.
  • It is seen in blunt trauma, especially high-speed motor vehicle accidents with sudden deceleration.
  • The most common site of injury is the aortic isthmus (just distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery).
  • The injury may progress to aortic transection or rupture, often fatal if not promptly managed.

Femoral shaft (Option A): While femoral fractures are common in trauma, the term “ladder tear” is not associated with femoral shaft injuries.

Mesentery (Option B): Mesenteric injuries do occur in blunt abdominal trauma, but the term “ladder tear” specifically refers to aortic injuries, not mesenteric.

Spinal cord (Option D): Spinal injuries involve cord contusion, laceration, or fracture-dislocations, but ladder tearing is not a recognised term in spinal trauma.

questions.text: Which of the following methods of prenatal diagnosis has the highest fetal loss?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Cordocentesis

Explanation: This procedure involves inserting a needle through the maternal abdomen into the umbilical cord to obtain a sample of fetal blood. It is usually performed later in pregnancy (after 18-20 weeks) when other tests are inconclusive. The fetal loss rate is reported to be around 1-2%.The risk is higher because the procedure directly involves the fetal circulation.

Culdocentesis (Option A): This is a procedure to obtain fluid from the cul-de-sac (a space behind the uterus). It is used to diagnose conditions like a ruptured ectopic pregnancy or pelvic infection, but it is not a method for prenatal genetic diagnosis.

Amniocentesis (Option B): This is a diagnostic procedure performed later in pregnancy (typically after 15 weeks) to obtain a sample of amniotic fluid. The risk of fetal loss is very low, generally quoted at 0.1-0.3%.

Chorionic Villus Sampling (CVS) (Option D): This test is performed earlier in pregnancy (typically between 10 and 13 weeks) by taking a small sample of placental tissue. The risk of fetal loss is generally quoted at around less than 1%.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with fatigue, early satiety, and repeated infections over the past 2 months. On examination, he has massive splenomegaly without lymphadenopathy. CBC reveals pancytopenia. A bone marrow aspirate is attempted but yields a dry tap. Flow cytometry shows clonal B-cells expressing CD11c, CD25, and CD103. Which of the following is correct about this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) BRAF V600E mutation

Explanation:

  • The clinical picture (pancytopenia, massive splenomegaly, dry tap) with characteristic flow cytometry markers (CD11c, CD25, CD103) is classic for Hairy Cell Leukemia (HCL)
  • Nearly all cases of HCL harbor the BRAF V600E mutation, a key diagnostic and therapeutic marker

Hairy Cell Leukemia (HCL)

Definition:

  • A rare chronic B-cell lymphoproliferative disorder
  • Named for the hair-like cytoplasmic projections on malignant B-cells

Epidemiology:

  • Most commonly affects middle-aged to older men
  • Accounts for ~2% of all leukemias

Clinical Features:

  • Fatigue, early satiety, infections due to pancytopenia
  • Massive splenomegaly (but no significant lymphadenopathy)
  • May present with bone marrow failure

Investigations:

  • CBC: Pancytopenia (↓ Hb, WBCs, platelets)
  • Peripheral smear: Lymphocytes with hairy cytoplasmic projections
  • Bone marrow aspirate: Often yields a dry tap due to fibrosis
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Shows fried egg appearance of cells
  • Flow cytometry: Clonal B-cells express CD11c, CD25, CD103
  • Molecular genetics: >90% cases have BRAF V600E mutation

Treatment:

  • Purine analogs (cladribine or pentostatin)
  • BRAF inhibitors (e.g., vemurafenib) for relapsed or refractory cases

BCR-ABL1 fusion t(9;22) (Option A):

  • Seen in Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML), not HCL
  • Associated with leukocytosis, not pancytopenia

PML-RARA fusion t(15;17) (Option B):

  • Characteristic of Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL)
  • Presents with DIC and blasts, not dry tap and hairy cells

RUNX1-RUNX1T1 fusion t(8;21) (Option C):

  • Found in AML with maturation (M2 subtype)
  • Does not present with the characteristic flow cytometry profile of HCL

questions.text: A 30 year old man presents with palpable purpura over lower limbs and joint pain involving knees and ankle joints along with fatigue and weakness. On examination livedo reticularis is noted. Urine examination shows hematuria with RBC casts. Past medical history is noted for Hepatitis C. The diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Essential mixed cryoglobulinemia

Explanation: The presence of palpable purpura, arthralgia, fatigue, and renal involvement (RBC casts) in a patient with known Hepatitis C strongly points toward Essential mixed cryoglobulinemia. It is a small-to-medium vessel vasculitis caused by deposition of immune complexes containing cryoglobulins, often triggered by chronic viral infections, especially HCV.

Classic Clinical Triad (Meltzer's Triad):

  • Purpura - especially palpable purpura over the lower limbs

  • Arthralgia/Arthritis - typically non-erosive

  • Weakness - fatigue, constitutional symptoms

Other Common Features:

  • Peripheral neuropathy - mononeuritis multiplex

  • Glomerulonephritis - often membranoproliferative pattem (MPGN)

  • Raynaud phenomenon

  • Hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy

  • Cutaneous ulcers, livedo reticularis

Henoch–Schönlein purpura (Option B) → Typically occurs in children; associated with IgA deposition, abdominal pain, and less commonly linked to Hep C

IgA nephropathy (Option C) → Renal-limited disease without systemic vasculitis signs like purpura, livedo

Serum sickness (Option D) → Occurs after drug exposure; typically self-limiting, no chronic Hep C association

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a waddling gait and difficulty in walking. On examination, when he is asked to stand on his right leg, his pelvis drops to the left. Which of the following muscles is most likely paralyzed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Right gluteus medius

Explanation:

  • A pelvic drop to the left while standing on the right leg indicates a positive Trendelenburg sign.
  • The right gluteus medius is the primary muscle that keeps the pelvis level during stance on the right leg.
  • Its paralysis leads to inability to abduct the hip and failure to stabilize the pelvis, resulting in contralateral (left) pelvic drop.

Gluteus Medius and Pelvic Stabilization

  • The gluteus medius is a fan-shaped muscle located on the lateral aspect of the hip, deep to the gluteus maximus.
  • It originates from the outer surface of the ilium and inserts into the greater trochanter of the femur.
  • Innervated by the superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1).
  • Function:
    • Primary abductor of the thigh.
    • Crucial stabilizer of the pelvis during walking or when standing on one leg.
  • During the stance phase of gait:
    • The gluteus medius of the stance leg contracts to prevent the opposite side of the pelvis from sagging.
  • If the gluteus medius is paralyzed:
    • The pelvis tilts downward on the opposite (swing) side.
    • This is known as a positive Trendelenburg sign.
    • Patients often compensate by leaning toward the affected side, resulting in a waddling gait.

Right gluteus maximus (Option A):

  • This is the main hip extensor, not involved in abduction or pelvic stabilization.
  • Active during rising from sitting, climbing stairs, and running.
  • Paralysis causes posterior trunk lurch, not pelvic drop.
  • Does not contribute to the Trendelenburg sign.

Left gluteus medius (Option B):

  • This muscle stabilizes the pelvis during left leg stance.
  • In this case, the patient is standing on the right leg, so the right gluteus medius should be active.
  • Paralysis of the left gluteus medius would cause right-sided pelvic drop, not left.
  • Therefore, it is not responsible for the current finding.

Left quadratus lumborum (Option D):

  • Located in the posterior abdominal wall, not the gluteal region.
  • Helps in lateral flexion of the spine and hip hiking, not in hip abduction.
  • Though it may compensate for pelvic instability, its paralysis would not cause a Trendelenburg sign.
  • It plays no role in active pelvic stabilization during single-leg stance.

questions.text:
Comment on the ECG shown below:

​​​
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sick sinus syndrome

Explanation:

The ECG shows intermittent disappearance of P waves, with long pauses between beats without any preceding PR prolongation. This pattern is classic for sinoatrial (SA) node dysfunction, also called Sick Sinus Syndrome (SSS).

  • SSS occurs due to degeneration or fibrosis of the sinus node, especially in the elderly.
  • It can present with sinus pauses, sinus arrest, bradycardia–tachycardia syndrome, or alternating bradycardia and supraventricular tachyarrhythmias.

Complete heart block (Option B): There is complete AV dissociation, where P waves and QRS complexes occur independently. This is not seen here—P waves are missing entirely at times, not dissociated.

Mobitz I heart block (Wenckebach) (Option C): There is progressive PR interval prolongation followed by a dropped beat. This pattern is absent on this ECG—there is no progressive PR lengthening.

Mobitz II heart block (Option D): Sudden dropping of QRS complexes without PR prolongation is the hallmark. However, in Mobitz II, P waves remain present, unlike in this ECG, where P waves themselves disappear intermittently.

questions.text: Stitch for cervical cerclage operation is cut at _____ of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) 36 weeks

Explanation:

  • Cervical cerclage is used to prevent mid-trimester pregnancy losses in women with cervical incompetence.
  • The stitch (McDonald or Shirodkar) is removed at 36–37 weeks to prevent complications during labor.
  • 14 weeks (Option A): Placement, not removal.
  • 28 weeks (Option B): Too early for removal.
  • 40 weeks (Option D): Risk of going into labor with stitches in place.

questions.text: What is the best investigation to diagnose Best disease?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Electro-oculogram

Explanation:

Best's disease, also known as Best vitelliform macular dystrophy, is a rare genetic eye disorder that primarily affects the macula, the central part of the retina responsible for sharp, central vision. It is characterized by the accumulation of a yellowish, lipofuscin-like material beneath the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).

The key to diagnosing Best's disease is identifying a specific abnormality in the retinal pigment epithelium's function. The Electro-oculogram (EOG) is a test that measures the standing potential of the eye, which is primarily generated by the RPE.

  • In a healthy eye, the EOG shows a distinct pattern where the electrical potential increases from a "trough" (dark adaptation) to a "peak" (light adaptation). The ratio of the peak to the trough (the Arden ratio) is typically greater than 1.8.

  • In patients with Best's disease, the RPE function is severely impaired. The EOG test shows an abnormally low or absent light peak, resulting in a significantly reduced Arden ratio (usually less than 1.5), even in the early stages when the vision may still be relatively normal. This characteristic EOG finding is a hallmark of the disease and is often present even before funduscopic changes are evident

  • Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) (Option A): This test involves injecting a fluorescent dye into the bloodstream and taking pictures of the retina. While it can show the stages of the disease (e.g., hyperfluorescence in the early stages and "egg yolk" appearance), it is not the definitive diagnostic tool. The EOG provides a more specific and sensitive functional diagnosis of the RPE dysfunction that is the root cause of the disease.\

  • Optical coherence tomography (OCT) (Option B): OCT provides high-resolution, cross-sectional images of the retina. It can visualize the subretinal fluid and the vitelliform material accumulation, which is useful for monitoring the progression of the disease. However, like FFA, it is a structural test, not a functional test of the RPE. The EOG remains the gold standard for functional diagnosis.

  • Visual field testing (Option D): This test measures the entire field of vision, including peripheral vision. It is used to detect vision loss associated with conditions like glaucoma or optic nerve damage. While a patient with advanced Best's disease may have central visual field loss, this test is not specific for diagnosing the condition itself. The primary vision loss in Best's disease is central, not peripheral.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about GBS?

choices.text: Cyto-albuminological dissociation in seen in CSF
Areflexia in weak limbs included in criteria
Plasmapheresis is not done in refractory GBS

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D. Plasmapheresis is not done in refractory GBS

Explanation:

  • Plasmapheresis is done in refractory GBS and is one of the mainstays of treatment. (Option D)
  • IVIG and plasmapheresis are equally effective and any one of these can be initiated.
  • GBS is an acute, immune- mediated polyradiculoneuropathy that typically presents with:
    • Rapidly progressive bilateral falccid limb weakness
    • Areflexia
    • Often preceded by an infection (e.g., Capmylobacter jejuni, CMV)
Brighton Criteria for Diagnosis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

Clinical case definitions for diagnosis of GBS

Level 1 of diagnostic certainty

Bilateral AND flaccid weakness of the limbs

       AND

Decreased or absent deep tendon reflexes in weak limbs

      AND

Monophasic illness pattern and interval between outset and nadir of weakness between 12 h and 28 days and subsequent clinical plateau

      AND

Electrophysiologic findings consistent with GBS

     AND
