Cytoalbuminologic dissociation (i.e, elevation of CSF protein level above laboratory normal value AND CSF total white cell count <5l cells/ipl

    AND

Absence of an identified alternative diagnosis for weakness

IVIG is initial therapy. (Option A)

Cyto-albuminological dissociation in & Areflexia are key components of Brighton criteria for diagnosis of GBS (Option B and C)

questions.text: 30-year-old know case of GTCS on Sodium valproate for last 5 years has presented with 32 weeks of pregnancy completed at your tertiary care hospital. Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Neonatal Seizures

Explanation:

  • Sodium valproate is a teratogenic anticonvulsant causing:
    • Neural tube defects (e.g., anencephaly) (Option B)
    • Cleft lip/palate (Option A)
    • Coagulopathies (→ neonatal hemorrhage) due to vitamin K interference (Option C)
  • Neonatal seizures are not a direct teratogenic effect of valproate.

questions.text: 30-year-old lady was admitted due to polytrauma. On day 3 of admission, she develops sudden onset breathing difficulty and spO2 is 70% on room air. On examination pulse is 120/min BP 100/80 mm Hg with loud S1 and wide split S2. Which of the following is first test to be done in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. D Dimer assay

Explanation:

The patient is having pulmonary embolism as evidenced by wide split S2 that indicates RVF, SpO₂ 70% on room air → suggests significant V/Q mismatch.

Approach: Suspected PE:

  • D-Dimer is a screening test – useful to rule out PE in low to intermediate probability

  • In high-risk settings (like trauma), it helps justify next steps (CTPA)

  • CTPA is diagnostic but not the first test due to time, radiation, and contrast load

  • If D-dimer is elevated → proceed to CTPA

  • If normal → PE unlikely

Fat embolism (Option A) does not cause heart failure but non cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

Stat ABG (Option C) → May show hypoxia but not diagnostic; doesn’t guide next steps

CTPA (Option D) → Investigation of choice for PE but not the first step in workup; needs D-dimer to justify in many cases

questions.text: Comment on the embryological structure shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Urachal remnant

Explanation:

The given radiograph depicts Urachal remnant.

  • Urachus → Embryological structure that connects the fetal bladder to the allantois during development.
  • Normally, it obliterates after birth to become the median umbilical ligament.
  • Persistence of this structure results in a urachal remnant, which can be seen on imaging as a midline cystic or tubular structure between the bladder and the umbilicus.

 

Structures

Remnant

Vitello-intestinal duct (Option C ruled out)

Meckel’s diverticulum

Urachus (Option A)

Median umbilical ligament

Ductus arteriosus and venous

Ligamentum arteriosum and venosum

Rathke pouch (Option B ruled out)

Craniopharyngioma


Cloacal pouch (Option D) is an embryological structure that gives rise to the hindgut and urogenital sinus but is not visualized as a discrete remnant like the urachus.

questions.text: EYE strategy is for elimination of which of the following infections?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Yellow fever

Explanation:

The EYE Strategy stands for: Eliminate Yellow Fever Epidemics. It was launched due to the resurgence of yellow fever in Africa and South America, especially urban outbreaks with global travel risk.

EYE Strategy:

  • Launched by:

    • World Health Organisation (WHO)

    • UNICEF

    • Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, and other partners

  • Goal:

    • To eliminate yellow fever epidemics by 2030.

  • Focus Areas:

    • Protecting at-risk populations through vaccination.

    • Preventing international spread.

    • Contain outbreaks rapidly.

Trachoma (Option A): Trachoma is targeted under the SAFE strategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial cleanliness, Environmental improvement), not EYE.

Vitamin A deficiency (Option B): It is addressed through supplementation programs, not the EYE strategy.

Dengue fever(Option D): It is managed under integrated vector control and vaccine trials, but not part of EYE.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is admitted to the medicine ward with complaints of vomiting and diarrhea. Lab investigations reveal a serum potassium level of 3.2 mEq/L. All of the following can be features of the underlying dyselectrolytemia except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Cerebral edema

Explanation:

The patient has hypokalemia (serum potassium = 3.2 mEq/L). Cerebral edema is Not caused by hypokalemia. Rather, it is associated with:

  • Hyponatremia
  • Rapid correction of hypernatremia

Hence the only condition not associated with it is cerebral edema.

Ventricular tachycardia (Option A): Hypokalemia increases cardiac excitability. This can cause ventricular arrhythmias due to prolongation of QT interval. So this is a correct feature of hypokalemia.

Quadriplegia (Option B): Severe hypokalemia can cause muscle weakness, even paralysis, including quadriplegia in extreme cases. It occurs due to impaired neuromuscular transmission.

Diabetes insipidus (Option C): This presents as polyuria and polydipsia. Hypokalemia impairs renal tubular response to ADH (by making V2 receptor resistant to action of vasopressin) , leading to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

questions.text: Tofacitinib exerts its anti-inflammatory effect by:

choices.text: Inhibiting NF-κB activation in T cells
Inhibiting JAK1 and JAK3-dependent cytokine signaling
Suppressing TNF-α synthesis via mRNA destabilization

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Inhibiting JAK1 and JAK3-dependent cytokine signaling

Explanation:

  • Tofacitinib is an oral Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitor that primarily targets JAK1 and JAK3, key components of the JAK-STAT pathway involved in cytokine receptor signaling (e.g., IL-2, IL-4, IL-6, IL-7, IL-15, IL-21).
  • By blocking JAK1 and JAK3, tofacitinib prevents STAT activation and transcription of pro-inflammatory genes, thereby suppressing the immune response in diseases like rheumatoid arthritis and ulcerative colitis.

Blocking IL-6 receptor directly (Option A): Describes the mechanism of tocilizumab, not tofacitinib.

Inhibiting NF-κB activation in T cells (Option B): Seen with agents like glucocorticoids or proteasome inhibitors, not JAK inhibitors.

Suppressing TNF-α synthesis via mRNA destabilization (Option D): Refers to the action of thalidomide and some anti-TNF agents, not tofacitinib.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to ER with severe chest pain. On examination BP 200/100 mmHg, and HR 120/min. CTA confirms stanford type A aortic dissection. What is the initial management step?

choices.text: Start esmolol followed by sodium nitroprusside
Start sodium nitroprusside followed by esmolol

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Start esmolol  followed by sodium nitroprusside 

Explanation:

Note that question is on initial management and not definite management. 

In Stanford type A aortic dissection, Option A is correct because beta-blockers reduce heart rate and shear stress, and vasodilators are added after to control BP. After medical stabilization surgical repair will have a better prognosis intra and postoperatively. 

Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition caused by a tear in the intima of the aorta, allowing blood to dissect between the layers of the vessel wall.

It is classified using the Stanford and DeBakey systems.

  • Stanford Type A involves the ascending aorta (± arch/descending) and always requires emergency surgical repair.
  • Stanford Type B involves only the descending aorta and is usually managed medically unless complications arise.
  • DeBakey Type I involves both ascending and descending.
  • Debackey Type II is confined to ascending
  • Debackey Type III involves only descending aorta.

Diagnosis is typically confirmed by CT angiography (CTA), which shows an intimal flap and true/false lumens.

Initial management includes beta-blockers (e.g., esmolol) to control heart rate and vasodilators (after HR control) to reduce blood pressure, followed by definitive surgery (for Type A) or medical therapy (for uncomplicated Type B).

Giving nitroprusside first (Option B) can cause reflex tachycardia, worsening the dissection.

Immediate surgical repair (Option C), is essential but only after stabilization with BP and HR control. 

Vitamin K inhibitors (Option D), are anticoagulants and contraindicated, as they increase bleeding risk. Thus, medical stabilization with beta-blocker first is the initial lifesaving step.

questions.text: A week old neonate is brought to hospital with difficulty in feeding and poor cry. On examination hypertonia and opisthotonus is noted. Which of the following is possible etiology?

choices.text: Toxin binds synaptic cleft and decreases release of ACh
Toxin binds to synaptobrevin and inhibits release of GABA
Toxin binds to renshaw cells and inhibits release of glycine
Toxin binds to purkinje cells and cause glutamate excitotoxicity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Toxin binds to synaptobrevin and inhibits release of GABA

Explanation:

  • The neonate presents with poor feeding, weak cry, hypertonia, and opisthotonus, which are classic features of neonatal tetanus.
    • Tetanus toxin acts on
    • Synaptobrevin and prevents the release of GABA
    • Strychnine
    • Binds to Renshaw cells and inhibits release of glycine (Inhibition of inhibitory cells)

Neonatal Tetanus

Etiology:

  • Caused by Clostridium tetani infection, often introduced through the umbilical stump due to poor aseptic delivery practices.
  • The bacterium produces tetanospasmin, a neurotoxin responsible for the clinical symptoms.

Pathophysiology:

  1. Entry & Transport:
    1. Tetanospasmin enters the body, typically through umbilical stump contamination in neonates.
    2. Travels retrogradely via peripheral nerves into the spinal cord.
  2. Cellular Target: The toxin cleaves synaptobrevin (VAMP), a component of the SNARE complex involved in vesicle fusion and neurotransmitter release.
     

  3. Neurotransmitter Inhibition:

    1. This blocks the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA and Glycine.
    2. This occurs primarily in inhibitory interneurons in the spinal cord (like Renshaw cells, but not exclusively)
    3. Lack of inhibition → Unopposed excitatory activity → Generalized rigidity, hyperreflexia, spasms, opisthotonus.

 

 

Hence, Synaptobrevin (VAMP) is the exact molecular target of tetanospasmin. Its cleavage → blocks release of GABA, an important CNS inhibitory neurotransmitter. Thus, Option B provides the most precise molecular mechanism.
 

Clinical Features:

  • Appears around 3–10 days of life
  • Poor feeding
  • Weak cry
  • Trismus (lockjaw)
  • Generalized hypertonia and severe spasms (often triggered by stimuli)
  • Opisthotonus (arching of the back due to extensor muscle spasm)

Toxin binds synaptic cleft and decreases release of ACh (Option A): This describes the action of botulinum toxin, not tetanospasmin. Botulism leads to flaccid paralysis, not hypertonia.

Toxin binds to Renshaw cells and inhibits release of glycine (Option C): This is functionally true, but not as specific as Option B. It describes the cellular site, not the molecular mechanism.
 

Toxin binds to Purkinje cells and causes glutamate excitotoxicity (Option D): This is not relevant to tetanus. Glutamate excitotoxicity occurs in stroke or neurodegeneration, not tetanus.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man suffers a cardiac arrest in the emergency room. After 3 cycles of CPR and 2 defibrillation shocks, he achieves return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC). He is now unresponsive, with a blood pressure of 88/50 mmHg and SpO2 of 92% on 10L/min oxygen by face mask. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer 1 mg epinephrine IV every 3-5 minutes and continue chest compressions
Perform immediate coronary angiography and stenting regardless of ECG findings
Optimize oxygenation and ventilation, and assess for need of vasopressors and targeted temperature management
Discontinue resuscitation efforts and observe, as ROSC has been achieved

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Optimize oxygenation and ventilation, and assess for need of vasopressors and targeted temperature management

Explanation:

  • The patient has achieved Return of Spontaneous Circulation (ROSC) but remains unresponsive and hemodynamically unstable.
  • The immediate next step post-ROSC is to stabilize the patient by supporting oxygenation, ventilation, and perfusion, and initiate post-cardiac arrest care, including targeted temperature management (TTM).

Post-Cardiac Arrest Management (Post-ROSC Care)

Goals of Post-ROSC Care:

  1. Optimize oxygenation and ventilation:
    • Maintain SpO₂ >94%
    • Avoid hyperoxia (PaO₂ >300 mmHg)
    • Maintain PaCO₂ within normal limits (35–45 mmHg)
  2. Hemodynamic support:
    • Maintain systolic BP ≥90 mmHg or MAP ≥65 mmHg
    • Consider vasopressors like norepinephrine if hypotension persists
  3. Targeted Temperature Management (TTM):
    • Indicated in comatose post-arrest patients to reduce neurologic injury
    • Maintain temperature at 32–36°C for at least 24 hours
  4. Identify and treat underlying cause:
    • ECG for ST-elevation MI (STEMI)
    • Consider emergent coronary angiography if STEMI present
    • Evaluate for other causes: PE, sepsis, electrolyte disturbance
  5. Neurologic assessment:
    • Reassess over time — early assessment is unreliable

Administer 1 mg epinephrine IV every 3-5 minutes and continue chest compressions (Option A):

  • Not appropriate after ROSC has been achieved.
  • Epinephrine and CPR are part of active resuscitation, which is no longer indicated.

Perform immediate coronary angiography and stenting regardless of ECG findings (Option B):

  • Coronary angiography is indicated only if ECG shows STEMI or if high suspicion exists.
  • Not warranted in all post-arrest patients.

Discontinue resuscitation efforts and observe, as ROSC has been achieved (Option D):

  • ROSC is only the first step; supportive care must continue.
  • Observation without intervention may result in rapid deterioration.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about placental previa?

choices.text: Height of uterus is disproportionate to gestational age

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Height of uterus is disproportionate to gestational age

Explanation:

  • In placenta previa, uterine size typically corresponds to gestational age unless complicated.
  • Therefore, height disproportion is not a characteristic finding.
  • Uterus is soft and relaxed (Option B): True – bleeding is painless and uterus non-tender.
  • Head is high floating (Option C): True – due to placenta blocking descent.
  • Fetal heart rate is present (Option D): Often normal unless abruption coexists.

questions.text: Differentiation of cyto and synctiotrophoblastic layers occurs on __ day following fertilization?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 7

Explanation:

On Day 7 post-fertilisation, the trophoblast differentiates into two distinct layers:

  • Cytotrophoblast: The inner mononuclear layer composed of individual cells
  • Syncytiotrophoblast: The outer multinucleated layer that invades the endometrium and facilitates implantation

This bilayered structure is crucial for early placental development and marks the beginning of successful implantation into the maternal endometrium.

5 (Option A): This is typically the blastocyst stage, before implantation or trophoblastic differentiation begins.

10 (Option C): By this time, implantation is nearly complete, and lacunae begin forming in the syncytiotrophoblast - differentiation has already occurred by this point.

21 (Option D): This is much later in the embryonic period - gastrulation and early organogenesis occur around this time.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with stable COPD and an mMRC dyspnea grade 1 presents for maintenance therapy. He has no recent exacerbations. Which of the following is the most appropriate monotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Indacaterol

Explanations:

This patient fits GOLD Group A:

  • Low symptom burden (mMRC 0–1 or CAT <10)
  • Low exacerbation risk (0–1 exacerbation in last year, not requiring hospitalization)

According to GOLD 2024 guidelines, Group A patients are managed with Monotherapy with a LAMA or a LABA: Ultra–long-acting β2 agonists (uLABAs) like indacaterol are preferred due to once-daily dosing and excellent bronchodilation.

Indacaterol is a once-daily ultra–long-acting β2 agonist (uLABA) used for maintenance in stable COPD with mild dyspnea (GOLD A). It improves Lung function, Symptom control and Quality of life. Its long duration and convenient once-daily dose make it ideal for monotherapy in patients with minimal symptoms and no recent exacerbations.

GOLD COPD group classification and treatment

Group

Symptoms (mMRC / CAT)

Exacerbation History

Preferred Treatment

Comments

A

Low (mMRC 0–1 or CAT < 10)

0 or 1 (not leading to hospitalization)

Monotherapy with a LAMA or LABA (e.g., indacaterol, tiotropium)

Choose based on availability, patient preference

B

High (mMRC ≥ 2 or CAT ≥ 10)

0 or 1 (not leading to hospitalization)

LAMA + LABA combination

For better symptom control

E

Any symptom burden

≥ 2 exacerbations or ≥ 1 hospitalization

LAMA + LABA ± ICS (if eos ≥ 300 cells/μL)

ICS added only if eosinophils high or asthma overlap

Salbutamol (Option A): Short-acting β2 agonist (SABA) used for acute symptom relief, not maintenance. It does not provide prolonged bronchodilation and is not recommended for long-term control.

Tiotropium (Option B): Long-acting muscarinic antagonist (LAMA), also acceptable for GOLD A monotherapy. However, uLABAs like indacaterol are now preferred in low-symptom patients due to better symptom relief and patient compliance (once-daily use). Still a viable alternative if uLABA is unavailable.

Budesonide (Option D): Inhaled corticosteroid (ICS). Not used alone in COPD. Reserved for:

  • Patients with frequent exacerbations
  • Eosinophilic phenotype (eos ≥300)
  • Asthma-COPD overlap

This patient has no exacerbations and is not a candidate for ICS therapy.

questions.text: Grouped vesicles in dermatomal distribution are called as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Herpes zoster

Explanations:

  • Herpes zoster (shingles) presents with grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, strictly confined to a single dermatome, and is usually unilateral. It is due to reactivation of varicella-zoster virus (VZV) from dorsal root ganglia.
  • The hallmark clinical clue is dermatomal distribution—a key distinguishing feature.

Herpes simplex (Option A): Typically causes painful grouped vesicles, but they do not follow a dermatomal distribution. They recur at the same site (like lips or genitalia) and are not dermatomally restricted.

Herpes gestationis (Option C): This is a misnomer—it's not a herpes infection. It's an autoimmune bullous dermatosis of pregnancy, now called pemphigoid gestationis, and does not show grouped vesicles or dermatomal patterns.

Genital herpes (Option D): Caused by HSV-2, it presents as grouped vesicles or ulcers over the genital area, but again, not in a dermatomal pattern—rather, in the anogenital mucosa.

questions.text: In the management of placenta previa in hospital, steroid therapy is given in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Active interference

Explanation:

In placenta previa, the management approach (expectant or active) depends on several factors like gestational age, maternal/fetal status, and severity of bleeding.

Steroid therapy is specifically indicated when:

  • Gestational age is <34 weeks.
  • There is a need for early delivery- usually due to active or recurrent bleeding, non-reassuring fetal status, or maternal compromise.

Steroids like betamethasone are given prior to preterm delivery — and delivery typically occurs under active management, not during expectant care unless complications arise.

Expectant Treatment (Option A): In expectant management, the goal is to prolong pregnancy for fetal maturity while monitoring closely. Steroid therapy may not be routinely initiated unless early delivery becomes likely. Only if bleeding recurs or fetal/maternal compromise occurs and delivery is anticipated, would steroids be administered — which transitions the management into active interference.

Cord Prolapse (Option C): This is a completely different obstetric emergency where the umbilical cord slips ahead of the presenting part of the fetus, leading to compression and a potential cutoff of the fetal blood supply. The management of cord prolapse is immediate delivery, usually an emergency Cesarean section, to relieve the pressure on the cord. Steroids have no role in the acute management of a cord prolapse.

No role of steroid therapy (Option D): Steroids play a vital role in the management of placenta previa, specifically as a prophylactic measure during expectant treatment to reduce neonatal morbidity associated with preterm delivery.

questions.text: Which is correct about the swelling shown below?

choices.text: Does not reduce on lying down

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bag of worms’ appearance

Explanation:

  • The image shows tortuous, dilated scrotal veins, consistent with a varicocele.
  • On clinical examination, a varicocele feels like a bag of worms — soft, compressible, and often more apparent with Valsalva maneuver.
  • This swelling typically reduces or disappears on lying down, confirming its venous nature.

Varicocele

Definition:

  • A varicocele is the abnormal dilatation of the pampiniform venous plexus in the spermatic cord.
  • Most commonly affects the left side due to anatomical drainage into the left renal vein, which is subject to higher venous pressure.

Etiology:

  • Left testicular vein drains at a right angle into the left renal vein → predisposes to increased hydrostatic pressure.
  • Compression between the aorta and superior mesenteric artery (nutcracker phenomenon) may also contribute.

Clinical Features:

  • Commonly occurs in adolescent males or young adults.
  • Presents as painless scrotal swelling or dull aching pain in the scrotum.
  • Characteristic “bag of worms” feel on palpation, best appreciated:
    • In standing position
    • With Valsalva maneuver
  • Reduces or disappears when lying down, which helps distinguish it from other scrotal masses.
  • Long-standing varicocele may lead to testicular atrophy or male infertility due to raised scrotal temperature and oxidative stress on spermatogenesis.

Grading:

  • Grade I: Palpable only during Valsalva
  • Grade II: Palpable at rest but not visible
  • Grade III: Visible through scrotal skin

Diagnosis:

  • Scrotal Doppler ultrasound is the investigation of choice.
    • Confirms dilated veins (>2–3 mm)
    • Demonstrates retrograde flow on Valsalva
  • Semen analysis if infertility is suspected

Management:

  • Observation in asymptomatic cases or small subclinical varicoceles.
  • Surgical correction (varicocelectomy) or embolization if:
    • Pain or discomfort
    • Testicular atrophy
    • Infertility with abnormal semen parameters

Cluster of grapes appearance (Option A):

  • Seen in lymphangioma or hydatid cyst of Morgagni.
  • Refers to a multiloculated cystic lesion, not venous dilatation.

Silk glove feel (Option C):

  • Describes the sensation of a patent processus vaginalis, commonly felt in pediatric inguinal hernia.
  • Feels like soft, smooth sliding layers under the examining finger.

Does not reduce on lying down (Option D):

  • Incorrect. Varicocele reduces or disappears in the supine position due to gravity-dependent venous drainage.
  • Swellings that do not reduce may indicate hydrocele or hernia.

questions.text: Sepsis is defined as

choices.text: 2-point increment in SOFA score over 2 serial examination
3-point increment in SOFA score over 2 serial examinations

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. 2-point increment in SOFA score over 2 serial examinations

Explanation:

Sepsis is defined as life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection

This organ dysfunction is objectively identified by a ≥2-point increase in the SOFA score from baseline.

  • SOFA = Sequential Organ Failure Assessment

  • It includes: PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio, platelet count, bilirubin, MAP/vasopressors, GCS, creatinine/urine output

  • A ≥2 point rise is associated with increased mortality

3-point increment (Option B): Incorrect cutoff. Sepsis is defined as a ≥2-point increase, not 3.

SIRS + positive blood culture (Option C): Blood culture positivity is not mandatory.

SIRS + hypotension requiring vasopressors (Option D): This describes septic shock, a subset of sepsis — not sepsis itself.

questions.text: The following oxyhaemoglobin dissociation curve is given. Select the correct statement
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Blue- oxyhaemoglobin and red – myoglobin

Explanation:

The Oxyhemoglobin Dissociation Curve shows oxygen affinity differences: the blue sigmoidal curve represents oxyhemoglobin with cooperative binding, and the red hyperbolic curve represents myoglobin with higher affinity and no cooperativity.

  • The oxygen dissociation curve for myoglobin is rectangular hyperbolic.
  • This is because, in the case of myoglobin, one molecule of haemoglobin binds with one molecule of oxygen with high affinity, and complete saturation will occur.
  • Unlike haemoglobin, which has a sigmoidal curve due to cooperative binding among its four subunits, myoglobin's curve does not exhibit cooperativity.
  • This means myoglobin can efficiently bind and release oxygen at varying partial pressures, making it well-suited for oxygen storage in muscle tissues.

questions.text: 25-year-old primigravida is having 6 weeks amenorrhea with severe pain in lower abdomen since today morning followed by two episodes of vomiting and prostration. In ER she tells about occasional spotting noticed for last one day, she is perspiring and looks pale. Pulse is 120/min low volume with cold clammy extremities and BP=80/60 mm Hg. Per abdomen bowel is tense and tender and no mass is felt. Vaginal examinations show blanched white vaginal mucosa and further examination was deferred as patient is sick. Which of the following is the best test to confirm the presentation of this case?

choices.text: Estimation of serum Beta HCG values

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Trans vaginal scan

Explanation:

  • This patient is presenting with signs suggestive of ruptured ectopic pregnancy (pain, pallor, hypotension, vaginal spotting).
  • Transvaginal ultrasonography (TVS) is the most sensitive and non-invasive method to confirm diagnosis by detecting an empty uterus and possibly an adnexal mass or free fluid.
  • Culdocentesis (Option A) is invasive and rarely done now.
  • Serum β-hCG (Option B) supports diagnosis but is non-localizing.
  • Blood grouping (Option C) is essential for management but not diagnostic.

questions.text: A patient of chest trauma underwent thoracic surgery. While reviewing output charts you find 200 mL of blood in the drain within the last one hour. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Notify the surgeon

Explanation:

  • Drain output of >200 mL of blood in 1 hour post-thoracic surgery is clinically significant and may indicate ongoing intrathoracic bleeding.
  • This requires immediate surgical attention, as it could lead to hemodynamic instability or the need for re-intervention.

Post-Thoracic Surgery Chest Drain Management

Purpose of Intercostal Drain (ICD):

  • To drain blood, air, or pus from pleural cavity
  • Monitor ongoing bleeding or air leak

Monitoring Parameters:

  • Type of fluid (serous, sanguineous, purulent, chylous)
  • Volume per hour
  • Trend over time

Criteria Suggesting Significant Post-Operative Bleeding:

  • 200 mL/hour of fresh blood
  • Persistent bleeding of >150 mL/hour for 2–3 hours
  • Sudden increase in blood loss
  • Signs of hemodynamic instability (tachycardia, hypotension)

Management:

  • Notify the surgeon immediately for evaluation
  • Prepare for possible re-exploration or intervention
  • Monitor vitals and hemoglobin levels
  • Ensure availability of blood products for transfusion if necessary

Document and continue monitoring (Option A):

  • While documentation is important, passive monitoring is inadequate in the face of potential active bleeding.
  • Delaying escalation can result in life-threatening hemorrhage.

Clamp the drain (Option B):

  • Clamping may cause tension hemothorax or tamponade effect, leading to respiratory or cardiac compromise.
  • Never clamp unless advised by the surgeon in specific situations.

Remove the drain (Option D):

  • Removing the drain would eliminate a vital diagnostic and therapeutic tool.
  • Also risks retention of blood in the pleural cavity and worsening the clinical status.

questions.text: Many people were drinking country liquor which was mixed with methylated spirit and are brought to ER in unconscious state. Which of the following will be used to manage these cases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Intravenous folate

Explanation:

This is a classic case of methanol poisoning (from ingestion of methylated spirit mixed in country liquor), which leads to metabolic acidosis, visual disturbances, and CNS depression, often progressing to coma or death.

Management of methanol poisoning:

Component

Role

Fomepizole or Ethanol

Competitively inhibit alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) to prevent methanol metabolism to toxic formic acid.

Folate (IV folinic acid or folic acid)

Enhances metabolism of formic acid to CO₂ and water, reducing toxicity.

Hemodialysis

For severe poisoning (pH < 7.25, visual symptoms, renal failure).

Supportive care

Airway, fluids, bicarbonate, etc

Intravenous ethylene glycol (Option A) is itself a toxic alcohol (causes oxalate nephropathy), not used for treatment

IV cyanocobalamine (Option C) is used for cyanide poisoning, not for methanol

IV atropine (Option D) is used in OP poisoning, has no role in methanol toxicity

questions.text: The image shows?

choices.text: Rocket endocervical brush for endocervical sampling

questions.solution:
​

Correct answer: B) Rocket endocervical brush for endocervical sampling

Explanation:

The Rocket endocervical brush is a type of cytobrush used to collect cells from the endocervical canal (the inner part of the cervix). The fine bristles are designed to reach into the canal to obtain columnar cells from the transformation zone, where many cervical cancers originate.

​

 

Ayre spatula for cervical scraping (Option A): The Ayre spatula is a traditional wooden or plastic instrument used to collect a cell sample from the ectocervix (the outer part of the cervix). Its unique shape is designed to fit the contours of the cervix, and it is rotated to scrape off cells for a Pap smear.

 

​​​​​

​​​​​

​​​​

Procedure:

  1. Insert the longer arm of the spatula into the cervical os (canal).
  2. Rotate 360° to collect cells from:
    1. Endocervix (inside the canal – purple zone)
    2. Transformation zone (squamo-columnar junction – green zone)
    3. Ectocervix (outer surface – yellow zone)
  3. Then spread the sample on a slide or deposit it into a liquid-based cytology container in the direction shown (right side of image).

Wooden spatula for cyto-hormonal study (Option C): While wooden spatulas (like the Ayre spatula) are used for cervical cytology, they can also be used for hormonal studies. A cyto-hormonal study involves examining the maturation of squamous cells to assess a woman's hormonal status (e.g., estrogen levels). The cells are collected using a spatula and then analyzed to determine the ratio of different cell types, which provides an indication of hormonal influence.

​​​​​

Karman cannula (Option D): This is a soft, flexible plastic cannula used for uterine aspiration. It is used in procedures such as manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) for early pregnancy termination, management of incomplete miscarriage, or for endometrial biopsy. It is designed to be flexible to reduce the risk of uterine perforation.

​​​​​


 

​

questions.text: Which of the following is called as nulligravida?

choices.text: Not pregnant now and never in past
Woman who has just now given birth

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Not pregnant now and never in past

  • Gravida: Refers to the total number of times a woman has been pregnant, regardless of the outcome (whether it was a miscarriage, abortion, or live birth).
  • Nulligravida: A woman who has never been pregnant. (Nulli- means "none" and -gravida means "pregnant"). (Option B)
  • Primigravida: A woman who is currently pregnant for the first time. (Primi- means "first"). (Option A ruled out)
  • Multigravida: A woman who has been pregnant more than once. (Multi- means "many").

And for parity:

  • Para (or Parity): Refers to the number of pregnancies that have reached the age of viability (usually 20 weeks).
  • Nullipara: A woman who has never given birth to a fetus that has reached viability. A nulligravida is also a nullipara.
  • Primipara: A woman who has given birth once to a fetus that has reached viability.(Option D ruled out)
  • Multipara: A woman who has given birth multiple times to a fetus that has reached viability.

Can never be pregnant (Option C): This describes a woman who is infertile, but it's not the definition of nulligravida.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of a sudden, strong urge to urinate, frequent daytime urination, and occasional leakage before reaching the bathroom. He denies straining, poor stream, or hesitancy. He recently was diagnosed with Sjogren syndrome. Which of the following is the most appropriate medication to relieve his urinary symptoms without worsening his underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mirabegron

Explanation:

  • The patient likely has overactive bladder (urge incontinence) due to detrusor overactivity.
  • Mirabegron is a β3-adrenergic agonist that relaxes the detrusor muscle during storage phase, improving urgency and frequency without anticholinergic side effects—ideal for patients with Sjogren syndrome, who already suffer from dryness.

Tolterodine (Option A): An antimuscarinic that may relieve symptoms but can worsen dry mouth and eyes in Sjogren’s.

Tamsulosin (Option C): An α1-blocker used for bladder outlet obstruction (e.g., BPH), which the patient does not have.

Oxybutynin (Option D): Another anticholinergic with even more pronounced drying effects, making it inappropriate in Sjogren’s.

questions.text: Intestine contracts to mix chyme from the stomach with pancreatic and intestinal secretions. This action is called
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Segmentation

Explanation:

  • Segmentation is the primary mixing movement of the small intestine that:
     

Gastrointestinal (GI) Motility

Migrating motor complexes

(Option A ruled out)

Cyclic peristalsis in stomach and small intestine to clear residual food ( intestinal housekeeper)

Basal electrical rhythm

(Option B ruled out)

Spontaneous fluctuations in RMP of smooth muscle. max is duodenum and least is caecum

Segmentation

(Option C)

Occurs in small bowel and mixes food ( chyme and pancreatic juice ).

Enhances contact with mucosa for absorption.

Involves rhythmic contractions of circular smooth muscle.

Deglutitive inhibition

(Option D ruled out)

Required for drinking liquids which require rapid swallows like beer

Hyperpolarization of smooth muscles and mediated by nor adrenergic and non-cholinergic neurons in myenteric plexus

questions.text: A 34-year-old nulliparous woman is having anemia. Menstural history has irregular cycles with heavy bleeding. TVS and colour doppler shows multiple fibroids in an enlarged uterus. All are true about this condition except?

choices.text: Centre of fibroid is least vascular and is likely to degenerate
Cervical fibroids can kink the ureter
Mifepristone is effective to reduce fibroid size and menorrhagia
Subserous pendunculated fibroid is best diagnosed with Saline infusion sonography

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Subserous pedunculated fibroid is best diagnosed with Saline infusion sonography

Explanation:

  • Saline infusion sonography (SIS) is useful for submucosal fibroids, not subserous ones.
  • Central degeneration due to poor vascularity is characteristic. (Option A)
  • Cervical fibroids may cause pressure effects like ureteric obstruction.(Option B)
  • Mifepristone, a progesterone receptor modulator, is used to shrink fibroids. (Option C)

questions.text: The risk of tubal pregnancy is increased with?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) IUD

Explanation:

  • IUDs prevent intrauterine pregnancy but not always tubal implantation.
  • If pregnancy does occur, it's more likely to be ectopic.
  • Age of parity (Option A): Slight association but not specific.
  • Recurrent UTI (Option C): Not directly associated.
  • Uterine malformations (Option D): More commonly associated with miscarriage, not ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: HPV triage strategy includes:

choices.text: Pap smear, HPV DNA PCR and colposcopy
Pap smear, Cervicography and visual inspection with acetic acid
Pap smear, Schiller test and Endocervical curettage

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Pap smear, HPV DNA PCR and colposcopy

Explanation:

  • HPV triage is used to improve cervical cancer screening:
    • Pap smear screens for cytological changes.
    • HPV DNA PCR testing detects high-risk viral strains.
    • Colposcopy evaluates abnormal areas for biopsy.

questions.text: The following splint is used for management of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Brachial plexus injury

Explanation:
Brachial plexus injury:

  • An aerial splint is a type of suspension splint used to support and elevate the flaccid upper limb.
  • It is specifically useful in:
    • Brachial plexus palsy
    • Flail arm conditions
  • Functions of aerial splint:
    • Maintains arm in functional position (abduction and external rotation)
    • Prevents contractures and dependent oedema
    • Allows passive movement and muscle recovery support

Radial nerve injury (Option A): Managed with a cock-up splint to address wrist drop, not with aerial suspension.

Median nerve injury (Option C): Treated with an opponens splint to support thumb opposition.

Ulnar nerve injury (Option D): Managed with a knuckle bender splint to correct claw hand deformity.

questions.text: 30-year-old rickshaw puller is diagnosed with duodenal ulcer. He is started on Vonoprazan. Which of the following is not correct about this medication?

choices.text: Can be taken without regard to meals
Long duration of action with rapid onset
Acid labile and requires enteric coating

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Acid labile and requires enteric coating

Explanation:

  • Vonoprazan is a Potassium-Competitive Acid Blocker (PCAB) that inhibits the H+/K+ ATPase enzyme in a reversible and potassium-competitive manner, unlike PPIs that bind irreversibly. Vonoprazan is acid-stable and does not need enteric coating and works faster.

Feature

P-CABs

PPIs (e.g. omeprazole)

Mechanism

Reversible, K+ - competitive inhibition (Option A ruled out)

Irreversible inhibition of H+/K+ - ATPase

Onset of action

Rapid (within hours) (Option C ruled out)

Slower (requires activation in acidic pH)

Duration of action

Long (Option C ruled out)

Long, but depends on enzyme turnover

Acid stability

Stable

Acid-labile (requires enteric coating)

Dosing

Can be taken without regard to meals (Option B ruled out)

Best taken before meals

questions.text: You are checking the distal pulse of a 30-year-old construction worker smoker. Which is not correct about it
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Palpated against cuboid bone

Explanation:

  • When checking the distal pulse of a 30-year-old construction worker who smokes, it cannot be palpated against the cuboid bone, as the cuboid is located on the lateral side of the foot near the lateral arch, whereas the dorsalis pedis pulse is felt more medially over the navicular and cuneiform bones.

Dorsalis pedis artery

  • The distal pulse is commonly checked here.
  • Palpated:
    • Against navicular and 2nd cuneiform bones
    • Lateral to tendon of EHL (extensor hallucis longus) (Option B ruled out)
  • It is the continuation of the anterior tibial artery (Option C ruled out)
  • It runs alongside the deep peroneal (fibular) nerve on the dorsum of the foot (Option D ruled out)

 

Posterior tibial artery

  • Behind medial malleolus

questions.text: Which is not a component of biophysical scoring
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Fetal scalp pH

 

Explanation: The Biophysical Profile Score (BPS) includes:

  1. Fetal breathing movements (Option A)
  2. Fetal tone (Option C)
  3. Fetal movements
  4. Amniotic fluid volume
  5. Non-stress test (for fetal heart rate) (Option B)
    • Fetal scalp pH is an invasive test done intrapartum, not part of routine antenatal BPS.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with metastatic small intestinal neuroendocrine tumor presents with recurrent episodes of flushing, diarrhea, and wheezing. His 24-hour urinary 5-HIAA level is elevated. Which of the following drugs may help alleviate his symptoms by antagonizing serotonin receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cyproheptadine

Explanation:

  • This patient is showing classic features of carcinoid syndrome, which occurs when a neuroendocrine tumor (NET), especially of the small intestine, metastasizes to the liver and secretes large amounts of serotonin (5-HT) and other vasoactive substances directly into the systemic circulation.

Cyproheptadine is a 5-HT2 receptor antagonist that helps reduce serotonin-mediated symptoms in carcinoid syndrome such as diarrhea and flushing. It is particularly useful as bridging therapy before initiating long-term agents like octreotide.

Ondansetron (Option A): 5-HT3 receptor antagonist used for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. It does not alleviate serotonin-induced carcinoid symptoms like flushing or diarrhea.

Octreotide (Option C): A somatostatin analog and the definitive treatment for carcinoid syndrome. However, it requires time for initiation/titration, and cyproheptadine is often used in the interim to control acute symptoms.

Metoclopramide (Option D): A dopamine D2 antagonist with prokinetic and antiemetic properties. It has no significant antagonistic action at serotonin receptors relevant to carcinoid syndrome symptoms.

questions.text: Mortality reducing aldosterone antagonist drug in diabetic nephropathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Finerenone

Explanation:

  • Finerenone is a non-steroidal selective mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist (MRA) that has demonstrated cardiovascular and renal mortality reduction in diabetic nephropathy, particularly in patients with CKD and type 2 diabetes.
  • FIDELIO-DKD and FIGARO-DKD trials showed significant reductions in CKD progression, cardiovascular events, and mortality.
  • It blocks aldosterone-induced inflammation and fibrosis in the kidneys and heart without the hyperkalemia risk seen with older steroidal MRAs like spironolactone.
  • Especially useful in diabetic CKD patients already on ACEi/ARB, where aldosterone escape may still drive progression.
  • Finerenone reduces albuminuria, slows CKD progression, and lowers cardiovascular and renal mortality, making it a preferred MRA in diabetic nephropathy.

Empagliflozin (Option B): Though it reduces cardiovascular and renal outcomes (shown in EMPA-REG and EMPA-KIDNEY), it is not an aldosterone antagonist. It works by inhibiting SGLT2 in the proximal tubule to lower glucose and intraglomerular pressure.

Sitagliptin (Option C): A DPP-4 inhibitor used for glycemic control, but it has not been shown to reduce mortality or have nephroprotective aldosterone-blocking effects.

Telmisartan (Option D): An ARB that is useful in diabetic nephropathy, but it does not reduce mortality as an MRA and is not considered an aldosterone antagonist.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the image shown below:

choices.text: A: Teres major, B: Teres minor
A: Teres minor, B: Teres major
A: Latissimus dorsi, B: Teres major

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A: Teres major, B: Teres minor

Explanation:

  • The given image depicts the labelled structures as: A: Teres major, B: Teres minor.

 

Features

Teres Major

Teres Minor

Origin

Oval area on lower third lateral side of inferior angle of scapula

Upper two-thirds of the lateral border of the scapula

Insertion

Medial lip of bicipital groove

Inferior facet of the greater tubercle of the humerus

Action

Medial rotation, adduction, stablisation of shoulder

Lateral (external) rotation and stabilization of the shoulder joint

Nerve supply

Lower subscapular (posterior cord C5,6)

Axillary nerve (posterior cord C5, C6)

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with a soft, fluctuant swelling located along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle at the junction of the upper and middle thirds. The swelling is non-tender, transilluminates, and has no discharge. Which of the following is not correct about the swelling shown?

choices.text: Derived from cervical sinus of his

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Opens into pyriform fossa

Explanation:

  • A soft, fluctuant, non-tender swelling along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid in a 20-year-old male, as shown in the image, is suggestive of a Branchial Cyst, which does not open into the pyriform fossa—a feature typical of third or fourth branchial fistulas, not second branchial cleft cysts (cysts does not have any internal or external opening).

 

Branchial cyst

Definition
  • Incomplete obliteration of 2nd branchial cleft (fluid-filled cysts) (Option A ruled out)
  • Lined with squamous epithelium.
  • Filled with thick, cloudy fluid.

Appearance & Location
  • Typical Location: Front edge of the sternocleidomastoid muscle (where upper and middle thirds meet).
  • Onset: Early or middle adulthood.
  • Appearance: Soft, sometimes translucent swelling.

Complications
  • Infection: May cause redness, tenderness, and difficulty in distinguishing from other neck masses.
  • Age Consideration: In individuals over 35, rule out cancerous lymph nodes before surgical removal.

Treatment
  • Preferred Treatment: Complete removal, ideally when not infected.
  • Surgical Considerations: Cyst located above hypoglossal and glossopharyngeal nerves, but beneath the posterior belly of the digastric muscle. The spinal accessory nerve must also be identified to avoid damage.

Derived from cervical sinus of his (Option B): These cysts originate from the cervical sinus, a transient embryonic structure formed by the second to fourth branchial clefts.

Contains lymphoid tissue in wall (Option C): Histologically, second branchial cleft cysts often contain lymphoid aggregates, sometimes with germinal centers.

 

  • Incomplete obliteration of 2nd branchial cleft: Branchial cyst
  • Branchial fistula
    • External opening: Junction of upper 2/3rd and lower 1/3rd of SCM
    • Internal opening: Tonsillar fossa

questions.text: Which is correct about Na-K ATPase?

choices.text: Heterodimer with 3 alpha and 3 beta subunits
Heterodimer with 3 alpha and 2 beta subunits
Heterodimer with 2 alpha and 3 beta subunits
Homodimer with 3 alpha and 3 beta subunits

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Heterodimer with 3 alpha and 3 beta subunits

Explanation:

The Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase is a transmembrane enzyme essential for maintaining resting membrane potential and ion gradients, structurally organized as a heterodimer composed of 3 α-subunits, which have ATPase activity and ion-binding sites, and 3 β-subunits, which aid in membrane targeting and stability.

  • Structure: A heterodimer, consisting of: (Option A)
    • 3 α-subunits (each with ATPase activity and ion binding sites)
    • 3 β-subunits (involved in proper membrane targeting and stability)

Cytoplasmic side 3 alpha subunit

3 Na, ATP and phosphate

Extracellular side 3 beta subunits

2 K and ouabain
  • Function:
    • Transports 3 Na out of cells and 2 K into cells for each ATP utilised calling is coupling reaction of 3: 2
    • It is electrogenic pump and sends positive charge out of cells .

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant presents with progressive developmental delay, loss of motor milestones and difficulty feeding. On examination, the baby is hypotonic with poor eye contact. Per abdomen shows no organomegaly. Fundoscopy reveals a cherry-red spot on the macula. There is no hepatosplenomegaly. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hexosaminidase

Explanation:

  • Cherry-red spots on macula without hepatosplenomegaly are classic for Tay–Sachs disease.
  • Tay–Sachs disease is caused by hexosaminidase A deficiency.
  • Presents in infancy with neurodegeneration, hypotonia, loss of milestones, and cherry-red macula.
  • No hepatosplenomegaly helps rule out other similar storage disorders like Niemann–Pick.

Tay-Sachs Disease and Hexosaminidase A Deficiency

  • Tay–Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of hexosaminidase A, an enzyme responsible for degrading GM2 gangliosides.
  • Accumulation of GM2 gangliosides occurs predominantly in neurons, leading to progressive neurodegeneration.
  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive; common in Ashkenazi Jewish populations.
  • Clinical features:
    • Normal development initially, followed by progressive developmental delay, regression of milestones, and hypotonia.
    • The cherry-red spot on the macula is due to the contrast between the pale retina and preserved fovea.
    • No hepatosplenomegaly, unlike in some other lipid storage disorders.
    • May progress to blindness, seizures, and early death.

 

Disease

Enzyme Deficiency

Cherry-Red Spot

Hepatosplenomegaly

Other features

Tay-Sachs

Hexosaminidase A

Yes

No

Hyperacusis, Neuridegeneration

Niemann-Pick

Sphingomyelinase

Yes

Yes

Foam cells, ataxia

Gaucher

β-Galactocerebrosidase

No

Yes

Bone crises, lipid-laden macrophages

Krabbe

Galactocerebrosidase

No

No

Peripheral neuropathy, Optic atrophy

β-glucocerebrosidase (Option A):

  • Deficiency causes Gaucher disease, another lysosomal storage disorder.
  • Presents with hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and cytopenias.
  • Neurological symptoms are rare in Type 1 (most common form).
  • Cherry-red spot is not typical of Gaucher disease.

Sphingomyelinase (Option C):

  • Deficiency causes Niemann–Pick disease, particularly Types A and B.
  • Also presents with cherry-red macula, neurodegeneration, and hypotonia.
  • However, hepatosplenomegaly is prominent, which is absent in this case, helping rule it out.

Galactocerebrosidase (Option D):

  • Deficiency leads to Krabbe disease, a leukodystrophy affecting white matter.
  • Presents with severe neurodegeneration, stiffness, seizures, and optic atrophy, not cherry-red spots.
  • No cherry-red macula, and the clinical picture is distinct.

questions.text: 45-year-old alcoholic cirrhosis patient is admitted after melena episodes. Which of the following interventions will prevent GI bleeding risk in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D. Endoscopic variceal ligation.

Explanation:

In a patient with alcoholoc cirhhosis and malena, which is suggestive of variceal bleeding, the prevention of GI bleeding is by endoscopic variceal ligation.

TIPS (Option A) is for refractory ascites.

Octreotide (Option B) is for acute variceal bleeding

Low salt diet and spironolactone (Option C) is useful for ascites management, not to prevent GI bleed.

questions.text: Which of the following protein marked as X connects Z lines to M lines
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Titin

Explanation:

The protein marked as X, Titin, is the largest known human protein and serves a crucial structural role by connecting the Z lines to the M lines, thereby maintaining the organization and stability of the sarcomere.

  • Titin
    • Largest known protein
    • Connects Z lines to M lines
    • Povides elasticity
  • Dystrophin anchors thin filaments to beta dystroglycan and provides strength to muscle sarcolemma. (Option D ruled out)
    • Absent dystrophin in DMD and less or altered dystrophin in BMD
  • Lighter I band is divided by dark Z line and Darker A band is divided by lighter H line
    • Mnemonic: ZEBRA IN A HAT

  • H line is heavy and hollow and has no actin
  • A band remains the SAME

Desmin (Option A) is an intermediate filament that links adjacent myofibrils at the Z line, but does not connect Z to M lines.

Troponin (Option C) is a regulatory protein complex on actin filaments that controls muscle contraction in response to calcium, not involved in structural linkage.

questions.text: 6-month child is noted to have polyuria and failure to thrive. On assessment child is found to have severe hearing loss. Vitals Pulse: 80/min, BP 60/40 mm Hg with signs of dehydration. Work up shows metabolic alkalosis with hypokalemia. Diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Bartter syndrome

Explanation:

  • Key words are polyuria and dehydration indicating tubular disease of kidney. Barrter has a defect of Chloride channel in kidney that also is present in inner ear hair cells and explains SN hearing loss. Loss-of-function mutations in BSND, which encodes an essential beta subunit for chloride channels.
  • The defect in TAL explains the hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis.

Gitelman syndrome (Option B): Typically presents later in childhood/adolescence, has hypomagnesemia, and no hearing loss.

Conn syndrome (Option C)(Primary hyperaldosteronism): Causes hypertension, not hypotension; also rare in infants.

Dent disease (Option D): X-linked tubulopathy with low molecular weight proteinuria, hypercalciuria, and nephrocalcinosis, but no alkalosis or hearing loss.

questions.text: Sudden drop in ETCO2 during neurosurgery indicates
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Venous air embolism

Explanation:

  • Venous air embolism is a well-known complication during neurosurgical procedures, especially when the surgical site is above the level of the heart (e.g., in sitting craniotomy).

  • If air enters the venous circulation, it travels to the right heart and then to the pulmonary vasculature, causing a ventilation-perfusion mismatch, decreased pulmonary blood flow, and hence a sudden drop in ETCO₂.

  • This is often one of the earliest and most sensitive indicators of venous air embolism.

Trans-tentorial herniation of brain (Option A): is incorrect because while it can cause bradycardia, hypertension, and altered consciousness, it does not acutely reduce ETCO₂ unless accompanied by respiratory arrest, which is a late finding.

Pontine bleeding (Option C): is incorrect because it may lead to apnoea or irregular respiration, but again, it does not cause a sudden ETCO₂ drop as a primary sign during surgery.

Rupture of undetected AV malformation (Option D): is incorrect because it would lead to intracranial haemorrhage, possible rise in ICP, or haemodynamic instability, but not a sudden fall in ETCO₂ unless cardiac output drops significantly — which is not the most immediate effect.

questions.text: Farmer is brought to ER in unconscious state. Pulse rate is 140/min, RR= 20/min, pulse is thready with BP =70/50 mm Hg. Lungs are clear. Garlic odor is noted in breath. pH= 7.2, pCO2= 20 mm Hg, HCO3= 24 meq/L. RBC cholinesterase levels are normal. Which of the following is most likely cause of this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aluminum phosphide poisoning

Explanation:
Aluminum phosphide poisoning is most consistent with:

  • Garlic-like odour on breath: Characteristic of phosphine gas released after ingestion.
  • Profound hypotension with thready pulse.
  • Normal lungs on auscultation (as there is no fluid overload or pulmonary edema).
  • Metabolic acidosis (pH 7.2) with normal bicarbonate (24 mEq/L) and low pCO₂ (20 mmHg) suggests early metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation.
  • Normal RBC cholinesterase rules out OP poisoning.
  • Common in agricultural settings (i.e., farmers) due to use of aluminum phosphide as a fumigant.

 

Organophosphate poisoning (Option A):

  • It causes cholinergic symptoms (SLUDGE: salivation, lacrimation, urination, diarrhoea, GI upset, emesis), bronchorrhoea, and wheezing/crackles on auscultation (lungs not clear).
  • RBC cholinesterase would be low, not normal.
  • No garlic odour is typical.

Snake bite (Option C):

  • Might cause neurotoxic or hemotoxic features, local swelling, ptosis, or bleeding.
  • No garlic breath, and no characteristic metabolic acidosis like this.
  • Not usually associated with this ABG pattern.

Methyl alcohol poisoning (Option D):

  • Causes metabolic acidosis with high anion gap, with low HCO₃⁻, visual disturbances (“snowfield vision”), and CNS depression.
  • Garlic odour is not characteristic.
  • Bicarbonate level is normal here, making methanol unlikely.

questions.text: Glucose in kidney tubules is absorbed via SGLT located in PCT. Which of the following segments of PCT contributes to maximum absorption?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) S1

Explanation:

S1 segment of the PCT (Proximal Convoluted Tubule) is the early proximal tubule and is the primary site for glucose reabsorption, absorbing the majority of filtered glucose via SGLT2 transporters.

  • PCT contains brush border epithelium and is called the workhorse of the kidney
  • It is the site of absorption of the following
    • 100% glucose is absorbed via PCT
    • 90% via S1 segment of PCT via SGLT and 10% via S2 and S3 (Option A) (Option B, C ruled out)
    • 100% amino acids are reabsorbed via SGLT
    • 65% of total salt in ultrafiltrate is reabsorbed
    • Active secretion of NH3

S4 (Option D) is more involved in other solute and water reabsorption, not primary glucose uptake.

questions.text: JAK inhibitor used in Severe UC is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Tofacitinib

Explanation:

  • Among the given options, only Tofacitinib is the JAK inhibitor
  • Mechanism of action: Inhibits JAK 1 and JAK 3 → suppresses multiple pro- inflammatory cytokine signalling pathways.

Management of moderate to severe UC:

Vedolizumab (Option A): gut selective integrin inhibition

Ustekinumab (Option C): IL-12 antagonist

Ozanimod (Option D): S1P receptor modulator

questions.text: Which is not correct about serous cystadenoma of ovary?

choices.text: It is largest benign ovarian tumour

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) It is largest benign ovarian tumour

Explanation:

  • Serous cystadenomas are the most common epithelial ovarian tumors.
  • Cells are like fallopian tube
  • Unilocular
  • Malignant transformation occurs in ~ 40% (Option A)
    • Delicate papillary excrescences on surface and within the cyst: Benign
    • Coarse papillary excrescences: Malignant
  • 30–40% are bilateral. (Option B)
  • Psammoma bodies (concentric calcifications) may be seen. (Option C)

  • Type 1 serous tumors:
    • Serous borderline tumors and low-grade serous carcinoma
    • They are genetically stable and are characterized by KRAS and BRAF oncogene
  • Type 2 serous tumors:
    • Rapidly growing, highly aggressive neoplasms
  • The largest benign ovarian tumor is mucinous cystadenoma, which can grow up to 30–40 cm. (Option D)

questions.text: AIDS-Positive truck driver is admitted with fever and nuchal rigidity. Which of the following is the most rapid and sensitive test for detecting the polysaccharide capsular antigen of the pathogenic yeast Cryptococcus neoformans?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Latex agglutination test

Explanation:

  • The patient is AIDS-positive with fever and nuchal rigidity—strongly suggesting cryptococcal meningitis caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, an encapsulated yeast. The most rapid and sensitive test for detecting its capsular polysaccharide antigen is the Latex agglutination test.
    • It detects capsular antigen in CSF or serum, even when fungal load is low.
    • It is more sensitive and faster than traditional microscopy.

Mucicarmine stain (Option B): Stains the cryptococcal capsule red on tissue biopsy, useful in histopathology but not rapid or sensitive enough for CSF screening in acute meningitis.

India ink stain (Option C): Demonstrates a clear halo around the yeast in CSF, but sensitivity is low—especially in patients with low fungal load—making it less reliable as a standalone test.

Urease test (Option D): Cryptococcus neoformans is urease positive, but this test lacks specificity and is not suitable for rapid or confirmatory diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man admitted with a pulmonary embolism is started on intravenous Unfractionated heparin. His aPTT is being monitored regularly to adjust dosing. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of the drug being used?

choices.text: Directly inhibits Factor Xa and thrombin (Factor IIa)
Inhibits synthesis of vitamin K–dependent clotting factors in the liver
Binds to antithrombin III and enhances its activity against Factor IIa and Factor Xa
Selectively enhances antithrombin-mediated inhibition of Factor Xa only

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Binds to antithrombin III and enhances its activity against Factor IIa and Factor Xa

Explanation:

Unfractionated heparin (UFH) is a parenteral anticoagulant that exerts its effect by binding to antithrombin III (AT-III). This complex inactivates both Factor Xa and thrombin (Factor IIa). UFH has the ability to inhibit both factors equally due to its sufficient chain length.

  • Its anticoagulant effect is monitored using aPTT (activated partial thromboplastin time), especially in IV use for conditions like PE or DVT.
  • UFH’s rapid onset and short half-life make it suitable for hospitalized patients needing titrated anticoagulation, especially before invasive procedures or in renal impairment.

Directly inhibits Factor Xa and thrombin (Option A): This describes direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) like dabigatran (direct thrombin inhibitor) and rivaroxaban/apixaban (Factor Xa inhibitors). These are not used IV and don’t require aPTT monitoring.

Inhibits synthesis of vitamin K–dependent clotting factors (Option B): Refers to Warfarin, which acts in the liver to block factors II, VII, IX, and X by inhibiting vitamin K epoxide reductase. Warfarin has a slow onset, is orally administered, and not used for immediate anticoagulation.

Selectively enhances antithrombin-mediated inhibition of Factor Xa only (Option D): This describes low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) like enoxaparin, which preferentially inhibits Factor Xa. It is administered subcutaneously, has predictable pharmacokinetics, and does not typically require aPTT monitoring.

questions.text: 28-year-old lady presents with complaints of progressive dyspareunia and infertility. Bimanual examination reveals nodularity of utero-sacral ligaments and nodularity of pouch of Douglas with fixed retroverted uterus. Per speculum examination shows bluish spots on posterior fornix of vagina. Which of the following is the first differential diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Endometriosis

Explanation:

  • Endometriosis is suggested by:
    • Infertility
    • Progressive deep dyspareunia
    • Nodularity of uterosacral ligaments and pouch of Douglas
    • Fixed retroverted uterus
    • Bluish spots on posterior fornix (endometriotic implants)
       
  • Chronic PID (Option A): Also causes adhesions but lacks cyclical pain or endometriotic nodules.
  • Adenomyosis (Option C): Causes bulky tender uterus but no fornix nodules.
  • Endometrial cancer (Option D): Rare at this age, typically postmenopausal.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Rocuronium is correct?

choices.text: It is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker
It has a rapid onset and intermediate duration of action
It is primarily eliminated by renal excretion
It causes significant histamine release leading to hypotension

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It has a rapid onset and intermediate duration of action

Explanation:
Rocuronium is a non-depolarising neuromuscular blocking agent belonging to the aminosteroid group. It is characterised by:

  • Rapid onset of action (~1–2 minutes), making it suitable for rapid sequence intubation
  • Intermediate duration of action (~30–60 minutes)
  • Minimal cardiovascular effects and good safety profile

Its quick onset and predictable recovery profile make it a widely used alternative to succinylcholine when a non-depolarising agent is preferred.

It is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker (Option A): Rocuronium is a non-depolarising agent. Succinylcholine is the classic example of a depolarising neuromuscular blocker.

It is primarily eliminated by renal excretion (Option C): Rocuronium is primarily eliminated through hepatic metabolism and biliary excretion, not renal. It is relatively safe in renal impairment.

It causes significant histamine release leading to hypotension (Option D): Rocuronium has minimal histamine release and rarely causes hypotension. This makes it suitable for haemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: A patient with AIDS has been having a fever with cough and breathing difficulty for the past 10 days . CXR and sputum examination was performed. Which of the following is the correct diagnosis and intervention done for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lobar pneumonia, levofloxacin

Explanation:

  • Patient with fever, cough, and respiratory symptoms and imaging consistent with lobar consolidation.
  • The microscopic image shows Gram-positive cocci, typical of bacterial pneumonia.
  • Treated effectively with antibiotics such as levofloxacin.

Bacterial Lobar Pneumonia

Etiology:

  • Most commonly caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae (Gram-positive diplococci)
  • Can also be caused by Klebsiella, Haemophilus, etc.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Acute onset of:
    • High-grade fever
    • Productive cough with purulent or rust-colored sputum
    • Pleuritic chest pain
    • Dyspnea
  • Signs of consolidation: bronchial breath sounds, dullness to percussion, increased tactile fremitus

Imaging:

  • Chest X-ray shows lobar consolidation—homogeneous opacity involving a single lobe

Diagnosis:

  • Sputum Gram stain: shows Gram-positive cocci in pairs/chains
  • CBC: leukocytosis with left shift
  • Blood/sputum culture to identify pathogen

Treatment:

  • Empirical antibiotics such as levofloxacin or ceftriaxone + azithromycin
  • Supportive care includes oxygen, fluids, antipyretics

Histopathology, CXR, and Clinical Features

Feature

Pneumocystis jiroveci (PJP)

Bacterial Lobar Pneumonia

Pulmonary Tuberculosis (TB)

Histopathology

Foamy alveolar exudate with cysts (silver stain)

Dense neutrophilic infiltrate filling alveoli

Caseating granulomas with Langhans giant cells

Chest X-ray (CXR)

Bilateral diffuse ground-glass opacities

Unilateral lobar consolidation

Upper lobe cavitary lesions or miliary pattern

Clinical Features

Subacute dyspnea, dry cough, low-grade fever, hypoxia

Sudden onset fever, productive cough, pleuritic chest pain

Chronic cough, night sweats, weight loss, hemoptysis

 

Pneumocystis jiroveci, cotrimoxazole (Option A):

  • Requires special fungal stains (e.g., silver stain), not Gram stain
  • CXR shows diffuse bilateral ground-glass opacities, not lobar consolidation

Pulmonary TB, ATT (Option B):

  • TB presents with chronic symptoms: weight loss, night sweats, hemoptysis
  • CXR shows upper lobe cavitary lesions or miliary nodules

Aspergillosis, voriconazole (Option D):

  • Occurs in immunocompromised/neutropenic patients
  • CXR/CT shows nodules with halo/crescent signs, not lobar consolidation

questions.text: Which of the following statements about celiac disease is incorrect?

choices.text: Anti-IgA tissue transglutaminase (TTG) is a key diagnostic marker
Modified Marsh criteria is used for histological classification
Anti-IgG gliadin antibodies are highly specific for celiac disease
HLA-DQ6/DQ11 are genetic markers associated with the disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. HLA-DQ6/DQ11 are genetic markers associated with the disease

Explanation:

  • HLA-DQ6/DQ11 are not associated with the celiac disease.
  • HLA DQ2 and DQ8 haplotypes is necessary for developing Celiac disease.
