Options A, B, C are all true, and are seen in celiac disease.

questions.text: Biomarkers for Alzheimer disease
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) CSF Abeta 42/40

Explanation:

  • CSF Aβ42/40 ratio is a validated and reliable biomarker for early diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease (AD)
  • Aβ42 decreases in CSF due to deposition in amyloid plaques, while Aβ40 remains stable → thus, the ratio falls in AD

Alzheimer’s Disease- Biomarkers

Pathophysiology of AD:

  • Characterized by accumulation of:
    • Extracellular β-amyloid plaques (especially Aβ42)
    • Intracellular neurofibrillary tangles (hyperphosphorylated tau)
  • Leads to neuronal death, cognitive decline, memory loss

Core CSF Biomarkers in Alzheimer’s:

  • ↓ CSF Aβ42: Due to its deposition in plaques
  • Normal CSF Aβ40
  • → Therefore, ↓ Aβ42/40 ratio is more reliable than Aβ42 alone
  • ↑ CSF total tau (t-tau) and ↑ phosphorylated tau (p-tau): Indicate neuronal injury and tangle formation

Other diagnostic tools:

  • Amyloid PET scan: Detects β-amyloid plaques in brain
  • FDG-PET: Detects decreased glucose metabolism in parietal lobes
  • Structural MRI: Shows hippocampal atrophy

CSF Amyloid Beta (Option B):

  • Non-specific; Aβ alone without ratio lacks diagnostic accuracy
  • Aβ42/40 ratio is more sensitive and specific

CSF Amyloid beta 2 (Option C): Not a recognized biomarker for AD; possibly a distractor

CSF lactate levels (Option D): Elevated in mitochondrial disorders or CNS infections, not Alzheimer's

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the image shown?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Finkelstein test

Explanation:
The image shows a person with their thumb tucked inside a clenched fist, and the wrist is being ulnar-deviated — this manoeuvre is the Finkelstein test, used to diagnose De Quervain's tenosynovitis.

  • It tests for inflammation of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons.
  • Positive test: Pain over the radial styloid area on ulnar deviation.

Phalen test (Option B): This test is performed by flexing the wrists together for 60 seconds to provoke symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.

Froment sign (Option C): This test evaluates ulnar nerve palsy — the patient is asked to grip a paper between the thumb and index finger; flexion of the thumb's IP joint indicates adductor pollicis weakness.

Hand of benediction (Option D): This occurs in median nerve injury when attempting to make a fist - the index and middle fingers remain extended due to flexor paralysis. It is not a test, but a clinical sign.

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypertension patient presents with heaviness in chest with shortness of breath on climbing stairs. ECG done in ER is normal. He was admitted in your hospital last year with a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome and was discharged on oral medications with advice for monthly follow up which he did not follow. Which of the following investigations is best for diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) C.C.T.A (Coronary CT Angiography)

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with exertional chest discomfort and history of previous ACS, but has a normal ECG.
  • CCTA is a non-invasive test that can accurately evaluate coronary anatomy and plaque burden.
  • It is ideal for stable patients with intermediate pretest probability and no acute ECG or biomarker changes.

Role of CCTA in Stable Chest Pain Evaluation

  • In patients with stable angina symptoms and no acute ECG or troponin changes, the goal is to evaluate obstructive coronary artery disease.
  • Coronary CT Angiography (CCTA):
    • A non-invasive imaging modality with high sensitivity and negative predictive value.
    • Useful for detecting non-calcified and calcified plaques, stenoses, and coronary anomalies.
    • Recommended by guidelines as the first-line test in many patients with intermediate risk.
    • Can help guide further management: medical therapy vs. invasive testing.
  • Why CCTA fits this case:
    • The patient is stable, has a prior history of CAD, but no acute changes.
    • CCTA provides detailed coronary anatomy without immediate need for catheterization.
    • Avoids invasive procedure unless significant lesions are identified.
  • Other diagnostic tools (e.g., stress testing) may be used but have limitations in anatomical visualization.

Troponin I (Option A):

  • Indicates acute myocardial injury, elevated in MI or myocarditis.
  • In chronic exertional symptoms with normal ECG, troponin is typically not elevated.
  • Does not help evaluate stable ischemia or coronary anatomy.

Coronary angiography (Option C):

  • Invasive and best reserved when there's strong evidence of obstructive CAD, or if non-invasive testing is inconclusive or high-risk.
  • Not first-line in stable patients without high-risk ECG/troponin findings.
  • CCTA can safely triage patients before committing to invasive angiography.

Stress echocardiography (Option D):

  • Functional test to assess inducible ischemia.
  • Less informative about anatomical details or plaque morphology.
  • CCTA provides direct anatomical visualization, making it more suitable for decision-making in this stable patient.

questions.text: Transillumination test is p ositive in this neck swelling in a child. Diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cystic hygroma

Explanation:

  • The clinical image shows a large, soft, fluctuant swelling in the lateral neck of a child.
  • The positive transillumination test confirms the cystic nature of the lesion.
  • These findings are classic for a cystic hygroma, a congenital lymphatic malformation.

Cystic Hygroma (Macrocystic Lymphangioma)

Definition:

  • A cystic hygroma is a macrocystic lymphatic malformation formed by congenital sequestration of lymphatic tissue that fails to communicate with the central lymphatic system.

Epidemiology and Sites:

  • Most commonly presents in infancy or early childhood.
  • Predominant site: posterior triangle of the neck (lateral neck region).
  • Other possible locations: axilla, mediastinum, groin, and retroperitoneum.

Clinical Features:

  • Soft, painless, fluctuant swelling.
  • Brilliantly transilluminant due to clear lymphatic fluid content.
  • May increase in size during respiratory infections or crying.
  • Can cause airway obstruction or dysphagia if large.

Associated Conditions:

  • Commonly associated with chromosomal abnormalities:
    • Turner syndrome
    • Down syndrome
    • Noonan syndrome

Diagnosis:

  • Ultrasound: Initial investigation to determine cystic nature.
  • MRI: Detailed anatomical mapping and preoperative planning.
  • Prenatal detection: Can be seen on antenatal ultrasound as large cystic mass.

Management:

  • Observation: Small, asymptomatic lesions.
  • Sclerotherapy: Preferred non-invasive treatment (agents like OK-432 or bleomycin).
  • Surgical excision: Reserved for large or recurrent lesions, or if sclerotherapy fails.

Ranula (Option A):

  • A mucous retention cyst of the sublingual gland, occurring in the floor of the mouth.
  • May transilluminate but does not present in the lateral neck.

Epididymal cyst (Option C):

  • Arises from the epididymis in the scrotal region, not the neck.
  • Irrelevant in this anatomical context.

Potato tumor (Option D):

  • Non-standard historical term sometimes used for retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Presents with fever, drooling, dysphagia, and does not transilluminate.
  • Appears as a deep neck space infection, not a cystic lesion.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida at 24 weeks of gestation presents with multiple soft, cauliflower-like lesions on her vulva. She is diagnosed with condyloma acuminata. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Trichloroacetic acid application

Explanation:

Trichloroacetic acid (TCA) is the treatment of choice for condyloma acuminata in pregnancy because it is:

  • Safe for use during pregnancy due to minimal systemic absorption
  • Topically applied, destroying warts by chemical coagulation of proteins
  • Effective on external genital warts, especially when bulky or symptomatic
  • Its non-teratogenic nature and lack of systemic toxicity make it ideal during pregnancy.

Imiquimod cream (Option A): This is an immune response modifier but is not recommended during pregnancy due to insufficient safety data and potential systemic absorption through the skin.

Podophyllin resin (Option B): Contraindicated in pregnancy. It is teratogenic and cytotoxic, interfering with mitosis, and poses a significant risk of systemic toxicity when applied to mucous membranes or large surface areas.

Oral interferon therapy (Option D): Not routinely used for genital warts. It has limited efficacy, high cost, and no established safety or benefit for treating condyloma acuminata during pregnancy.

questions.text: Which is correct about paraphilia by name of Pygmalionism?

choices.text: Sexual arousal on giving physical pain
Sexual arousal on seeing others indulging in sexual activity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Falling in love with toy

Explanation:

  • Also called Agalmatophilia, it refers to sexual or romantic attraction to statues, dolls, mannequins, or inanimate representations of the human form.
  • Named after Pygmalion, a figure from Greek mythology who fell in love with a statue he had carved.
  • In modern contexts, this can extend to toys, robots, or life-like artificial figures.

Sexual arousal on giving physical pain (Option A): This is called Sadism, a type of sexual sadomasochism.

Sexual arousal on seeing others indulging in sexual activity (Option B): This is known as Troilism.

Sexual arousal with excreta (Option C): This is called Coprophilia (faeces) or Urophilia (urine).

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with seizures, irritability, and developmental delay. Blood glucose is normal, but CSF glucose is markedly low. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) GLUT 1 deficiency

Explanation:

A 6-month-old infant presenting with seizures, irritability, and developmental delay, along with normal blood glucose but markedly low CSF glucose, is diagnosed with GLUT1 Deficiency.

  • Normal blood glucose + Low CSF glucose = impaired glucose transport → Think GLUT1 deficiency.

Glucose 6 phosphatase deficiency (Von Gierke disease) (Option A): Presents as: Hypoglycemia + Lactic acidosis + Hepatomegaly, but not with isolated low CSF glucose.

Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency (Option B) causes hemolytic anemia, especially under oxidative stress — no neurological signs or low CSF glucose.

Phosphofructokinase deficiency (Glycogen Storage Disease Type VII) (Option D) involves muscle weakness and exercise intolerance, not CNS symptoms or altered CSF glucose.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Von Gierke disease?

choices.text: Crumpled tissue paper appearance of cytoplasm on Bone marrow study

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Crumpled tissue paper appearance of cytoplasm on Bone marrow study

Explanation:

  • Von Gierke disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I) is caused by a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase, which disrupts the conversion of glycogen to glucose during fasting, while the crumpled tissue paper appearance of cytoplasm—seen in bone marrow macrophages due to glucocerebroside accumulation—is characteristic of Gaucher disease, not Von Gierke.

Von Gierke's Disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I)

Cause

Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme

Pathophysiology

Inability to convert glucose-6-phosphate to glucose; leads to accumulation of glycogen, lactate, and triglycerides

Symptoms
  • Severe fasting hypoglycemia (Option B ruled out)
  • Hepatomegaly and Renomegaly
  • Growth retardation
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperlipidemia (Option B ruled out)
  • Doll-like facies (Option C ruled out)

Diagnosis
  • Biochemical tests (hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia)
  • Genetic testing

Management
  • Frequent feedings with slow-release carbohydrates
  • Blood glucose monitoring
  • Medications for associated conditions
  • Liver transplantation (in severe cases)


Renal enlargement (Option A): Due to glycogen accumulation in the kidneys.

questions.text: All are correct about Intrauterine Devices except?

choices.text: The most widely used reversible method
The most common side effect is managed with ferrous sulfate
LNG IUD is used for 5 years
CuT 380 Ag inhibits ovulation to prevent contraception

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) CuT 380 Ag inhibits ovulation to prevent contraception

 

Explanation:

CuT 380 Ag (a copper IUD) does not inhibit ovulation. Instead, it creates a local inflammatory reaction in the endometrium, which is toxic to sperm and ova, preventing fertilization and implantation. Ovulation continues normally.

 

The most widely used reversible method (Option A): IUDs, along with implants, are considered Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptives (LARCs) and are among the most effective forms of reversible birth control. They are highly popular globally due to their effectiveness and convenience.

 

The most common side effect is managed with ferrous sulphate (Option B): The most common side effect of copper IUDs is menorrhagia (heavy menstrual bleeding), which can lead to iron-deficiency anaemia. Ferrous sulfate (oral iron) is often prescribed to manage this.

 

LNG IUD is used for 5 years (Option C): Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine devices (like Mirena) are effective for up to 5 years, although newer evidence suggests they may be effective longer.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with pain in the scrotum. On examination the testis is swollen and erythema over scrotal skin is noted. Inguinal lymph nodes are not palpable. Elevation of testis reduces the pain in this patient. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Epididymitis

Explanation:

  • The key diagnostic clue is that elevation of the testis relieves pain, known as Prehn’s sign, which is typically positive in epididymitis.
  • The absence of inguinal lymphadenopathy also supports this diagnosis and helps rule out other differentials.

Epididymitis

Definition:

  • Inflammation of the epididymis, commonly due to bacterial infection.

Etiology:

  • Sexually active men (<35 years): Chlamydia trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrhoeae
  • Men >35 years or children: Escherichia coli, urinary tract pathogens
  • Chronic cases: May be due to tuberculosis or non-infectious causes

Clinical Features:

  • Gradual onset of pain and swelling in the scrotum
  • Scrotal erythema, warmth, and tenderness
  • Positive Prehn’s sign: Relief of pain on scrotal elevation
  • Fever and dysuria may be present
  • Testicle is not high-riding or transversely oriented

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical examination is usually diagnostic
  • Urinalysis and urine culture to identify infection
  • Doppler ultrasound shows increased blood flow (hyperemia) to the epididymis

Management:

  • Empirical antibiotics (e.g., doxycycline + ceftriaxone)
  • Scrotal elevation and support, NSAIDs
  • Treat sexual partners if STD is confirmed

Torsion testis (Option B):

  • Presents with sudden severe pain, often with a high-riding testis and absent cremasteric reflex.
  • Prehn’s sign is negative — lifting the testis does not relieve pain.
  • Surgical emergency.

Lymphogranuloma venereum (Option C):

  • Sexually transmitted infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (L1-L3 serovars).
  • Characterized by painless genital ulcer followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo).
  • Scrotal swelling is not an early feature.

Testicular cancer (Option D):

  • Usually presents as a painless, hard testicular mass.
  • May have a dull ache, but not acute inflammatory signs.
  • Does not improve with elevation and is non-tender.
  • Diagnosis confirmed with ultrasound and tumor markers (AFP, β-hCG, LDH).

questions.text: 30-year-old primigravida is having Hb= 9 gm% in second trimester with MCV of 110fl. What is next best step?

choices.text: Give Blood transfusion 2 units and then put on oral iron for remaining weeks
Start Folic acid and B12 tablets
Give oral iron only and monitor Hb after 4 weeks

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Start Folic acid and B12 tablets

Macrocytic anemia (MCV of 110f) is most commonly caused by deficiencies in Folic acid or Vitamin B12. Both of these are crucial for DNA synthesis, and a deficiency impairs red blood cell maturation, leading to large, immature red blood cells. The most appropriate first step is to

start supplementation with both to address the most likely cause of her anemia.

Start parenteral iron supplementation (Option A): Iron deficiency anemia is typically microcytic (low MCV). Since the patient's MCV is high (110 fL), her anemia is macrocytic, not due to iron deficiency. Therefore, giving iron supplementation (oral or parenteral) is not the correct first step and would not address the underlying cause.

Give Blood transfusion 2 units and then put on oral iron for remaining weeks (Option B): A blood transfusion is reserved for severe symptomatic anemia or cases where the patient's condition is unstable. An Hb of 9 gm% in the second trimester, while anemic, is not typically severe enough to warrant a transfusion unless the patient has severe symptoms like heart failure or is close to delivery. The anemia is macrocytic, not microcytic, so iron supplementation will not correct it.

Give oral iron only and monitor Hb after 4 weeks (Option D): The anemia is macrocytic, not microcytic, so iron supplementation will not correct it. Waiting four weeks on an incorrect treatment could also worsen her condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about molding?

choices.text: Occurs in normal delivery due to compression of engaging diameter of head
Occurs due to stagnation of fluid in layers of scalp below girdle of contact
Occurs in cephalopelvic disproportion and changes the bimastoid diameter of fetal skull

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Occurs in normal delivery due to compression of engaging diameter of head

Explanation:

  • Molding refers to the overlapping of fetal skull bones, especially at the sutures, due to compressive forces during labor, enabling the fetal head to adapt to the maternal pelvis.
  • It is a normal physiological process and helps in the progression of labor.
  • Crossing of suture lines occurs in caput succedaneum, not molding. (Option A)
  • Fluid accumulation under the scalp layers is characteristic of caput or cephalohematoma, not molding. (Option C)
  • Bimastoid diameter is not primarily altered during molding; suboccipitobregmatic diameter changes are more relevant in cephalic presentation (Option D).

questions.text: Which is correct about superfecundation?

choices.text: Fertilization of second or more ova in same menstrual cycle
Fertilization of second or more ova in different menstrual cycle
Age of fetus is different by 1-3 months

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Fertilization of second or more ova in same menstrual cycle 

Explanation:

  • Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two or more ova released during the same menstrual cycle by sperm from separate acts of sexual intercourse, which may involve the same or different fathers. (Option A)

  • Superfetation: Fertilization of an ovum from a different cycle, i.e., after a previous conception- extremely rare in humans (Option B)

  • Age difference by 1–3 months (Option C) is not true for superfecundation; twins born are still of the same gestational age.

  • Always occurs in septate uterus (Option D): There’s no anatomical requirement like a septate uterus for superfecundation to occur.

questions.text: The following transducer recordings are obtained in physiology lab for arterial waveforms during the cardiac cycle Which of the following is correct about the marked arrow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dicrotic notch

Explanation:

The marked arrow in the Arterial Waveform corresponds to the Dicrotic Notch, which represents the brief rise in arterial pressure caused by the closure of the aortic valve at the end of systole.

  • A small downward deflection or notch in the arterial pressure waveform occurring just after the systolic peak (marks the beginning of diastole).
  • Represents the closure of the aortic valve at the end of ventricular systole.
  • Physiological significance:
    • Marks the beginning of diastole.
    • Indicates transient backflow of blood hitting the closed valve, causing a brief rise in pressure.
  • Clinical relevance:
    • Presence confirms proper aortic valve function.
    • Alterations may indicate valvular or arterial pathology.

C wave (Option A): Small upward deflection in the jugular venous pulse, not arterial waveform.

V wave (Option B): Reflects venous filling in atrial pressure tracing, not seen in arterial pressure waveform.

Percussion wave (Option D): The initial systolic upstroke, not the notch after systole.

questions.text: A 26-year-old lady with metallic prosthetic mitral valve is getting married next month. She is visiting your clinic with her fiancé today and seeks advise about tablets of anticoagulant she is using as they plan to start a family as early as possible. The strip of tablets she shows you from her purse is warfarin at dose of 0.5 mg per day. What is correct advice you would give her?

choices.text: Continue warfarin and use barrier method
Continue warfarin and use Progestin only pills

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Discontinue warfarin and start LMWH

Explanation: Since warfarin has a significant risk of severe birth defects and other complications if administered during the first trimester and hence is replaced with LMWH which does not cross the placenta, making it safe for the fetus.

Continue warfarin and use the barrier method (Option B): Since the subject wants to start a family, continuing a contraceptive method contradicts her wishes. Second, and more importantly, barrier methods can fail. If she were to become pregnant while on warfarin, the fetus would be at a significant risk of severe birth defects and other complications. And thus not prescribed.

Continue warfarin and use Progestin only pills (Option C): Since the subject wants to start a family, continuing a contraceptive method contradicts her wishes. More critically, continuing warfarin exposes any potential pregnancy to a high risk of teratogenicity.

Discontinue warfarin and start digoxin (Option D): Digoxin is a medication used to treat heart failure and control heart rate in conditions like atrial fibrillation. It is not an anticoagulant. Stopping warfarin and starting digoxin would leave her completely unprotected from the risk of blood clots forming on her prosthetic valve, putting her at a very high risk of a life-threatening stroke or acute valve thrombosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of recurrent pulsatile headaches associated with photophobia and occasional vomiting. These headaches occur 6–8 times per month and often interfere with her ability to work. Which of the following medication is used once a month for prevention of such attacks
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fremanezumab

Explanation:

  • Fremanezumab is a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) monoclonal antibody that targets CGRP, a neuropeptide involved in migraine pathophysiology.
    It is given as a subcutaneous injection once a month or quarterly for the preventive treatment of chronic or episodic migraine.
  • It is especially useful in patients who have frequent attacks and require long-term prophylaxis.
  • CGRP monoclonal antibodies like Fremanezumab, Galcanezumab, and Erenumab are revolutionizing migraine prevention, particularly in patients with frequent or refractory attacks.
  • Sumatriptan and Rizatriptan are acute abortive agents used during an attack, not for prevention. (Option A and B ruled out)
  • Atogepant is a CGRP receptor antagonist, but it's given as a once-daily oral tablet, not monthly. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about action of renin

choices.text: Conversion of Angiotensinogen to Angiotensin I in plasma
Conversion of Angiotensin I to Angiotensin II in pulmonary endothelium
Conversion of angiotensin I to Angiotensinogen in plasma
Conversion of Angiotensin II to Angiotensin I in pulmonary endothelium

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Conversion of Angiotensinogen to Angiotensin I in plasma

Explanation:

  • Renin is an enzyme secreted by the juxtaglomerular cells of the kidney that converts angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) into angiotensin I in the bloodstream (plasma).

Component

Produced by

Location of action

Renin

Juxtaglomerular (JG) cells of kidney

Secreted into circulating blood

Angiotensinogen

Liver

Circulates in plasma

Conversion site

Bloodstream (Systemic circulation)

Renin acts on angiotensinogen in plasma

Conversion of Angiotensin I to Angiotensin II in pulmonary endothelium (Option B) is carried out by ACE, not renin.

Conversion of angiotensin I to Angiotensinogen in plasma (Option C): Angiotensinogen is the precursor, not a product of angiotensin I.

Conversion of Angiotensin II to Angiotensin I in pulmonary endothelium (Option D): Angiotensin II is the active product and is not converted back to angiotensin I.

questions.text: A 30-year-old veterinarian presents with fever, night sweats, and arthralgia. Blood cultures are sent. Which of the following media is most appropriate for the isolation of Brucella species?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B)

Explanation:

  • Castaneda’s Medium is a biphasic medium containing both solid (agar) and liquid (broth) phases.
  • It is ideal for isolating Brucella species from blood, especially in cases of brucellosis, as it allows continuous culture without subculturing (minimizing lab-acquired infection risk).
  • Useful in chronic infections where Brucella may be present in low numbers.

Lowenstein-Jensen Medium (Option A): Used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis, not for Brucella.

Egg Yolk Agar / Milk Agar (Option C): Used for Clostridium perfringens (lecithinase activity) or Listeria growth, not appropriate for Brucella.

TCBS Agar (Option D): Selective for Vibrio species, especially Vibrio cholerae and V. parahaemolyticus, not for Brucella.

questions.text: 16-year-old girl using soft contact lenses went for swimming lessons without removing contact lens. After few days he is having pain in both eyes with corneal ring infiltrates and radial kerato-neuritis. Which is best management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Poly-hexamethylene biguanide eye drops

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario strongly suggests Acanthamoeba keratitis, a protozoal infection of the cornea.
  • Key clues:
    • History of contact lens use during swimming
    • Severe pain out of proportion to findings
    • Corneal ring infiltrate
    • Radial keratoneuritis (inflammation of corneal nerves)
  • PHMB is a topical anti-amoebic agent and the first-line treatment for Acanthamoeba keratitis.
  • It is used along with chlorhexidine or propamidine isethionate in many protocols.

Change to hard contact lens (Option A):

  • Changing lens type does not treat infection.
  • In fact, all contact lens use should be discontinued immediately during active infection.

Penetrating keratoplasty (Option B):

  • Though it may be required in advanced or unresponsive cases, it is not first-line treatment.
  • Early medical therapy with anti-amoebic agents is essential and often effective.

Riboflavin eye drops (Option C): Riboflavin is used in corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL) for keratoconus, not for infectious keratitis.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions in a pregnant lady will have least risk of maternal mortality?

choices.text: Mitral stenosis with Dyspnoea grade IV

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Bioprosthetic valve

Explanation:

  • Bioprosthetic heart valves are less thrombogenic and do not require long-term anticoagulation, making them safer in pregnancy compared to mechanical valves or other severe cardiac lesions.
  • Coarctation of aorta (Option A): High risk of aortic rupture.
  • Severe mitral stenosis (Option B): Increases pulmonary congestion risk during pregnancy.
  • Fallot's tetralogy (uncorrected) (Option C): Cyanosis and hypoxemia increase risk.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the Nitabuch layer?

choices.text: Limits invasion of decidua by trophoblast
Helps in facilitated diffusion of glucose
Formed due to ageing of fetal components

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Nitabuch layer is a zone of fibrinoid degeneration in the decidua basalis that limits the depth of trophoblastic invasion during placental implantation.
  • This layer forms a physiological barrier that prevents excessive invasion into maternal tissues, and its absence or deficiency is associated with placenta accreta spectrum disorders.

  • Facilitated diffusion of glucose is mediated by GLUT transporters in the syncytiotrophoblast, not via the Nitabuch layer. (Option B)
  • Hofbauer cells are fetal macrophages present within chorionic villi, not within the Nitabuch layer. (Option C)
  • The Nitabuch layer is not related to ageing of fetal components; it forms during early implantation. (Option D)

questions.text: A 60-year-old women with T2DM and Hypertension has presented with ulcer on vulva of 3 cm that she has been neglecting for last 4 months. Because of bad smell from ulcer and groin swelling she has come to your tertiary care hospital. You have advised biopsy which shows is to be Squamous cell cancer. MRI pelvis shows enlarged inguinofemoral nodes with extension of growth to lower 1/3 vagina. According to FIGO staging of carcinoma of vulva she is stage?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) III

Explanation:

  • Stage III involves inguinofemoral lymph node metastasis
  • According to FIGO staging for vulvar carcinoma:
  • Stage I Limited to the vulva
    • Ia: Tumor ≤ 2 cm, stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm
    • Ib: Tumor > 2 cm, stromal invasion > 1 mm
  • Stage II Any size tumor involving:
    • Lower 1⁄3 vagina
    • Lower 1⁄3 urethra
    • Anus
  • Stage III Any size tumor with or without extension to adjacent perineal structures (⅓ lower urethra, 1/3 lower vagina, anus) with positive inguinofemoral lymph nodes
    • IIIa: With 1 lymph node metastasis (≥5 mm) or With 1–2 lymph node metastasis(es) (<5 mm)
    • IIIb: With 2 or more lymph nodes metastases (≥5 mm) or 3 or more lymph nodes metastases (<5 mm)
    • IIIc: Regional LN with extra capsular spread
  • Stage IV Tumor invades other regional (2/3 upper urethra, 2/3 upper vagina), or distant structures
    • IVa: Growth fixed to pelvic bone or ulcerated pelvic LN
    • IVb: Distant metastasis

questions.text: Patient with cerebral toxoplasmosis is admitted for treatment. Lab shows Na-125 meq/L, K 5.0 meq/L. Which of the following findings will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Dry sticky mucous membranes with increased thirst
Tachycardia and orthostatic hypotension with bounding pulse
Confusion, headache and risk of seizure
Peripheral and pulmonary edema with distended neck veins

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Confusion, headache and risk of seizure

Explanation:

  • The patient has Na+ = 125 mEq/L, which is moderate hyponatremia. K+ is normal, so it’s not a volume loss issue- Patient is having euvolemic hyponatremia. Low sodium increases risk of seizures with confusion and headache (Option C)
  • Dry sticky mucous membranes with increased thirst (Option A): Seen in hypernatremia, not hyponatremia.
  • Tachycardia and orthostatic hypotension with bounding pulse (Option B): Seen in hypovolemia, not euvolemia.
  • Peripheral and pulmonary edema with distended neck veins (Option D): Suggests hypervolemic hyponatremia (e.g. in CHF, cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome), not SIADH.

questions.text: Which among the following is the first investigation recommended for diagnosing pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Urinary total Metanephrines

Explanation:

  • For diagnosis of pheochromocytoma biochemical evidence is proven with Urinary Metanephrine levels and plasma metanephrine values.
  • Then imaging is done like PET/CT or MRI.

  • Fractionated metanephrines
  • Total metanephrines

Plasma catecholamines (Option A): Less sensitive, not preferred as first-line test. Can fluctuate with stress and other conditions.

USG whole abdomen (Option C): Not the first step. Imaging is done after biochemical confirmation of pheochromocytoma.

Urinary vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) (Option D): Lower sensitivity

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is a key regulator phosphate metabolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) FGF-23

Explanation:

Among the given options, FGF-23 (Fibroblast Growth Factor 23) is the key regulator of phosphate metabolism, primarily acting to lower serum phosphate.

  • Produced by osteocytes and osteoblasts in bone and has phosphaturic action.
  • Function: Maintain phosphate homeostasis and prevent hyperphosphatemia.
    • Reduces serum phosphate levels by increasing renal phosphate excretion.
    • Inhibits 1α-hydroxylase in the kidney, decreasing active vitamin D (calcitriol) production.
    • Lower calcitriol reduces intestinal phosphate absorption.

 

PTH (Option A) also promotes phosphate excretion, but its primary role is calcium regulation.

Calcitonin (Option B): Minimal effect on phosphate metabolism.

Vitamin D3 (Option C): Increases phosphate absorption, but not the main regulatory hormone.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient presents with early satiety, fatigue and enlarged lymph nodes. Physical examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Hb is 8 gm%, TLC is 25,000 cells/cu mm and absolute lymphocyte count of 8,000/mm³. Peripheral smear is show below. Which of the following is best test for confirmation of diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Flow cytometry on peripheral blood

Explanation:

  • Elderly patient with fatigue, early satiety, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly
  • Lab findings:
    TLC = 25,000/µL, ALC = 8,000/µL (suggests lymphocytosis)
    • Hemoglobin = 8 g/dL (anemia)
    • Peripheral smear: Shows smudge cells — classic for CLL.
    • IOC is Peripheral blood flow cytometry (Option A)

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady was diagnosed as having severe pre-eclampsia and was started on Pritchard regimen. Which of the following is not useful for determining magnesium toxicity?

choices.text: Loss of Ankle and knee jerks bilaterally
Severe respiratory depression with elevated pCO2
Urine output charting showing output of 60 ml per hour

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Urine output charting showing output of 60 ml per hour

Explanation:

  • Magnesium toxicity is monitored using clinical signs:
    • Loss of deep tendon reflexes (early warning) (Option A)
    • Respiratory depression (Option B)
    • Bradycardia or ECG changes (Option C)
  • Urine output <30 ml/hr is a red flag because magnesium is excreted renally.
  • However, 60 ml/hr is normal and not a sign of toxicity.

questions.text: Young lady comes with complaints of difficulty in swallowing food, skin tightening of fingers and finger-tip discoloration on putting hands in cold water. Face shows telangiectasias. Work up show ANA positive and following IF pattern is present. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Systemic sclerosis- centromere pattern

Explanation:

The patient’s clinical features strongly point to limited systemic sclerosis (CREST subtype):

  • C – Calcinosis cutis (not mentioned, but may be present)
  • R – Raynaud’s phenomenon (finger-tip discoloration in cold)
  • E – Esophageal dysmotility (dysphagia)
  • S – Sclerodactyly (tight skin over fingers)
  • T – Telangiectasias

ANA testing reveals a centromere pattern, which is highly specific for CREST syndrome.

  • Centromere pattern: Discrete speckles seen in nucleus (specific for limited scleroderma)
  • It correlates with anti-centromere antibodies, seen in up to 90% of patients with CREST

Pattern

Common Autoantibodies

Diseases/Associations

Speckled

Anti-Sm, Anti-RNP, SSA/Ro, SSB/La

SLE, Sjögren syndrome, Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD), Systemic sclerosis

Homogeneous

Anti-dsDNA, Anti-histone

SLE (especially with anti-dsDNA), Drug-induced lupus

Mixed

Varies

Seen in overlap syndromes and mixed connective tissue diseases

Nucleolar

Anti-PM/Scl, Anti-RNA polymerase

Diffuse systemic sclerosis, polymyositis-scleroderma overlap

Centromere

Anti-centromere

Limited systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome)

Peripheral

Anti-dsDNA

SLE (highly specific), especially with lupus nephritis

SLE (Peripheral pattern) (Option A): Typically associated with anti-dsDNA; not fitting this clinical picture.

Speckled pattern (Option B): Seen in diffuse systemic sclerosis, SLE, and Sjögren; but not specific.

Sjögren syndrome (Nucleolar pattern) (Option D): Also seen in scleroderma, but clinical features here are not suggestive of Sjögren (e.g., no dry eyes/mouth).

questions.text: Which of the following is called a countercurrent exchanger?

choices.text: Thin descending limb of Loop of Henle
Thick ascending limb of Loop of Henle

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Vasa recta

Explanation:

  • Vasa recta is called a Countercurrent Exchanger
 

Countercurrent Multiplier

Countercurrent Exchanger EV

Function

Creates the medullary concentration gradient.

Maintains the medullary concentration gradient

Mechanism

Active transport of Na⁺, Cl⁻ (no water) → sets up osmotic gradient

Passive exchange of solutes and water via diffusion

Energy use

Requires ATP (active transport)

No ATP (passive process)

Purpose

Concentrates medullary interstitium

Prevents "washout" of medullary gradient

Main structure

Loop of Henle (especially thick ascending limb) (Option A, B ruled out)

Vasa recta (capillaries of juxtamedullary nephrons) (Option D)


Collecting tubule and duct (Option D) are involved in final urine concentration (under ADH control), not part of countercurrent system.

questions.text: Distance by which two touch stimuli should be separated to be perceived as two different stimuli is greatest on
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Back of scapula

Explanation:

  • Two-point discrimination threshold is inversely proportional to tactile receptor density
  • The back of the scapula has low density of touch receptors → requires greater separation to perceive two stimuli

Two-Point Discrimination

Definition:

  • The minimum distance at which two tactile stimuli are perceived as distinct
  • Reflects the spatial resolution of the skin's sensory receptors

Neuroanatomy:

  • Depends on density of mechanoreceptors (e.g., Merkel cells, Meissner corpuscles)
  • Also influenced by size of receptive fields and cortical representation in the somatosensory cortex

Areas with Low Threshold (High Sensitivity):

  • Fingertips, lips, and tongue have high tactile acuity → lower two-point threshold
  • Back, scapular region, and thighs have poor tactile acuity → higher threshold

Clinical Use:

  • Part of neurological examination to assess posterior column (dorsal column) integrity

Lips (Option A):

  • Very high receptor density → low threshold for two-point discrimination

Fingertips (Option C):

  • Highest tactile acuity in the body; can discriminate two points at 2–4 mm apart

Tongue (Option D):

  • Also has high tactile resolution, especially on the anterior part

questions.text: Alcoholic presents with palpitations and dizziness. On examination pulse is fast and rhythm is irregularly irregular with bilateral crepitations in bilateral lung fields and elevated BNP. Pulse 130 min with BP 100/80 mm Hg. What is the DOC for rate control?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Digoxin

Explanation:

In this clinical scenario, the patient is an alcoholic presenting with:

  • Palpitations and dizziness
  • Irregularly irregular pulse → likely atrial fibrillation
  • Tachycardia (HR 130/min)
  • Bilateral lung crepitations → suggestive of heart failure
  • Elevated BNP → supports heart failure
  • Low-normal BP (100/80 mmHg)

 

The patient likely has acute atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response in the setting of decompensated heart failure. Hence the goal is to control the ventricular rate without worsening hypotension or heart failure. Digoxin is the best candidate for this.

  • Its is a Positive inotrope and AV nodal blocker.
  • It is preferred in atrial fibrillation with heart failure, especially when BP is low and beta-blockers/CCBs are contraindicated.
  • It works well in sedentary patients (less effective during exercise).
     

Esmolol (Option A): It is a beta-blocker, useful in AF, but can worsen heart failure (especially acute decompensated) and lower BP further. It is not preferred in acute decompensated heart failure.

Diltiazem (Option B): It is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker; effective for rate control. But also has negative inotropic effects and may worsen LV dysfunction, and drop BP.

Clevidipine (Option D): This is a dihydropyridine CCB used to lower BP in hypertensive emergencies. It causes arteriolar vasodilation, which leads to- ↓ Afterload and Possible reflex tachycardia (due to sympathetic activation). It has no role in rate control of atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: Which of the following is best for reducing transfusion dependency in beta thalassemia patient who is having serum ferritin of 1500 ng/ml and increased transferrin saturation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Luspatercept

Explanation:

  • Luspatercept is approved for reducing transfusion burden in beta-thalassemia patients.
  • It enhances late-stage erythroid maturation, improving hemoglobin levels.
  • It directly addresses ineffective erythropoiesis, not just iron overload.

Luspatercept and Beta-Thalassemia Management

  • Beta-thalassemia is caused by defective synthesis of beta-globin chains, leading to ineffective erythropoiesis and chronic anemia.
  • Management typically involves regular red blood cell transfusions, which over time cause iron overload (elevated serum ferritin and transferrin saturation).
  • Luspatercept:
    • A recombinant fusion protein acting as a TGF-\u03b2 superfamily ligand trap.
    • Promotes late-stage erythroid differentiation, enhancing red blood cell production.
    • FDA-approved for adult patients with beta-thalassemia who require regular blood transfusions.
    • Reduces transfusion dependency and may indirectly reduce iron overload by minimizing transfusion frequency.

Deferoxamine (Option B):

  • Parenteral iron chelator used to treat iron overload from frequent transfusions.
  • Helps lower ferritin and transferrin saturation.
  • Does not address anemia or reduce the need for transfusions.

Deferiprone (Option C):

  • Oral iron chelator.
  • Used when deferoxamine is not tolerated or effective.
  • Also does not affect erythropoiesis or transfusion dependency.

Voxelotor (Option D):

  • Approved for sickle cell disease, not beta-thalassemia.
  • Works by increasing hemoglobin's oxygen affinity and preventing sickling.
  • Not indicated for thalassemia and has no role in transfusion reduction in these patients.

questions.text: You are assisting in thoracocentesis for massive unilateral Hydrothorax. Which of the following is most important step in preventing complications

choices.text: Insert needle along lower border of upper rib
Perform procedure with patient in prone position
Advance needle when patient is breathing in
Limit fluid removal to less than 1.5 L

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Limit fluid removal to less than 1.5 L

Explanation:

  • The most important step to prevent complications during thoracocentesis, especially in massive pleural effusion (hydrothorax), is to limit the volume of fluid removed in a single sitting.
  • In thoracocentesis maximum amount of fluid removed is 1.5L per sitting to minimize the risk of re-expansion pulmonary edema, which can be life-threatening. This occurs due to rapid re-expansion of a chronically collapsed lung.
  • Insertion along the lower border of upper rib (Option A) will injure neurovascular bundle.
  • Standard position is sitting upright, leaning forward over a table. Prone position is not used.(Option B)
  • Needle advancement is not timed with respiration. (Option C)

questions.text: Teenager jumps into water head first and develops sudden onset quadriplegia. Which of the following is correct about this condition
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Jefferson fracture

Explanation:

Jefferson fracture (Option A) refers to a burst fracture of the C1 vertebra (atlas), typically caused by axial loading, such as when someone dives head-first into shallow water. The force is transmitted from the skull through the occipital condyles to the lateral masses of the atlas, leading to a fracture of the anterior and posterior arches of C1.

  • Mechanism: Axial compression from diving accidents
  • Presentation: Neck pain, possibly with quadriplegia if the spinal cord or medulla is involved
  • Imaging: Lateral displacement of lateral masses of C1 on open-mouth (odontoid) X-ray or CT
  • Stability: Potentially unstable if transverse ligament is ruptured

Hangman fracture (Option B) is a traumatic spondylolisthesis of C2 involving bilateral fracture of the pars interarticularis. It occurs due to hyperextension and distraction, like in hanging or road traffic accidents - not axial compression.

Clay shoveller fracture (Option C) is an avulsion fracture of the spinous process, usually C6 or C7. It results from forceful muscle contraction — not typically associated with quadriplegia or severe neurological deficits.

Odontoid fracture (Option D) involves the dens (odontoid process) of C2. While it can be serious, it usually results from flexion or extension injury in elderly or trauma, not classic for diving injuries leading to burst fractures.

questions.text: A patient with blunt trauma to the chest is brought to hospital. On examination he is using accessory muscles of respiration and trachea appears deviated to the contralateral side. Breath sounds appear distant with dullness to percussion. Which of the following should be done in this patient?

choices.text: Urgent wide bore needle in 5th ICS in mid axillary line
Urgent wide bore needle in 2nd ICS in mid clavicular line
Do blood grouping and cross matching and start massive transfusion protocol

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Urgent CXR

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with signs of respiratory distress and mediastinal shift.
  • However, breath sounds are diminished and dullness to percussion is noted — these findings suggest a hemothorax, not a pneumothorax.
  • Therefore, an urgent chest X-ray (CXR) is necessary to differentiate between hemothorax and tension pneumothorax before intervention.

Chest Trauma with Decreased Breath Sounds and Dull Percussion

Likely Diagnosis:

  • Hemothorax - accumulation of blood in the pleural cavity.
  • Presents with decreased breath sounds, dullness to percussion, tracheal deviation, and dyspnea.

Causes:

  • Trauma (rib fractures lacerating intercostal vessels or lung parenchyma)
  • Post-operative bleeding

Clinical Examination Clues:

  • Hyperresonance suggests pneumothorax.
  • Dullness to percussion suggests fluid - likely blood in this setting.
  • Tracheal deviation can occur in massive hemothorax as well as in tension pneumothorax.

Initial Steps:

  • Obtain an urgent CXR to confirm diagnosis and estimate volume.
  • CXR will reveal a fluid level or white-out of affected hemithorax in case of hemothorax.

Further Management:

  • If hemothorax is confirmed: insert chest tube and monitor output.
  • If tension pneumothorax is found: immediate needle decompression followed by chest tube.

Urgent wide bore needle in 5th ICS in mid axillary line (Option B):

  • This is the standard site for chest tube placement, not needle decompression.
  • Needle decompression is not first in suspected hemothorax with dullness.

Urgent wide bore needle in 2nd ICS in mid clavicular line (Option C):

  • Correct for tension pneumothorax, which presents with hyperresonant percussion.
  • In this case, percussion is dull, favoring hemothorax, not air accumulation.

Do blood grouping and cross matching and start massive transfusion protocol (Option D):

  • Premature unless evidence of massive hemorrhage or shock.
  • Although important later in management, the first step is to confirm diagnosis via imaging.

questions.text: Name the condition shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dropped shoulder

Explanation:

The condition shown in the image, characterized by one shoulder being lower than the other, is known as Dropped Shoulder.

  • Causes:
    • Trapezius muscle weakness or paralysis
    • Accessory nerve injury
    • Postural issues
    • Clavicle fractures or deformities

 

Spinal accessory nerve damage

Winging of scapula

  • Serratus anterior palsy
  • Long thoracic nerve

 

Winging of scapula (Option B) is a condition where the inner (medial) border of the scapula sticks out prominently, especially when the person pushes against a wall. This happens because of paralysis or weakness of the serratus anterior muscle, which is usually caused by injury to the long thoracic nerve. The protrusion of the scapula resembles a wing, which is how the condition gets its name.

Sprengel deformity (Option C) is a congenital failure of descent of the scapula, leading to a high-riding, hypoplastic scapula. It is often associated with limited abduction, short neck, and sometimes an omovertebral bone.

Klippel-Fiel syndrome (Option D) may co-exist and is characterized by cervical vertebral fusion.
